story:
Short Summary

Hi Everyone!

I am Ashley's older sister. I look forward to seeing you at the big event-Ashley and Jimmy's wedding!

I had an idea for a wedding SURPRISE. Ashley and Jimmy will be married in the historic Dryden theater (part of the George Eastman House).  The Dryden, was recently renovated. To help with funds for the project, they have offered the community an opportunity to purchase seats in the theater.

Wouldn't it be great if we could SURPRISE Ashley and Jimmy on their wedding day, with a seat of their own?  We could commemorate their speial day AND support one of their favorite local causes. 

What We Need & What You Get

We don't need much, just about the cost of a movie ticket ($10-$15) each. You can contribute right here on this site!  So easy! Their special day is almost here, so we hope to purchase the seat ASAP. 

The Impact

We think they would be touched to have this added to their special day. 

 

Here's some info on the Dryden Project:

http://eastmanhouse.org/takeaseat/

http://dryden.eastmanhouse.org/

 

ANY QUESTIONS CONTACT ME AT amybetti@gmail.com, and remember, it is a surprise!

story:
FOR THE LAST 10 DAYS- MORE BANG FOR YOUR BUCK! MORE PERKS!

$50- ACCESS TO LIVESTREAM EVENT- Great if you're out of town! See the show despite the distance! (Plus all other perks at the $50 level!)

GET THE $100 "TWO TICKETS PERKS" FOR JUST $75!! 

GET THE $150 "THANK YOU VIDEO" PERKS FOR JUST $100!!

WE'RE SO CLOSE TO OUR GOAL! HELP US MAKE IT!

(ALL PERKS NOW COME WITH MAILED THANK YOU CARDS FROM DIRECTOR REBECCA SCOLNICK- Who doesn't love mail?)

What is PROOF?

PROOF is a Pulitzer Prize winning play by David Auburn, that follows Catherine, her estranged sister Claire, and a former student of their father Robert's named Hal, during the days after Robert's sudden death. Although all are extremely intelligent mathematically, they struggle with human relationships- never finding that perfect answer. Catherine is also dealing with the possibility of inheriting her father's insanity, which lead to the demise of his mathematics career.

After it's Broadway debut in 2000 starring Mary Louise Parker as Catherine, PROOF won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama, took home multiple Tonys including Best Play, and was adapted into a film starring Gwyneth Paltrow, Jake Gyllenhaal, and Anthony Hopkins in 2005.

In January 2014, PROOF is returning to New York City for 5 performances at The Producer's Club, in the heart of the theatre district!

Who are we?

Director and Producer Rebecca Scolnick moved to NYC from Folsom, California to study acting at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. She will graduate in December of 2013. "I am thrilled to be a part of PROOF and to have the opportunity to start my career here in New York so soon after graduation! Please help us make this adventure possible! We've already set the wheels in motion and we need you to keep us going! xx, Rebecca."

Producer and Actress Gabrielle Loneck grew up in upstate New York and completed her training at Pace University in NYC, and the William Esper Studio. She has worked with many theatre companies in the city including The Seeing Place, and is now producing her own work with PROOF, playing Catherine. "I am thrilled and humbled to be working on such an exceptional piece with equally inspiring cast members and director. I am so excited to see everything come together and be able to share a real and relevant story with friends, family and supporters."

  • Additional Cast:
  • Catherine: Gabrielle Loneck
  • Hal: Daniel Perez
  • Robert: Craig Stoebling
  • Claire: Natalya Krimgold

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking to raise $5,000. If you donate to our project, you will be funding:

- Theatre rental

- Rights to the play

- Rehearsal space rental

- Costumes, Props, etc.

- Marketing materials and Promotional expenses

- Additional funds will help compensate those generous people that have donated their time and efforts to our production.

For your donations, we have a list of perks (check them out on the right!) that we've created. We hope they will show our deep appreciation and gratitude for helping us continue our production and our careers in NYC!! Without your help, this journey will not be possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you absolutely can't contribute financially, please help us spread the word!!!

Share our link on Facebook: www.facebook.com/proofnyc2014

Tweet about us! www.twitter.com/proofnyc2014 @proofnyc2014

Read and share our blog! www.blogger.com/proofnyc2014

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU! We really do appreciate all of your help and support and hope to see you in January for PROOF!

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU! We really do appreciate all of your help and support and hope to see you in January for PROOF!

story:
I live in Chicago, and am sick to hear of yet another shooting, which this time has wounded over a dozen people: http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/chi-multiple-people-including-3yearold-shot-in-south-side-attack-20130919,0,352520.story. Making Chicago safe for everyone who lives here is going to take a lot of time, change, commitment, and policy, and I don't know all the the answers to how to make it happen. But I know that I and many others want to be able to do something.

I was living in Boston after the Marathon Bombing, and almost immediately the One Fund developed to support victims of the violence and their families - it certainly didn't fix everything, but it seems it has made a difference, and has given people a way to show their support of families who can feel isolated and unseen even in the midst of their grief. To me, that seems like the least we can do for the victims of this terrifying and ongoing violence.

So this is a fundraising campaign to show our support, ending on November 1st, All Saints Day, when I hope we can honor and remember all who have died in our city this year. I would love to figure out a way to get this directly to victims' families, but since I don't really understand how that would work legally or logistically yet, and I don't know how much we can raise that would be meaningful for the at least 312 murder victims already this year (you can find their names here: http://homicides.redeyechicago.com/), for now the promise is that the money will go to CeaseFire Illinois, an organization with a proven track record in reducing violence in Chicago which has recently had to shut two offices because of lack of funding from the city and state: http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-09-13/news/ct-met-cease-fire-contract-20130914-36_1_ceasefire-illinois-2-communities-domestic-violence-charges. (The non-profit Indigogo names is the University of Illinois Foundation, because all donations to CeaseFire, also known as Cure Violence, are processed through them.)

If anyone has better ideas let me know. I, like most, am at a loss, and this with my prayers is just an attempt to throw a raindrop at a fire, which seems to not be getting any attention from our politicians and policy makers. In prayers for all experiencing violence, and especially those in neighborhoods in Chicago who are routinely exposed to violence.

story:
About The Gang

Elisabeth Schiffbauer & The BigStrongGang is dedicated to dance, movement, and artistic expression. Through our work we aim to do away with pre-conceived notions and stigmas surrounding dance.Our goal is to break boundaries between music and movement and to challenge our audience by showing then something unique and unfamiliar. Our works exemplify the core themes of freedom, rebellion, immediacy, and progressiveness of contemporary music. We believe that dance resonates and connects with individuals more than other art forms because it is through the physical body. Dance is a powerful medium through which we exchange knowledge by collaboration.


What's in a Gang?


Big. We believe in moving big.

Strong. We are each strong individuals. Together, we make an even stronger group.

Gang. A gang is a group or organization that shares a common identity, this often involves defying mainstream norms.


About Fuse

Fuse reflects the joining together of singer M.I.A.'s hip hop rhythms and stylistic elements of ballet, modern, and hip hop to create a new, dynamic and energetic piece of contemporary ballet. The piece explores the physical potential of the individual and the joy of movement within a community.

The Impact

Elisabeth Schiffbauer & The BigStrongGang have been selected to perform an excerpt from Fuse with music by M.I.A. for the Pasadena Dance Festival. Proceeds from the Pasadena Dance Festival will go to Dance for Parkinson's and Dance for People with Down Syndrome.

$4,435.00 is a lot of money...

$4,435.00 will help us cover our expenses to the festival, at the festival, and from the festival. Here's what we need and what your money will go towards:


Rehearsal space for 10 weeks at $175.00/week: $1,075.00

Costumes: $300.00

Travel Stipends for Dancers: $490.00

Round-trip Airfare: $1,200.00

Hotel for Tech Weekend: $400.00

Hotel for Festival Days: $250.00

Transportation for Tech Weekend: $500.00

Transportation for Festival Days: $220.00


TOTAL: $4,435.00


Pasadena Dance Festival provides us with a venue, lighting, and publicity. Thanks Pasadena Dance Festival!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help us with a donation today, don't worry! There are other ways you can help! Spread the word about us! Tell your friends nearby to buy tickets to the show http://lineagedance.org/performanceevents/.

Forward this campaign to others! Post our campaign on your Facebook! Tweet about it! Every little bit will help us get there!

story:
Our Story

 

Liz Ulmer, Moxyrah Productions, and Dreamcatcher Entertainment are aiming to present a one-night only concert reading presentation of the parody Twilight: The Musical (A parody) January 16th, 2012 at 8pm to benefit national charity organization Blessings in a Backpack. The concert will be directed by Gabriel Barre, with music direction by David John Madore, and will presented at New World Stages in Times Square. (To purchase tickets, please call telecharge, or go to: 

http://www.telecharge.com/go.aspx?MD=102&PID=8718&AID=CRP000871800

For more information please visit www.thetwilightmusical.com)

 

All net proceeds will benefit national charity organization Blessings in a Backpack. 

 

Blessings in a Backpack (http://www.blessingsinabackpack.org/) is a unique program designed to feed elementary school children whose families qualify for the federal Free and Reduced Price Meal program, and have little to no food on the weekends. Better test scores, improved reading skills, positive behavior; improved health and increased attendance have all been attributed to the success of this program. $80 feeds a child in the program for an entire school year.

Blessings in a Backpack is a 501 C (3) non-profit organization currently feeding over 55,000 children in 318 schools in 37 U.S. states and three countries - Canada, Columbia and Haiti.

 

 

Twilight: The Musical is a parody of the Twilight saga in the vein of Urinetown and The Rocky Horror Picture Show. Twilight: The Musical examines our culture of obsession through the story of teenage outsider Bella Swan who risks everything when she embarks on a star-crossed romance with Vampire Edward Cullen.

 

Twilight: The Musical was created by Ashley Griffin, and features a book by Ashley Griffin, with music and lyrics by Jeremy Ezell, Ashley Griffin, Sean Mahoney, David Mallamud, and Michael Sutherland. The show had its first workshop in NYC in 2010 at the LABA theater, and is currently in development in NYC.

 

 

The concert will feature wonderful Broadway performers (casting to be announced soon) - and everyone is donating their time and resources in order to give back as much as possible to Blessings in a Backpack.  

 


The Impact

This concert, besides being a wonderfully entertaining evening, has the potential to raise a significant amount of money for this fantastic charity. If we don't raise enough money for overhead costs, this great opportunity will be lost. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Right now we've set our campaign goal at $5,000 - though we would love to try and raise more than that. Reaching this goal will guarantee our overhead costs for the space will be met, and will significantly ground our footing proceeding with this event. We are currently in the process of pursuing other funding sources including corporate sponsorship, and private donations. We've already received support from Sam Ash - who have provided some wonderful perks for indiegogo donors. Any amount of money raised will help this event move forward, but the more we can raise, the better (and the more we raise, the more we'll be able to donate to Blessings in a Backpack at the end of the concert.)  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out! Please share the link to this campaign with everyone you can - post it to facebook, twitter, or just tell your friends! You can also purchase tickets to the event (visit telecharge at: 

http://www.telecharge.com/go.aspx?MD=102&PID=8718&AID=CRP000871800)

 

If you are a corporation, or know a corporation that would be interested in sponsoring the event - please let us know (you can always contact us at: info@thetwilightmusical.com)

story:
“Probably my favourite of all the plays I saw this year...squarely on the side of ingenious” --VUE Magazine

Support a dream!

Small theatre depends on the supporters of the arts to survive and succeed. We have been given a once in a lifetime opportunity to take ONE to The SummerWorks  Theatre Festival in Toronto where we will be performing in the famous Factory Theatre. This is our big chance to be seen by producers from across the globe looking for the next big show to produce!

Help the cast and crew fulfil this dream and possibly be a part of the magic that gets ONE shown across the country, and the world. Please, take a moment now and become a part of this dream!

In return of your donation you will receive:
$5 to 19 – a tweet and Facebook post from everyone in the cast thanking you.

$20 to $99 – A credit as a producer on all our collateral, a tweet and Facebook post from everyone in the cast thanking you.

$100 – $4,999 – A credit as an executive producer, a tweet and Facebook post from everyone in the cast thanking you, a signed poster from all the cast.

$5,000 – $10, 000 - A flight out to Toronto, tickets to opening night, credit as an executive producer, hang with the crew, and we will put your image up on our mantel of awesomeness…forever!


Anyone who has seen ONE will say that it is an amazing show, filled with images and emotions that stay with you for long after the curtain closes. Just have a read at one of our many amazing reviews that we have been getting every time it has been produced.

ONE - Love, Loss, and Memory. | Avenue Magazine
www.avenuecalgary.com/blogs/post/one-love-loss-...

Or have a look at the video above

Who We Are:
Created in 2004, Redtoblue Performance is an Alberta based multi‐disciplinary production company focused on creating new, highly visual work using all mediums of performance. Drawing from a wide range of artists, Redtoblue creates work in theatre, dance, sound and film while also working to encourage the development of new work through classes and workshops. The company’s theatrical style is characterized by a total encompassing of the audience with each element of the performance: movement, space, costume, lighting, sound and direction. The result is the creation of an entire world in which the audience can disappear.

The Show:
ONE is a visually stunning re-imagining of the Orpheus and Eurydice myth that follows the desperate journey of Philistine; a librarian whose devoted search for a lover ‘lost at sea’ takes her beyond the living world, and into the strange and all-consuming world of the dead. Through wild choreography, poetic language, innovative design and evocative soundscape ONE delivers an experience that is at once an engaging narrative and a sensory adventure.



Touring History of ONE:

- NextFest Emerging Artist Festival, Edmonton, Alberta 2006
- Edmonton International Fringe Festival, Edmonton, Alberta, 2006
- International Canoe Festival, Edmonton, Alberta,, 2008
- Revolutions International Theatre Festival, in Albuquerque, New Mexico 2010.
- Ghost River Theatre’s 2010/11 Season, Calgary, Alberta.

Our Costs:
Your donations will go to support each and every person or item in this list: 
We have 7 artists (4 actors, 1 Stage Manager, 1 Director, and 1 Stage Hand) a dance captain joining us for rehearsal in Edmonton, a Production Designer, Sound Designer, and Install Technician. We need to rent rehearsal space in Edmonton and pay union fees. We also require publicity material (Posters, programs, and flyers.) 

Thank you so much for considering supporting our dream!

The entire crew from Redtoblue Performance

The result is the creation of an entire world in which the audience can disappear.The Show:ONE is a visually stunning re-imagining of the Orpheus and Eurydice myth that follows the desperate journey of Philistine; a librarian whose devoted search for a lover ‘lost at sea’ takes her beyond the living world, and into the strange and all-consuming world of the dead. Through wild choreography, poetic language, innovative design and evocative soundscape ONE delivers an experience that is at once an engaging narrative and a sensory adventure.Touring History of ONE:-	NextFest Emerging Artist Festival, Edmonton, Alberta 2006-	Edmonton International Fringe Festival, Edmonton, Alberta, 2006-	International Canoe Festival, Edmonton, Alberta,, 2008-	Revolutions International Theatre Festival, in Albuquerque, New Mexico 2010.-	Ghost River Theatre’s 2010/11 Season, Calgary, Alberta.Our Costs:Your donations will go to support each and every person or item in this list: We have 7 artists (4 actors, 1 Stage Manager, 1 Director, and 1 Stage Hand) a dance captain joining us for rehearsal in Edmonton, a Production Designer, Sound Designer, and Install Technician. We need to rent rehearsal space in Edmonton and pay union fees. We also require publicity material (Posters, programs, and flyers.) Thank you so much for considering supporting our dream!The entire crew from Redtoblue Performance

story:
With your help, we will be able to bring African Lesbian Activists fighting for the rights of LGBTQ people in 11 African countries to the U.S., so they can tell their stories, be part of the revolutionary performance, Mother Tongue Monologues, and so we can build solidarity across gender-justice movements.

We cordially invite you to contribute to Black Women's Blueprint's Mother Tongue Monologues for Lesbian Ancestral Wives and Revolutionary Women Speaking the Unspeakable, as we make a critical pivot in the movement for gender-justice, speak truth to power and link our local stories to the global voices of women and lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer people and allies who want to love freely and without persecution. February 16-18 at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in New York, NY.

This play is for you. This play is about us. Women-loving-women, men-loving-men, human-loving-humans who have had to love, in secret, in shame, and far too often, in fear. This work of daring truth telling is about those of us who have watched love ones live in isolation, trepidation, and with too few affirmations. And, this night is about those of us who by the grace of the universe and beat of our boots, fought to create spaces where we could love, live, and lust in full bloom.  Cause like it was said in the 1990’s: every time we make love, we win.  And anytime we mouth the words to our wives, husbands, or gender non-conforming sweethearts, we rewrite the story and defy the status quo. Tonight, we are here to celebrate, rage, and honor the courage it has taken to persist.  This production is our moment.  

Poets, drummers, dancers and actors dramatizing and performing community will speak of gay and lesbian identities of people in Black communities that remain even today, hidden, intensely controversial, and/or dismissed as an insignificant aspect of their lives. The Black lesbian in particular, who stands at the crossroads of two well-developed ideologies in America, one about women and one about “the Negro”, remains a dangerous site saturated with the belief that female sexual energy deserves punishment.

The performance shatters the dominant paradigm that insists on seeing only tragedy in lesbian existence, by lifting up the narratives of ancestral wives—lesbians of pre-colonial Africa, contemporary lesbians, and defiant lesbians like Barbara Smith, Audre Lorde, Cheryl Clark, and Jewelle Gomez. These women are among many who’ve contributed to liberation struggles, the American civil rights, Black power, feminist and gay rights movements and whose existence continue to take on a particular poignancy of courage. For Black women, trapped in families, communities, and internalized hatred, their words have been a place of solace, understanding, and validation.  Their words for some have been the breath needed to keep living---affirming the right to exist and revel in our splendor.

Transgender men and women, gender non-conformers and straight allies will also share center stage as a force to demand an end to domination. Visitors from 11 African countries, funded by your generosity, will also be present at the production to bear witness to these stories, tell their own, build bridges and solidarity with gender justice movements across the Atlantic, and ensure that this evening is the start to a movement.

When you open your wallet to contribute to Mother Tongue Monologues, you send a powerful statement that our sexuality will not be silenced. If you have ever been paralyzed by fear, uncertainty or ignorance, now is your time to step up and show support to someone you were not able to do that for before. Stand with us in solidarity. The costs of a high-impact show, however, are not low. 

-----------------

Now in its third year, Mother Tongue Monologues has been wildly successful-- a critical catharsis for the Black community and allies to gather and speak truth to power. This year, we want to speak the unspeakable.  

We lay claim to all that is lush, rich, warm, hollow, happy and somber. It is all ours. We lay claim to moving freely, from shore to shore and land to land. Every place belongs to us. We lay claim to intimacy. We lay claim to love. 

Join us on our journey. Please donate.

--------------------------

We understand that times are difficult for many, but that ability to pay should never interfere with the ability to give voice to our collective demands. If you are unable to donate to the production, there are a few other actions you can take to help us reach our goal. We'd be forever grateful if you could:

  • Share our campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr or other social networks and ask your contacts to donate on your behalf (you can use the Indiegogo buttons right on this page!)
  • Write a blog post about Mother Tongue Monologues and ask your readers to donate.
  • Talk about Black sexual politics with your friends, family, neighbors and young women in your sphere and tell them about the campaign.

Have questions or want to collaborate on outreach? Shoot an email to info@blueprintny.org

story:
Inspired by

No Place like Home: a Memoir in 39 Apartments

Crashbox, an off-off-Broadway theater company, will be producing two full-length plays by Brooke Berman for our 2013 season.  We have been lucky enough to have an ongoing dialogue with the playwright over the course of the past year.  She has generously entrusted us with the world premiere of The Liddy Plays - and offered to be a part of our rehearsal process in the months ahead. We are calling this series: Crashing with Brooke Berman.  The plays...

 

Hunting and Gathering

A dark comedy about finding your place. 

Directed by Alison Beatty, Assistant Director: Milee Bang

March 21-24, 2013

Eric Southern and Chris Morris - Lighting and Scenic Design
Gigi Hernandez - Costume Design
Griffin Sherbert - Music and Sound Design
Meridith Jones - Props Master and production Manager
Jolenta Greenberg - House Manager
Jon Friestedt- Stage Management

 

The Liddy Plays

(World Premiere)

A cycle of short inter-connected plays about an enigmatic brother and sister, seeking and learning as they confront the death of their mother

Directed by Sharone Halevy

May 16-25, 2013

 

*Both productions will be performed at the Access Theater, 380 Broadway

Featuring: Michael Sean Cirelli, Meridith Jones, Keilly McQuail, Tom Muccioli, Rebecca Schoffer, Jordan Douglas Smith, Erica Genereux Smith.

 

Both of these plays have parallel themes of spirituality, healing and home. What's even more intriguing: Both plays draw on the experiences of the playwright's own transient lifestyle and search for meaning as discussed in her memoir No Place Like Home: a Memoir in 39 Apartments.

 

Your Donations Allow Us to Buy:

  • Rehearsal Space (Just like rent in NYC, rehearsal space does not come cheap!)
  • Theater Rental
  • Insurance
  • A modest budget for our designers and marketing team

*See perks for what you will recieve in exchange for your generosity.

T-shirt available with donation of $50 or more:

printed by our friends at The Vanity Project

The Impact

With your donation, you contribute to our company’s longevity.  We hope to bring many more works to the New York stages in the years ahead.  Crashbox searches for plays we feel are vital, inspiring and progressive. Brooke Berman’s writing exemplifies these characteristics. Each play has the power to bring its audiences clarity and peace.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our fundraising campaign with your friends!
  • Volunteer? Contact: MeridithJones@crashboxtheater.org
  • Purchase Tickets Here!

story:
My name is Annalyn Lehnig and I am a theater artist with a penchant for cross-disciplinary collaboration. In 2008, under the guidance and direction of Alma Schneider, I wrote and performed THE CIRCUS LOVESICK, a one-woman show that explores the disorder and the downfalls, the majesty and the mayhem of love through monologues delivered to the audience by six lovesick circus performers. THE CIRCUS LOVESICK is happening again, now, in New Orleans.  It’s happening in an opium-scented, freak show circus brothel and it’s a glorious shame! March 2013.

Help manifest the grit and glitter of THE CIRCUS LOVESICK fantasy. Give a little or give a lot and let The Marionette, The Fire Breather, The Juggler, The Lion Tamer, The Tight Rope Walker and The Freak give back to you. As far as dollars go, the more we get, the grander the show. We’ll involve more artists and performers to help create a more luxurious circus.

Your loving giving will get you a personal love letter from one of these lovesick ladies. Give a little more and get a signed portrait from the lady of your choice.  How about an autographed ball belonging to the Infamous, Incredible, Insatiable Ingrid, THE CIRCUS LOVESICK’S Juggler? For you high-balling, big spending, pleasure-seeking love purveyors, you could give to get the ultimate prize – a date with the lovesick lady of your choosing!

THE CIRCUS LOVESICK lovesick ladies are ready to step into the ring with sumptuous desperation and make you feel. Come see! This show is taut and hot and yearning to inspire you, upset you and arouse you. THE CIRCUS LOVESICK submits to you.

 THE CIRCUS LOVESICK knows that the price of giving doesn’t always begin with a $. We know that giving-in means giving love and giving love means spread the word. THE CIRCUS LOVESICK is coming to town! Give by being a fellow solicitor and help us fill our seats with a loving audience. Share this video! Share the LOVE!

story:
Be A Big Mouth

I’m Bess Welden, a Portland, Maine-based actor and writer. Over the last several months I’ve been working with an incredible team of collaborators to prepare for the world premiere of my latest one-woman show, BIG MOUTH THUNDER THIGHS: A Solo Vaudeville. The creative staff includes: Jennie Hahn (director), Stacey M. Koloski (set/props), Christine Nilles (costumes), Chris Fitze (sound), Emily Kenny (lights), Alexander Adams (puppet maker), Deb Freedman (choreographer), and Emily Dixon (stage manager) Check out all of our bios at  www.bigmouththunderthighs.com.

On the one hand, BIG MOUTH THUNDER THIGHS is memoir storytelling. On the other, it’s a highly-theatrical, unpredictable, and outrageously entertaining variety show featuring: roller-skating, stand-up comedy, country-western singing, flamenco dancing, a Shakespearean monologue, a Broadway style song and dance number, an Inuit folktale, original Spoken Word-style poems, and a series of five “Death-Defying Acts.” And, in the crucial role of the perfectionist arch nemesis - Skinny Bitch - a puppet like you’ve never seen before. It’s a one-woman extravaganza about hunger, appetite, fear, largeness, enoughness, loneliness, aloneness, and what it takes for us to accept ourselves. It’s deeply personal and surprisingly funny.

The show will have its first run in the debut season of the Portland Stage Studio Rep (www.portlandstage.org) this coming February and March, which will set the stage for future productions around the country.

We need to raise $5,000 to reach our overall budget of $13,000, which will cover production expenses and marketing the show to future producers. The great news is that we already have $8,000 in the bank from a grant from the Maine Arts Commission and contributions from people who have seen readings of the play and believe in its message.

With just five weeks before Opening Night, I’m turning to you to ask for contributions that will help pay for:

1) Production Expenses: fees for artistic collaborators (director/designers/stage manager); rehearsal space; props, set and costumes; materials for puppet construction

2) Marketing investments to attract future producers/presenters: video shoot of live performance; video editing; custom website creation and hosting; still photography; reproduction costs of show DVD

In exchange for your contribution, you’ll have the satisfaction of knowing you helped bring a brand new play to life and get a fun perk or two. More importantly, though, you will be helping people who struggle with food and their bodies to see how having the courage to tell the truth about ourselves and laugh can be the first step toward giving up the fight once and for all.

Other Ways to Help

Once you’ve made a contribution (thank you!) you can help us a few other ways:

1) Send a link to this campaign to other people you know who will resonate with the message of the show.

2) Come to the show and see how your generous contribution helped make it all come to life. Visit www.bigmouththunderthighs.com for performance dates and times and then call 207-774-0465 or order online at www.portlandstage.org.

3) Volunteer to be a House Manager/Usher and get a free ticket to the show. You’ll have to come early for a very brief training session, but a free ticket is worth it. Email us directly if you’re interested at bigmouththunderthighs@gmail.com.

4) If you aren’t anywhere near Portland, Maine but want to see the show, email us at bigmouththunderthighs@gmail.com with a contact name at your local theater/performance venue so we can reach out and say you sent us. The show is designed to travel.

story:
Buy your tickets now! Click Contribute Now and donate $20 for each ticket you wish to buy.

We expect to sell out before the event, so get your tickets today!

 

The Rivalry

Here in Chicago, we have a bit of a rivalry with New York. Deep dish pizza vs. Thin crust. Bears vs. Giants. Sweet smelling transit system vs. Sweet smelling transit system.

But when something as big as the recent superstorm affects so many people, you have to put petty rivalries off to the side and do everything you can to help. This campaign and benefit performance are meant to do just that.

The Show (12/2/2012 @ 7 p.m.)

We are putting together a diverse lineup of comedy acts together from all over the area to perform on Sunday, December 2nd at the Skokie Theatre just outside the city at 7 p.m. Tickets for the show are $20 a piece and all proceeds will go directly to the Red Cross to benefit victims of Hurricane Sandy in New York and New Jersey.

Beyond the Show

One of the reasons we ran the campaign through IndieGoGo is so that people who can't attend the show would still be able to help. Even if you contribute $1 you will be listed as a donor on our website. Donate $10 and we'll put you in the program. Donate more and you can even be listed as a Silver or Gold Donor or have your business represented in the program with an advertisement.
 
All donations are going to the Red Cross and are therefore tax-deductable.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign far and wide. Spread it around on Facebook, Twitter, etc. We've set a funding goal of $2,500, but if we sell out the show and get a lot of additional donors, we may be able to far surpass the goal. Meeting or exceeding the goal will truly show that Chicago cares.

FAQs

Why does it look like there are only 40 tickets available?

There are actually 150 seats in the Skokie Theater. We're just keeping the perk at 40 available to compensate for people who buy multiple tickets. If you want to buy more than one ticket, just donate $20 for each ticket you want to buy. We will make more tickets available here soon.

What if I want to be a Gold or Silver Donor and get one or more tickets?

If you donate more than $50 and you want to attend the show, select the $20 ticket perk. We'll still list you as a Silver or Gold Donor, we just want to keep track of how many tickets have been claimed.

Why do I have to enter my shipping info for the ticket? Will you be shipping the tickets?

No, we will not be shipping the tickets, we'll handle all of that digitally. While you have to put in the shipping information (because we made the ticket a limited perk), we will not be using that shipping info for anything, so don't worry, your info is safe with us.

What acts are performing at the show?

We are negotiating with several awesome Chicago comedy groups to come. Currently we have the Underage Sugar Addicts, Rom-Com, Urlakis and Cusick, comedic musician Matt Griffo and Pimprov confirmed and we'll update this list with more performers as we have them.

Find out more about them here:

http://facebook.com/usaimprov

http://www.facebook.com/romcomimprov

http://www.youtube.com/user/UrlakisandCusick

http://mattgriffo.com/

http://www.pimprov.com/Pimprov/Home.html

How do I get to the Skokie Theater?

The Skokie Theater is located at 7924 Lincoln Ave. in Skokie. The theater is a half-mile away from the Oakton-Skokie station on the CTA's Yellow Line. There is street parking available in the area in addition to several parking lots. More information on parking is available here:

http://www.skokie.org/downtown/parking.cfm

What is the Red Cross doing to help?

As of 11/11/2012, the Red Cross was sheltering some 3,700 people and had delivered more than 4.8 million meals or snacks, and more than 477,000 relief items, according to NBC News.

Beyond the Show
One of the reasons we ran the campaign through IndieGoGo is so that people who can't attend the show would still be able to help. Even if you contribute $1 you will be listed as a donor on our website. Donate $10 and we'll put you in the program. Donate more and you can even be listed as a Silver or Gold Donor or have your business represented in the program with an advertisement.
 
All donations are going to the Red Cross and are therefore tax-deductable.

Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this campaign far and wide. Spread it around on Facebook, Twitter, etc. We've set a funding goal of $2,500, but if we sell out the show and get a lot of additional donors, we may be able to far surpass the goal. Meeting or exceeding the goal will truly show that Chicago cares.

FAQs
Why does it look like there are only 40 tickets available?
There are actually 150 seats in the Skokie Theater. We're just keeping the perk at 40 available to compensate for people who buy multiple tickets. If you want to buy more than one ticket, just donate $20 for each ticket you want to buy. We will make more tickets available here soon.
What if I want to be a Gold or Silver Donor and get one or more tickets?
If you donate more than $50 and you want to attend the show, select the $20 ticket perk. We'll still list you as a Silver or Gold Donor, we just want to keep track of how many tickets have been claimed.
Why do I have to enter my shipping info for the ticket? Will you be shipping the tickets?
No, we will not be shipping the tickets, we'll handle all of that digitally. While you have to put in the shipping information (because we made the ticket a limited perk), we will not be using that shipping info for anything, so don't worry, your info is safe with us.
What acts are performing at the show?
We are negotiating with several awesome Chicago comedy groups to come. Currently we have the Underage Sugar Addicts, Rom-Com, Urlakis and Cusick, comedic musician Matt Griffo and Pimprov confirmed and we'll update this list with more performers as we have them.
Find out more about them here:
http://facebook.com/usaimprov
http://www.facebook.com/romcomimprov
http://www.youtube.com/user/UrlakisandCusick
http://mattgriffo.com/
http://www.pimprov.com/Pimprov/Home.html
How do I get to the Skokie Theater?
The Skokie Theater is located at 7924 Lincoln Ave. in Skokie. The theater is a half-mile away from the Oakton-Skokie station on the CTA's Yellow Line. There is street parking available in the area in addition to several parking lots. More information on parking is available here:
http://www.skokie.org/downtown/parking.cfm
What is the Red Cross doing to help?
As of 11/11/2012, the Red Cross was sheltering some 3,700 people and had delivered more than 4.8 million meals or snacks, and more than 477,000 relief items, according to NBC News.

story:
Why we need you...

New Jersey Rep, (the 2012 recipient of the National Theatre Company Award by the American Theatre Wing) has selected To Paint the Earth to be part of their reading series with the intention of mounting a full production of the show in their 2014 season. The reading will be costly and we need funds to pay for our rehearsal space, MD/director/actor salaries, and transportation.

But most importantly...

The timing for To Paint the Earth could not be more fitting.  April 2013 will mark the 70th anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising and Warsaw ghetto survivor, Vladka Meed, the woman who inspired the musical, passed away on November 21st of this year. 

Our performance would serve as a way to honor Vladka and the work she did both during World War II, and afterwards, to continue to teach and educate the world about what happened.

Some background...

Written by Daniel Levin and composer, Jonathan Portera, To Paint the Earth tells the story of the thousands of tiny acts of Jewish resistance—studying, telling jokes, arguing, praying, falling in love—that kept life pulsing in the Warsaw Ghetto underneath German watch during WWII.

The show won the Richard Rogers Development Award (Stephen Sondheim, Committee Chair) and had a sold-out run at the 2008 New York Musical Theatre Festival. 

One of the great supporters of the show, lyricist Sheldon Harnick (Fiddler on the Roof) summed up the drama of the piece:

 “To Paint the Earth” is a remarkable achievement.  Daniel Levin and Jonathan Portera have managed to convey through the characters they have created and the story they enact, a gripping sense of what life was like in the last days of the Warsaw Ghetto during World War Two… This unusual and adventurous musical is a deeply moving experience.

story:
THE MUSICAL:

What would you do when the love you’ve sacrificed your world for betrays you? Inspired by the life of Marie Laveaux and adapted from Euripides The Medea, this rarely-produced musical by Michael John LaChiusa explores what it means to love unconditionally and culminates in incomprehensible vengeance when that love is betrayed.

In 1896, deep in the heart of New Orleans genteel creole society, a young priviledged woman of color finds herself mired by the men and social demands that govern her life. With headstrong disobedience and a gift for the power of Voodon she finds her escape in managing the love affairs of others. When an ambitious sea captain passes through town, she discovers her own all consuming love. Together they chart the waters of their romance to the burning streets of Chicago’s First Ward with a trail of blood along the way.


WHY NOW?

Marie Christine was the last major musical produced in New York City in the 20th century. It created quite a stir in the theatre community during its short lived run due to it’s controversial subject matter and the complexity of its structure. The show has never been produced in America since its Lincoln Centre closing. Thirteen years later the story is itching to be told again. In the wake of recent political debates, it has become clear that issues of race, basic human rights and feminist support still fall short of a level playing field. The United States is wrought with double standards. This deeply moving musical is a reminder that we as a “liberal” society, are not that much further along in our “free thinking” as we were in the late 1800’s. We need to challenge ourselves with art like this to keep forging ahead towards true equality regardless of race, orientation, sex or class. At the same time, this play deals with the brutal theme of murdering one’s own children. Recent events in America have demonstrated that such gruesome acts are a part of our reality. Regardless of what people’s positions on gun control are, one thing is clear: change is necessary. This theatre piece allows us to glimpse into the mind of a person who can contemplate such atrocities. It challenges its audience to consider how far their fury would take them and hopefully will enable people to consider the their own values and the necessary political change to a stronger and more proactive degree.

 

DATES:

Marie Christine will be performed at 3LD in downtown Manhattan for 5 limited performances between March 6th and 9th. For more information on tickets please visit: www.columbiastages.org

 

THE CREATIVE TEAM:

Director: Raymond Zilberberg

Producer: Anthony McDonald

Music Director: Marcus Baker

Choreographer: Joe Barros

Associate Music Director: Max Mamon

Stage Manager: Danielle Thomsen*

Set Designer: Jung Griffin

Costume Designer: Rebecca Welles

Lighting Designer: Christina Wantanbe

Sound Desginer: Julian Evans

Projection Designers: David Bengali

Fight Choreographer: Al Foote III

Dramaturg: Anika Chapin

Associate Choreographer: Miltery Tucker

Assitant Director: Cameron Perry

Assistant Stage Manager: Elizabeth Goodman

 

THE CAST:

Marie Christine: Gisela Adisa*

Dante Keyes: Shain Fike*

Prisoner #1: Talia Thiesfield*

Prisoner #2: Jessica Norland

Prisoner #3: Christy Hall

Marie Christine's Mother: Nicole Mitchell

Magdalena: Lanene Charters*

Jean: Angelo Rios*

Paris: Bruce Jones

Charles Gates: Bob D'Haene*

Lisette: Rachael Ferrera*

Ensembe:

Darilyn Castillo, Michael Ciccetti*, Mike Cruz, Tyrone Davis Jr.*,Liza Dealey, Tia D'Shazor, Alanna Fox, Jeffrey Funaro*, Jessica Giannone, Elizabeth Gray, John Hollingsworth, Adam Hyndman, Alexandra Smith, Mariana Weisler, Matthew Wiggen*

 

WHAT WE NEED:

Producing a musical is very expensive. We are raising $5000.00 to cover the cost production. Our cast and creative team are volunteering their time. This is a labor of love for a story that needs to be told and hasn't seen the light of day for thirteen years. Our costs include printing and distributing of publicity materials, matierals for set and props construction, 75 costumes for 26 actors, lighting equipment, projections software, the legal right to produce this show and transportation of equipment.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

By making a donation to this production you are enabling us to provide this musical and all the hard work we are putting into it, the production it deserves. Please see our different perk packages below.


If you are unable to help, please spread the word do pass on this campaign to those people who might be interested in helping our cause!

story:
USC’s Musical Theatre Repertory has been preparing for our spring production of Sweeney Todd. Our show is all ready to go, but now we need some support from you! All money donated will go directly to all production costs for Sweeney Todd, including costumes, our set, and performance space. The show opens on Thursday, January 24th through Sunday, January 27th in the Massman Theater on the USC campus. We can’t wait to show you all what we’ve been working so hard on. Thank you all so much in advance for your support, and we will see you all in January!

Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. Our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Explore our website [www.uscmtr.com] for general info about the company, ticketing details, upcoming events, production stills, and even a few production videos! Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

story:
LET'S CELEBRATE! 

Boston Community Dance Project is proud to celebrate their 6th year this summer and what better way to celebrate than with a wonderful show! VOCALIZE! will be a captivating production that you do not want to miss!

We are proud to announce that we will have TWO SHOWS this year as well as adding an Art Gallery part of the night festivities which will be located in The BU Dance Theater Lobby before entering into the theater! Sculptures, Painters, Graphic Designers, Poets, and more art related pieces will be showcased to support the local artists of our community and tie in the theme of vocalization right when you enter in! 

Part of the proceeds will go to our beautiful and hardworking dancers as well as a charity of BCDP's choice to bring dance to everyone! Our 2018 Charity Pick is still to be determined! 

BCDP BIO

Boston Community Dance Project was created in 2011 by Sarah-Katarina (SKooJ CorE-O) to bring artistry to the next level! BCDP concentrates in Contemporary and Fusion based movements, but also inspired by Modern, Musical Theater, Hip Hop, Jazz Funk, and Cultural Dance! BCDP strives to showcase the true art of story telling through movies, novels, and historical events. Since premiering their "Power Struggle" set, BCDP has been a part of The Massachusetts Dance Festival, SoulDeSoul Dance Gala, NACHMO, and many charity events on the East Coast. They have also performed in New York City at NYC Dance Week, NYC Dance Parade, and Carnival: Choreographers Ball. 

Reaching out to the community with realistic concepts, that connect all viewers emotionally is a mission for BCDP to help spread the positivity and the release dance can give towards all. Watch out for our “IMPROVIZE!” Workshops, CONTEMPORIZE Intensive, and our 2017 Summer Show at Boston University!

 

THE BREAKDOWN AND BUILDUP! 

$20 part of one costume 

$60- Printing show flyers and event brochures

$50- travel reinbursement for one dancer

$150 Fabric to use for the routines

$175 Programs for the show

$200 Make-Up Artist for the dancers

$750 Studio rentals for rehearsals

$600  Lighting Director and Crew Payment

$1500 total payment for guest artists to perform and teachers to come at our Intensive

$1100 Custom BCDP Apparel for the members and public

$1500 Costume reimbursement for all 29 dancers

$4000 rental of venue and insurance policies/liability agreements

As you can see our show needs more than $8000 however we thankful for each donation given! 

We will be continuously updated our social medias to show you rehearsal footage, member experiences, and weekly progress to making our show the best it can be. 

 

BRING VOCALIZE TO LIFE! 

Dance is a vessel to peoples' souls! We are hungry to bring a show that is inspired by real life scenarios and gear to all viewers. We want to spark the audience to free their movement and realize that there bodies are wanting to dance! 

STEP BY STEP! 

Our production is put together in 8 weeks! You can just imagine the excessive sweat, packed full rehearsals, and numerous meetings are needed to make this all be ready for when the curtain opens. 

Not only does Boston Community Dance Project have  16 fabulous Adult Company Dancers but there is also a Teen Apprentice Program that shows pre-professional dancers the real feel of being on a dance company! To mesh all the dancers into one cohesive product is always challenging but the process and ending result of seeing everyone together is a true prize in itself! 

 

STAY CONNECTED! 

Buy tickets to "VOCALIZE!" on https://bcdpvocalize.bpt.me starting this week

Share our Facebook Page and "like" our cause! This page will keep you updating with our events,show sneak peak videos, and post pictures during our whole process! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Boston-Community...

Follow our Instagram to see more updates on our Summer Season! @BCDPArtistry 

Chat about us on social media with our hashtag #FollowTheArtistry

Come to our workshop events:

BCDP Jazz Funk Class: Every Tuesday 8-915pm at Mass Motion Dance in Boston, MA! 

BCDP Heels Series starting Tuesday July 24th 915-1030pm at Mass Motion Dance in Boston, MA!

BCDP Contemporary Class: Every Thursday 6-730pm at Green Street Studios in Cambridge, MA! 

IMPROVIZE Workshop: 2 Hour improv Jam Sunday July 22nd 12-2pm at The Dance Complex Cambridge, MA! Sign up by emailing BCDPArtistry@gmail.com 

CONTEMPORIZE! 2 Day Intensive! Sign up by emailing BCDPArtistry@gmail.com or register online https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeSAudx4VOhVFnYMfnkMwT7AOOkH4WjN1DB75Q_JTDlicbgAg/viewform

 

VOCALIZE! is very dear to us and we hope to be able to produce this show with your help and support! 

Happy Dancing!

BCDP Heels Series starting Tuesday July 24th 915-1030pm at Mass Motion Dance in Boston, MA!
BCDP Contemporary Class: Every Thursday 6-730pm at Green Street Studios in Cambridge, MA! 
IMPROVIZE Workshop: 2 Hour improv Jam Sunday July 22nd 12-2pm at The Dance Complex Cambridge, MA! Sign up by emailing BCDPArtistry@gmail.com 
CONTEMPORIZE! 2 Day Intensive! Sign up by emailing BCDPArtistry@gmail.com or register online https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeSAudx4VOhVFnYMfnkMwT7AOOkH4WjN1DB75Q_JTDlicbgAg/viewform

Happy Dancing!

story:
Dictating to the Estate

 

Dictating to the Estate is a verbatim documentary play about events leading up to the Grenfell Tower fire.

Its title derives from a remark made by Rock Feilding-Mellen, former Deputy Leader of Kensington and Chelsea Council, that the village does not dictate to the estate.

Using contemporary blog posts, emails and council records, it tells the story of the renovation of the tower and residents’ attempts to hold the council and contractors to account. At the same time, it places these events in a wider context of austerity, estate regeneration and deregulation.

The production will run for two weeks in November 2021 at the Maxilla Social Club, a popular local venue five minutes’ walk from Grenfell Tower. A digital version of the production will be filmed onsite and released in early 2022.

The production team will also collaborate with a local youth charity to help them stage a performance that will open the play.  

 

Why we are making Dictating to the Estate

The Grenfell Tower fire, in which seventy-two people died, was the worst residential fire in Britain since the end of the Second World War. It happened in the wealthiest borough of the one of the wealthiest cities in the world, in a building managed by a council that held hundreds of millions of pounds in reserves. The plays aims to present, in dramatic form, an account of how such an event could occur.

The aims of this production are to:

  • Broaden understanding among audiences beyond North Kensington and housing activists of how the fire came to happen
  • Provide people with information that may help them scrutinise and challenge the actions of their own local authority
  • Place these events in the context of deregulation, austerity and estate regeneration, showing how key local government decisions are determined by national policy
  • Raise awareness of the campaign to have similar cladding removed from tall buildings around the UK
  • Help maintain pressure on the authorities to ensure that those responsible will be held to account

 

Why we need you

We have managed to raise a good proportion of the budget so far, but we still need another £13,697.

Since the pandemic, funding available from grant bodies has become a lot scarcer. We had always planned a fundraising campaign, but in the current circumstances it has become more vital than ever.

The funds raised will go towards paying for the cast and crew, the venue hire and the play’s equipment, set and props. It will also help fund our partnership with the local youth charity by paying for the young people’s tutors and expenses.

 

Who we are

Nathaniel McBride is a writer and translator who lives in Kensington and has been involved in a number of local campaigns around housing.

Allegra Nespoli is a creative producer who makes works about social justice and human rights. She has produced work that has been shown at the Royal Court theatre, Hackney Showroom, Birmingham Rep and Roundhouse.

 

Risks & Challenges

The pandemic has affected our original schedule and budget. The uncertainty of the post-lockdown climate has led us to believe the best way forward is to mount a free digital production alongside a socially distanced theatre production.

This means that whatever happens, the play will still go ahead safely and responsibly and will reach a wider range of audiences. A digital performance will also bring the following benefits:

  • It will remove any financial barriers to audiences attending the theatre, since it will be free
  • It will be accessible to D/deaf audiences as it will have closed captioning
  • People will be able to watch it from anywhere, and on all types of digital device across the country

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that we're in the middle of a pandemic and times are particularly tough right now. If you can't help us financially, you can still support us by shouting about this campaign, sharing our posts, and spreading the word.

Place these events in the context of deregulation, austerity and estate regeneration, showing how key local government decisions are determined by national policy
Raise awareness of the campaign to have similar cladding removed from tall buildings around the UK
Help maintain pressure on the authorities to ensure that those responsible will be held to account

 
Why we need you
We have managed to raise a good proportion of the budget so far, but we still need another £13,697.
Since the pandemic, funding available from grant bodies has become a lot scarcer. We had always planned a fundraising campaign, but in the current circumstances it has become more vital than ever.
The funds raised will go towards paying for the cast and crew, the venue hire and the play’s equipment, set and props. It will also help fund our partnership with the local youth charity by paying for the young people’s tutors and expenses.
 
Who we are
Nathaniel McBride is a writer and translator who lives in Kensington and has been involved in a number of local campaigns around housing.
Allegra Nespoli is a creative producer who makes works about social justice and human rights. She has produced work that has been shown at the Royal Court theatre, Hackney Showroom, Birmingham Rep and Roundhouse.

 
Risks & Challenges
The pandemic has affected our original schedule and budget. The uncertainty of the post-lockdown climate has led us to believe the best way forward is to mount a free digital production alongside a socially distanced theatre production.
This means that whatever happens, the play will still go ahead safely and responsibly and will reach a wider range of audiences. A digital performance will also bring the following benefits:

It will remove any financial barriers to audiences attending the theatre, since it will be free
It will be accessible to D/deaf audiences as it will have closed captioning
People will be able to watch it from anywhere, and on all types of digital device across the country


 
Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that we're in the middle of a pandemic and times are particularly tough right now. If you can't help us financially, you can still support us by shouting about this campaign, sharing our posts, and spreading the word.

story:
We are 'Rage, but Hope' 

  • 'Rage, but Hope' is a brand new play by award-winning writer Stephanie Martin, addressing the current climate crisis with humour, hope and lots of heart. 
  • We're so excited to have been invited to join the Edinburgh Fringe as part of Extinction Rebellion's residency at Summerhall, an iconic festival venue, to help raise awareness of the crucial fight for climate justice.
  • However...

 

We need your support!

  • We're raising money to help our ensemble of 10 get themselves to Edinburgh and bring our show to life.
  • We need to pay for travel and accommodation for the team, plus some basic show costs including costume, props and coffee. (Lots of coffee.) 
  • We've set a target of £3000:
    • £1000 covers our team's return travel from Edinburgh, by train (no flights!). 
    • £2000 covers our accommodation, notoriously pricey during the Festival.

 

None of our team are receiving a fee for their work on this project, and any funds raised beyond our target will be donated directly to Extinction Rebellion to further their vital work.

 

Why are we doing this?

  • Scientists from across the world are clear on one thing: urgent and immediate change is needed to prevent global climate disaster. Time is running out, and fast. The headlines are terrifying, and we must act now.
  • 'Rage, but Hope' is our contribution towards raising awareness of the climate crisis, to share key information and to activate change and action.
  • Our play is non-judgemental and tells stories of the human reaction to the movement: the fears, the anxieties, the struggle and, most importantly, the hope that we can make change, together.

 

Why us?

Here's some press coverage for our previous work: 

  • Lyn Gardner for Stagedoor: "It offers a real and rare pleasure in seeing a lesbian relationship put centre stage with a matter of fact ease. Sophisticated, slicker and shinier is Stephanie Martin’s terrifically enjoyable Juniper and Jules, a rom-com with a sting in its tail. This is sit-forward, lean-in theatre. It’s provocative with a small ‘p’."
  • Cindy Marcolina for Broadway World: "It's authenticity that sets Juniper and Jules apart, opening the doors to a subject that's rarely portrayed on stage analysing commitment, love, and desire with raw and keen writing.”
  • Alice Saville for Exeunt Magazine: "This is carefully observed, witty stuff, and it is so completely ‘relatable’ that I end up wondering if lines I hear are somehow cosmically plagiarised from conversations I’ve had or overheard."
  • The Times: “An irrepressible, swaggering spirit that sweeps you along with it and leaves you glowing.”

 

Why you?

  • The last-minute nature of this production means traditional long-term funding options are not available to us and - as the performances are part of a larger, free event - there won't be any box office income to cover our costs.
  • Any help you can offer us will be so gratefully received. Spreading the message of our show and the Extinction Rebellion movement at large will make a huge difference in the fight to save our planet for future generations.

 

Thank you!

Your support means the world to us, and to the Earth. No contribution is too small, and will help us to make our show a reality and elicit real change.

Love and rage, from Team 'Rage, but Hope'.

 

P.S. If you'd like to know more about the groups we're working with, click the following:

  • Extinction Rebellion's Summerhall residency.
  • Extinction Rebellion itself.
  • Extinction Rebellion's Spring Uprising.
  • Edinburgh Festival Fringe.
  • Summerhall, Festival Venue 26.

story:
The Petworth Dance Project is currently a non-funded outdoor festival, in the heart of Petworth NorthWest DC.

The newly formed Petworth Dance Project launches its first Summer series in Washington, DC, with performances on the 2nd Saturday during the months of May through September. The outdoor dance series is free to the public and features an eclectic set of performances on the lawn of the Petworth Recreation Center located at the corner of 8th and Taylor Street NW. The Petworth Dance Project Summer series features eleven DC area dance companies with styles ranging from Modern, West African, Ballet Folklorico, Contemporary, and more. The Project's goal is to bring the art and joy of Dance to our neighborhood by introducing the community to a wide range of artists, while creating a new space for thriving DC dance companies to perform.

All proceeds raised through the Indiegogo campaign will help towards compensation of artists, having sufficient sound, marketing, and conducting master classes with performing companies, in an effort to provide you, our audience, the best experience possible for this FREE outdoor dance series.

story:
LE STORY

Le Kleitoris Ballet is the fruit of a joyous odyssey that began at Ecole Philippe Gaulier International Theatre and Clown School in France. Two years ago, a Brazilian actress, an American actress, and an Italian actress walked into a bar… and set off on a crazy journey.

Originally inspired by Sartre’s adaptation of Euripides’ Trojan Women, we began to explore and debate feminine issues and gender inequalities – harassment, abuse, beauty standards, pay gap, genital mutilation… Trojan Women screamed, “injustice”, “invasion”, “violence”, “control”, “appropriation”, “rape”, “slavery”: women, ostensibly victims of their own bodies, born in a world where penis is law. We asked, “What if…?”

The evocation of many Greek plays and myths- Trojan Women, Lysistrata, The Bacchea, Pandora’s Box- and our reactions to contemporary cultural depravity came together and captivated us. We set out to create a show that encompassed our questions and assumptions. To cultivate an utterance of hope in response to all the “pussy grabbing” Trumps, Weinsteins, Temers, Berlusconis, those who abuse the power they possess. We examined different forms of expression, looking at avenues of creative inspiration to confront these injustices and timeless human degradation. What if WE react differently? How?

At Ecole Philippe Gaulier, with Greek tragedy, vaudeville, and red nose clowning behind us, in the throes of the Buffon workshop our ‘What If” found its voice. The Buffons- societies outcasts- experience deep suffering and pain in the depths of human misery. They find freedom through comedy, parody, and truth. They laugh! Their audience laughs too. Serendipitously, in the midst of this epiphany, we came upon the ancient Greek word for Clitoris, “Kleis”: “THE KEY”! Through comedy, pleasure, laughter, and joy, costumed as the Clitoris, dancing, our “form” was unlocked.

As Cassandra displayed the brutal strength to not submit, but to laugh and dance in the face of horror – movement, humor, and pleasure, sans guilt, shame, or fear, became our “kleis” to insubordination. As modern day Buffon, we claim the lasting pleasure of seriously not being serious. We join the swelling current of rising voices. A cri du coeur and a cackle in the face of the grotesque. This is a unique moment of resistance. A work in progress. The Kleitoris Ballet is a groan of pleasure and a giggle of freedom.

LE TEAM

Julia Henning grew up in her parents’ music school in Brazil and studied singing during her adolescence. She studied theatre and received a Degree in Pedagogical Studies at the University of São Paulo. She went on to co-found the Experimental Laboratory of Art Education and Culture with the Faculty of Education at the University of São Paulo, and began to teach theater in 2006. Julia has participated in several creations of the Titere Azul Cie under the direction of Rafael Rios. She has taken part in many workshops with Julia Varley from Odin Teatret, Yoshi Oida, and Tapa Sudana. She went on to obtain a Master 2 in Performing Arts at Paris 8 University, focused on the theatre of Peter Brook. Her professional theatrical training continued under the direction of Jean-Paul Denizon. In 2011 she created the company Cie des Sens and produced many productions in France, in collaboration with Jean-Paul Denizon and Rafael Rios. Julia won the 3rd prize at the 2011 OISTAT Theater Architecture Competition in Prague. In 2017, after two years of training with Philippe Gaulier, she began to participate in the creation and work of the Tête de Babel Collectif.

Bianca Maria Lay is a recent graduate of École Philippe Gaulier, which was a culmination of her special interest in comedy and clown.  She had previously studied with Merche Ochoa (Estudis Berty Tovías), Nicolas Cohen (Escuela Internacional de Teatro) and Eric de Bont’s International Clown School. She has collaborated with the Italian comic Stefano Manca and is a member of Barbigialli, a theatre company based in Sardinia. Bianca is an accomplished dancer who has won multiple Italian national competitions in Latin American dance. She has performed with the Sardinian dance companies Jana, Teatro Danza Leonarda, and Balletto Del Mediterraneo. Her work as a choreographer includes multiple solo and group performances that tour throughout Sardinia. She recently had a starring role in the Italian feature film Bianco di Babbudoiu. She is a principal in La Tête de Babel Collectif's creation and production of Le Kleitoris Ballet.

Dain Alexandra Rubin is an actress. She was born in the mountains of Aspen, Colorado. From age 11 to 18 she studied Drama at The Denver School of the Performing Arts. In 2005 she received a Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree in Acting from Emerson College in Boston Massachusetts.  After a year's solo voyage throughout Europe, Dain settled into New York City to pursue her theatrical dreams. In 2008 she began to study with master teacher Wynn Handman. While working in many staged productions, readings, short films, and commercials, Dain went on to complete a yoga teacher training in 2009. Her passion for physical comedy led to her participation in workshops with clown teachers Christopher Bayes and Kendall Cornell. This work inspired her journey across the Atlantic to France and to the prestigious École Philippe Gaulier. There she completed the two year program in 2017. After falling in love with a French man she decided to make France her home! Dain is now creating theatre in English for primary schools in the french national education system. She is currently a yoga/movement/theatre arts teacher at Ecole Mines ParisTech and Ecole Philippe Gaulier. Dain is a principal in the creation and work of Tête de Babel Collectif with her collegues.

Collaborating Amazing Team:

Susana Alcantud - Director

Susanna Amato - Actor

Andrea Coghene - Actor

John-Luke Roberts - Consulting Writer

Aldo Milia - Actor

Clément Perriollat - Musician

Alessandro Scaramella - Actor

Samantha Tiger West - Musician

Emanuela Solinas - Videographer

and more...

but...

We need YOU!!!

YOU can be a part of this movement too! Give us a tickle!

Your generosity will enable us to meet our production costs. The largest percent of which will fund the professional team we have built; John-Luke Roberts who will coalesce the writers room. Susana Alcantud who will direct this expression of delight. The amazing actors who will twerk right into your heart. Emanuela Solinas, whose visual wit, will weave multi-media technique into our physical living fun.  Samantha Tiger West and Clément Perriollat who will score and arrange this musical adventure.

Word, Direction, Actors, Video, Set, Music.... Audience!

What Can You Do?

Donate. Please. Thank you.

And/or.. Tell your friends!! The more people that know about LE KLEITORIS BALLET, the better. 

S P R E A D the word!

Email - email our indiegogo link!

Facebook - post our indiegogo link to your page and like our page!

story:
PLACAS

San Francisco International Arts Festival (SFIAF), Central American Resource Center (CARECEN) and the Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts (MCCLA) present playwright Paul S. Flores’ premiere of PLACAS, directed by Michael John Garcés of Cornerstone Theater and starring Ricardo Salinas of Culture Clash. PLACAS will premiere at the Lorraine Hansberry Theater in San Francisco’s Union Square, September 6 – 16, 2012.

PLACAS has also been co-commissioned through the National Performance Network by MACLA in San Jose, Su Teatro in Denver, CO, The GALA Theatre Center in Washington, DC and Pregones Theatre Center in New York City and is scheduled to go on a national tour in September of 2013.

PLACAS (barrio slang for graffiti tags, a nickname or body tattoos) is a stage drama that focuses on the human and local community ramifications of geo-political events. Set in today’s San Francisco it looks at the impacts that U.S. foreign policy during the Civil War in El Salvador in the 1980’s still has on migrant and refugee communities in the United States and throughout the Americas. In particular it addresses the issues of Central American street gangs that are a bi-product of the war and breaking the cycles of violence. PLACAS focuses on intergenerational relationships between young men and their fathers and uses the metaphor of tattoo removal as a way of moving forward and as a path to a possible solution.

PLACAS stars Ric Salinas as Salvadoran immigrant Fausto Carbajal, a now middle-aged ex-gang member recently released after nine years in prison. As a requirement of his parole Fausto must remove the tattoos that mark him as a member of his gang. Wearied by what has been a lifetime of violence, he accepts the terms. He is determined to reunite his family, traumatized by three decades of war, forced migrations and street crime. He returns to San Francisco to live with his mother, a war refugee, and hopes to re-unite with his ex-partner, Claudia and their now teenaged son, Edgar. But Edgar, who has not seen his father for most of his life, resents Fausto and displays disturbing character traits that remind Fausto of himself in his youth. It is clear that the reunion will be difficult.

What We Need

We’ve raised the money to develop the script, we’ve raised the money to pay the artists and we’ve raised the money to pay the rent on the Lorraine Hansberry Theater. Now, we are in the last three months before we open the show, we need to raise additional funds to market the show and fully realize its production and visual elements. Lorraine Hansberry has a big stage and we have some exciting ideas in regards to a set design. But it is a stretch for our current budget to realize these ideas. Plus, as we described above, after the show has premiered in San Francisco, over the course of the next 18 months it will tour to at least five cities across the country and hopefully more. Therefore, we need a set that is both striking and well designed so that it is easy to take on the road. Over the long term, it is a good investment, but creating this set (and then storing it) is initially more expensive than just building something that will get thrown away at the end of the San Francisco run.

Marketing Support

We have over 4,000 tickets to sell at the Lorraine Hansberry Theater and a portion of a surplus from the production will go to CARECEN's Second Chance Tattoo Removal Program. Removing a gang members tattoos is seen as an important step on the path to leaving the gang. Any help you can give towards marketing support will increase the numbers of tickets we can sell towards achieving this goal.

If you can't donate funds

We are looking for skilled carpenters and electricians who are interested in donating their time. Or if you have a scenic or prop shop and can donate space and/or building materials, these things will be invaluable to us.

If your skill set or inventory does not include the above, there are plenty other ways to volunteer or get involved with the production. Just get in touch with us either by calling our office or dropping us an e-mail.
