Any help you can give towards marketing support will increase the numbers of tickets we can sell towards achieving this goal. 

If you can't donate funds
We are looking for skilled carpenters and electricians who are interested in donating their time. Or if you have a scenic or prop shop and can donate space and/or building materials, these things will be invaluable to us.
If your skill set or inventory does not include the above, there are plenty other ways to volunteer or get involved with the production. Just get in touch with us either by calling our office or dropping us an e-mail.

story:
A note from Ellen:

Thank you for taking the time to read about my experiences, and my hopes for attending SDL. What I desire to take away from my time there is a new perspective on what kind of dancer I am and what kind of dancer I could be; I truly believe the instructors can help me get there. With the 5-week program I have the chance to participate in the Apprentice program with an acclaimed choreographer and dancer who will no doubt bring out a better dancer in all the students.  Every penny counts, and it would really be a blessing to be able to experience this!


Dear Friends,

Welcome!  from the Peterson family of beautiful Whidbey Island, WA:  Brian and Molly, Hannah, our college student on the right, and youngest daughter Ellen, standing next to Dad.  Our sixteen-year-old Ellen has been dancing since age 4, twelve of those years at The Ballet Slipper Conservatory under the direction of Diane Geragotelis, an amazing ballet teacher and choreographer. Here are two photos of her as Alice, in Alice in Wonderland, just after she had turned 12 years old:

          

And some from her last year at The Ballet Slipper Conservatory:

    

Nutcracker, 2013

Ellen rose to the highest class by age 11, and enjoyed the opportunity to perform many lead roles, choreograph to various music styles, and even teach all four levels of ballet class for a day while Miss Diane was on vacation!

Recently, Ellen and I (Molly) made a temporary move in order for her to join the Jubilee Dance Co. of Dancing For Joy (DFJ from now on), a dance company she
fell in love with after meeting several members at a summer dance intensive.  Read a great article about the directors of DFJ here.  Imagine how thrilled we all were
as we watched her dance the part of Mary in the Christmas Nativity show,
 'We Danced Our Best For Him' performed at the beautiful Mount Baker Theater in Bellingham, WA this December!

 


  




(Click on 'gallery' at the top for more fun photos - dance through the years!)


Along with taking ballet, jazz, modern, hip hop, contemporary and lyrical dance at DFJ, Ellen has participated in many community events and enjoyed being a teacher's assistant.  One of her favorite experiences was choreographing a modern piece for five dancers for DFJ's  Thirst No More March benefit to raise money for Evangeline International's Sweet Water Wells project.  The dancers succeeded in securing funds for a 5th well donated by DFJ as well as funds toward a 6th! Each year, the students are given an update on the building progress of the wells they have worked so hard for - the fruit (or shall we say, drink?) of their labors!

Check out this cool video created by Anthony Fiorillo of Ellen and her friend, Ian (who also danced as Joseph in the Nativity) at a women's day retreat at Hillcrest Chapel.  They are performing a piece they danced for the March benefit, (set to different music in the video):


 This spring, a group of the Dancing For Joy students carpooled to Seattle in order to audition for SDL, the summer dance lab held at Whitman College where Ellen first met her DFJ friends.

It was such an honor for her to be remembered by the directors of the program, Lydia Tetzlaff and John Passafiume.  On completion of the audition, Ellen received a $450 scholarship, and was highly recommended to apply for the apprenticeship program led by guest Repetiteur Brett Perry if she chose to attend for the full five weeks.  Due to the high cost of the program, Ellen had only signed up for three weeks, which was a financial stretch to begin with!  Here is a portion of her acceptance letter:

Dear Ellen,
It was good to see you again. Thank you for auditioning for Summer Dance Lab's 2015 program. We greatly enjoyed viewing your work in class and are very happy to inform you that you have been accepted to this Summer's SDL intensive!

Because of your performance in class, we strongly encourage you to attend the full five weeks of the program. We see that you did not mark this as a preference on your application, but if you were open to reconsidering the amount of time that you would attend, we feel that at your current stage of training the intensity and immersion of the full five weeks would benefit you immensely. In addition, we'd also like to offer you some financial assistance in the form of one of our tuition merit scholarships in the amount of $450.00. This scholarship is offered based on attendance for the full five week session.

Additionally, all of our five week students are eligible to audition for our Apprentice Program.  We think that you would be a very strong candidate. The dancers chosen will have the opportunity to perform in a new work to be created on our students by guest Repetiteur Brett Perry in an exciting work by world renown choreographer Trey McIntyre. This work will share the program on the annual Walla Walla Dance Festival to be held in Cordiner Hall on July 31st. Whether our five week students are chosen for the apprentice program or not, our small classes with highly individualized attention and broad spectrum of dance faculty, encompassing the very best of the current dance world, ensures that our dancers leave the program with greater strength, physical awareness, and artistry to take with them on their individual path in dance.

Again, congratulations on your acceptance to SDL! We are proud of your good showing at our audition, and we look forward to dancing with you this summer!   

Sincerely,

John Passafiume & Lydia Tetzlaff, Directors, Summer Dance Lab

Is it any wonder she wants to attend for the full five weeks now??


Introducing: Our Campaign!

The total cost of five weeks at Summer Dance Lab is:
Five-Week Program: June 28 - August 1
Tuition $2,039
Room and Board $2,655
Admin. Fee $45
Pointe shoes, character shoes, character skirt $283
Total: $5,022

Thankfully, we have a few subtractions:
SDL scholarship  - $450
Personal Donations (friends/family-including Ellen's Dad!)  - $1,272

Total Adjusted Balance: $3300


With the cost of nonstop year-round dancing, renting our place in Bellingham, an older daughter in college, substantial medical bills each year, a one-income household and everyday living, paying for the full five week program just isn't feasible.  We looked into several local scholarships, but all required the recipient to be a student of the public school system, and Ellen is a home-schooled student.  So we look to you, our community, to help us:  it takes a village to send a dancer to a summer intensive! Every little bit helps.  Know that your contribution will go towards SDL's dance intensive.  If our goal isn't reached, we'll use any funds received toward the remaining balance (most likely of the 3-week program) and kiss Dad a million times for being such an understanding Artist's father.  If there happens to be any extra funding, it will all go directly into our Dancing ForJoy account for future dance expenses.


For every $100-299 contribution, you will receive this lovely mini - poster
 featuring Ellen and her fellow Jubilee Dance Co. member (and boyfriend), Elijah Ryan to thank you for supporting the art of dance!

Actual size:  11.25" x 17.3"



You can be a vital part of making Ellen's dream a reality!  Imagine knowing that with your help, Ellen has had the training and expertise it takes to become a professional-level dancer and solid dance teacher and choreographer!   And she will bring this training home with her to help her studio bless the community of Whatcom County and beyond.   We would love for you to pass this on to anyone you know interested in supporting young dancers!

We plan to keep you all updated on Ellen's experiences on this site or via email or facebook.

Thank you from the bottom of our hearts and the tips of our toes!!

-Molly (Mom) Peterson


P.S. Other ways you can help:

We understand not everyone is able to help monetarily... but you can still make a contribution towards Ellen's dance career! 

  • You can share our site using the Indiegogo tools at the top of the campaign. Indiegogo tracks how many "shares" each site receives from using these tools, and that increases Ellen's chances for her campaign to be viewed at the top of the search engine!
  • Crowdfunding works when we get a CROWD together, so even if you can't contribute money, if you can get 5 people who can then you are helping in a big way!
  • Please feel free to leave comments and encouragement on the comment page, and we hope to see you at her next performance! xoxoxoxoxo


P.P.S.
For a taste of the SDL apprenticeship program from the viewpoint of former students, here are two quotes from the SDL 2014 newsletter, viewable online:
(Ellen remembers the author of the second quote from her time at SDL in 2012!)

        "The apprentice program was the experience of a lifetime. Getting a taste of working with professional choreographers and dancers really opened my eyes to how certain aspects of the dance world are. Being choreographed on was an incredible honor, but what I loved the most was that KT and Yayoi included us in the process of creating the piece. I know not all companies give you that kind of freedom, but it was incredible to experience the collaboration and sense of camaraderie it gave."  - Gabby Connors, SDL Apprentice Student 2014 

    

"I have had the privilege of working as an apprentice for KT and Yayoi for two summers now. It has been an incredible experience both times. The two women really treat all the apprentices like professionals. When I am in rehearsal, I am expected to not only be a dancer, but also a choreographer.  In the end, the piece tends to feel more like a work of art than simply just a dance. Both years I have been so proud to be able to perform alongside the other apprentices, who feel like they have become a part of my family. We all worked extremely hard, and it truly paid off when we performed in the beautiful Cordiner hall in front of the audience of the Walla Walla Dance Festival.  Being in the apprenticeship gave me a small taste of what being a professional dancer can be like, and now I'm hooked. Working with fellow apprentices, as well as so many amazing professionals has helped me to know that I am meant to be a dancer. I cannot express how grateful I am for this opportunity."  -Miranda Lyman, SDL Apprentice Student 2013, 2014

story:
The Yellow Wallpaper

Hi! My name is Sebastian Pray and I am currently a senior Theatre and Performance major at Purchase College. For my senior thesis, I am adapting and devising an experimental theatre piece based on Charlotte Perkins Gilman's short story The Yellow Wallpaper. The process has been absolutely thrilling and thought provoking. I am working in collaboration with a talented ensemble, a playwright, and designers in the Theatre Design/Technology program. There's just one thing missing--funding. Creating new and exciting theatre can be difficult, but it's important to me to tell this story with the integrity that it deserves.

"It was not intended to drive people crazy, but to save people from being driven crazy, and it worked." - Gilman, on The Yellow Wallpaper

The Yellow Wallpaper is set in the Victorian Era and tells the story of a young woman that is deemed hysteric by her doctor husband. In an attempt to "heal" her, he prescribes her the rest cure, brings her to a home in the country, and locks her in a room with barred windows and an omnipresent yellow wallpaper. The narrator becomes fascinated with the wallpaper, and begins to see women creeping about within it. In her text, Gilman examines the gender roles and the expectations of women in the Victorian Era. She exposes the social forces that were confining women in an attempt to make sense of her own circumstance.

In the quote above, Gilman explains as to why she wrote the story. Part auto-biography, Gilman had to make sense why she was regarded as ill when in face her voice was being ignored. My goal is the same as Gilman's. I hope to retell the story in a theatrical setting in order to help audience members make sense of what social forces are oppressing them. 

Where is the Money Going?

All funding will go directly to defray production costs. Producing theatre is exciting, but everything comes at a price. 
  • $500 for scenic design
  • $300 for costumes
  • $50 for props
  • $50 for advertising
  • $250 for unexpected costs 

Cast and Creative Team

Alia Tejeda as The Narrator
Bridget Flynn as Jennie/Creeping Woman
Matthew DeCostanza and John
Parade Stone as Mary/Creeping Woman
Kanae Miyahara as Creeping Woman/Ensemble Leader

Director: Sebastian Pray*
Written by The Ensemble
Production Stage Manager: Jessica Yost
Dramaturg: Allison Hart
Scenic Design: Lacey Ballard
Lighting Design: Ash Zeitler
Costume Design: Lindsey Raquette 
Assistant Stage Manager: Tara Goodman
Music Composition: Sequoia Sellinger 
Choreography by The Ensemble

* Denotes senior thesis

story:
Why Studio Azul? 

Studio Azul is more than a dance studio- It's a community that inspires people to reach their full potential. I'm Lily, owner, founder and artistic director of Studio Azul. Two years ago when I opened the doors to my little 800 SQF space on Lake City Way I was looking for a place for me and my 15 dancers to rehearse and grow. It was beyond my wildest dreams that what I was truly doing was making a space for our student base to quadruple, creating a home where people feel safe, understood and confident all while giving myself a platform to push the envelope of Latin Dance in Seattle and around the country. It is because of my belief in our community and our commitment to one another that we have outgrown our current studio and will be expanding to a new home opening December of 2019. 

What do we need to do this? 

In addition to small business loans for the major construction of our space we are looking for crowd funding to help with costs associated specifically with our studio and equipment needs. Funding raised in this campaign will go towards- 

  • Mirrors for approximately 80 feet of wall length 
  • Sound equipment including speakers and microphones 
  • Equipment for dance conditioning and yoga (new mats, yoga blocks, stretching bands, balls, pilates rings and weights) 
  • Furniture for our new lobby waiting area 

Every contribution is treasured- our goal is to create an incredible experience for every person who walks through our doors and these additions to our facility will be priceless. This list is in priority order- if we do not reach our campaign goal we will start at the top and use funds until we run out. 

With great space comes great responsibility- 

While we are stoked to be able to offer double the classes we currently do, expand our team programs, kids program and beginners program. While there is a need in our new neighborhood building classes from the ground up can be challenging. Having this funding will allow us more flexibility to stay consistent with our classes as they build. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes monetary commitment just isn't an option- and we totally understand! Other ways you can support us include- 

  • Following us on social media 
  • Sharing this campaign with people in your network who might be interested in contributing

Thank you for your support.

story:
Short Summary

From 2010 to 2015, Between the Seas established itself in New York as the only platform presenting and promoting the work of independent Mediterranean artists and encouraging cultural exchanges between Mediterranean and North American artists. After a 4 year break during which we expanded our activities around the world, we return to New York with a 4 day Mediterranean performing arts platform.

Between the Seas has always been and will remain a grassroots, independent platform ran by artists and for artists, taking risks in our programming and offering opportunities to emerging performers. We work voluntarily and we cover part of our expenses from ticket sales. Which is why YOUR support is vital in allowing us to exist and continue our work.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The way Between the Seas works is that we cover the production costs of organizing the platform in NYC, while artists take care of their flight and accommodation costs. The basic costs of production include: theater space rental, press and marketing, and technical support staff. The amount we are trying to raise through this campaign will go towards covering about half of these costs while the other half we seek to cover through ticket sales.

We hope that you'll get interested in our programming and you'll become a part of our community. Between the Seas makes every effort to offer quality, interesting and socially relevant programming in a highly professional setting, and create those conditions that will allow our community of artists, audiences and friends, to get together, meet, exchange ideas and experiences. As an independent organization, we cannot do this without your help!

 

The Impact

Our vision with Between the Seas is to contribute to the ecology of New York's performing arts with the exciting, diverse voices of Mediterranean artists; and to give those artists the opportunity, to experience this exciting city, and share their work with the world. In the 8 years we have been operating between New York and Greece, we have created a strong community of artists with whom we collaborate on a regular basis:  we have presented artists in NYC that have later been invited to Greece and vice versa; and we have introduced to NYC Mediterranean playwrights whose work has then been produced. Ultimately, what we care for is dialogue and communication - between artists and audiences. Seeing the increasing corporatization of culture, the increasing isolationism and fear of others, we really think it is important that we stay in the picture and defend our place in the world - as artists, cultural practitioners, and citizens operating at the grassroots level. By supporting us you become an integral part of this vision and you help sustain the cultural diversity that we urgently need.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

No amount is small in this effort - imagine that if 100 people give $10, that's already about half the money we seek to raise!

Yet if you can't donate, we totally understand. But if you still believe in us and want to get involved, you will greatly help us by helping us promote this fundraiser, by spreading the word about the festival so audiences come and see it, and of course by coming to see some of our shows this May!

We work voluntarily and we cover part of our expenses from ticket sales. Which is why YOUR support is vital in allowing us to exist and continue our work.

 
What We Need & What You Get
The way Between the Seas works is that we cover the production costs of organizing the platform in NYC, while artists take care of their flight and accommodation costs. The basic costs of production include: theater space rental, press and marketing, and technical support staff. The amount we are trying to raise through this campaign will go towards covering about half of these costs while the other half we seek to cover through ticket sales.
We hope that you'll get interested in our programming and you'll become a part of our community. Between the Seas makes every effort to offer quality, interesting and socially relevant programming in a highly professional setting, and create those conditions that will allow our community of artists, audiences and friends, to get together, meet, exchange ideas and experiences. As an independent organization, we cannot do this without your help!
 

The Impact
Our vision with Between the Seas is to contribute to the ecology of New York's performing arts with the exciting, diverse voices of Mediterranean artists; and to give those artists the opportunity, to experience this exciting city, and share their work with the world. In the 8 years we have been operating between New York and Greece, we have created a strong community of artists with whom we collaborate on a regular basis:  we have presented artists in NYC that have later been invited to Greece and vice versa; and we have introduced to NYC Mediterranean playwrights whose work has then been produced. Ultimately, what we care for is dialogue and communication - between artists and audiences. Seeing the increasing corporatization of culture, the increasing isolationism and fear of others, we really think it is important that we stay in the picture and defend our place in the world - as artists, cultural practitioners, and citizens operating at the grassroots level. By supporting us you become an integral part of this vision and you help sustain the cultural diversity that we urgently need.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
No amount is small in this effort - imagine that if 100 people give $10, that's already about half the money we seek to raise!
Yet if you can't donate, we totally understand. But if you still believe in us and want to get involved, you will greatly help us by helping us promote this fundraiser, by spreading the word about the festival so audiences come and see it, and of course by coming to see some of our shows this May!

story:
New Year, New Dances

This January over 300 choreographers across the country will take the NACHMO challenge and choreograph a new dance piece in one month. It will be our 11th season of giving dancers, choreographers, and movers of all kinds a choreographic kick in the pants!

At the end of the month, we produce a series of informal studio shows and two fully produced theater shows in NYC so that choreographers can share their new pieces with the public. In a nutshell, NACHMO is a creative challenge culminating in a festival of new dances. Our goal is to encourage and support the creation of new dance work by providing a deadline, a community of peers, and low-cost performance opportunities. The shows allow choreographers to see their work in performance - they are a learning opportunity, a way to strengthen ties among participants, and a celebration of the effort that went into the creation of the new dances.

This campaign will help us fund these shows by ensuring that we have the cash to pay for studio and theater rentals while keeping ticket prices and choreographer fees super low. Your contribution facilitates the creation of new dances, strengthens the NYC dance community, and gives the public opportunities to see new dances for as little as $10. Thank you!

What We Need And Where it Goes

To cover the cost of renting studios at the Mark Morris Dance Center and the Mark O'Donnell Theater at the Actors Fund Arts Center, while keeping studio tickets to $10 and theater tickets to $20, NACHMO NYC needs $1,200 at the start of the season.

100% of the funds from this campaign go to our performance rental fees.

Perks!

We're grateful for a gift of any amount, and we'd love to thank you with a postcard, a tote bag, a personalized dance, or any of the perks listed at right.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes there's no cash to spare, but there's always a way to help:

 - Send us some love on Facebook and Instagram

- Want to volunteer for NACHMO? email us at info@nachmo.org

- Or perhaps you've been so inspired by the video, photos, and enthusiastic quotes that you want to try your hand at making a dance. Do it!

story:
Zach Bivins and Ian Stevens of Amphora Media in Seattle have been selected to film Ling Hui's 2018 dance performance Riding Twilight.  

An example of Zach and Ian's work can be seen here:

https://www.washington.edu/news/2016/03/04/uw-v...

Our goal is to raise $500.  This covers the cost of filming and producing the video of this performance. 

If we reach our goal, we will have a video of the performance for ourselves, our kids and those who could not attend the performance.  This video will be available for viewing and downloading. (The video will be password protected for privacy but the password will be given to parents of the dancers.)

story:
This campaign is raising funds on behalf of Arts Council Of The Conejo Valley, a verified nonprofit. The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

Why YA4Ever?

We are YA4Ever and the new branch of the Young Artists Ensemble, run by alumni, for alumni and friends. We created our company to benefit the place from which we all came and loved, YAE.  Young Artists Ensemble began in 1981, and now does and annual Family Theater season as well as Teen Dramas and Teen Summer Musicals. YA4Ever will provide an outlet for alumni of the YAE to do the shows they want to do with the people with whom they want to perform them! After the success of our premiere production of Urinetown, and our following productions of The Rocky Horror Show, and our concert of Into the Woods we decided to continue fundraising for YA4Ever. This January we will be doing a production of Godspell, and would love your support! The performing arts is something we all hold near and dear to our hearts, and therefore we are using this production of Godspell and this online campaign to help us raise funds to do more shows in the future. 

The Breakdown

Our goal is $1000 and it will go towards future productions to help keep our company up and running, and specifically help us fund technical aspects of this January's production of Godspell. We are currently in pre-production for our January production of Godspell, and would love to see you all there (for more information go to yaeonine.com or https://www.facebook.com/yaeforever1)  Even if we don't reach our entire goal, the money we raise through this campaign will still benefit our current production and future shows, so please contribute! All funds for this campaign are run through through the non-profit Arts Council of the Conejo Valley (Tax I.D. 95-310-5047) and the funds will be used exclusively for the YA4Ever production of Godspell. Contributions are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, please join us for our production of Godspell on January 9-12! For ticket information, or more information about Young Artists Ensemble, please visit yaeonline.com and like us on Facebook, twitter and instagram! [@weareya4ever and https://www.facebook.com/yaeforever1]

THANK YOU IN ADVANCE FOR YOUR CONTRIBUTION  Please put correct contact information so that we can get you your perks with ease and velocity!

story:
Six on Shakespeare needs your help to bring fresh and innovative theater to life. Our newest production is A Comedy of Errors performed by ‘twin’ six person casts-one all male and one all female.

Help bring this unique and hilarious play to the stage! You’ve never seen Shakespeare quite like this! 24 characters, 6 actors each night, and countless laughs.

'A Comedy of Errors' stars Cecily Overman, Rob Harrison, Liz Hayden, Jeff Desautels, Torrey Cornwell, James Lawrence, Melissa Whitney, Chris Murphy, Michelle Seaton, Nate Cohen, MaryAnne Glazebrook and Ben Plont.

The show runs Thurs-Sun April 2-19 at the Backdoor Theater, 4319 SE Hawthorne Blvd. 

Story

Tired of ‘scholars’ telling you how Shakespeare should be presented? Well so are we! Six on Shakespeare has been lovingly thumbing our noses at the stuffy and boring approach to Shakespeare for years with past productions of the Comedies Hamlet, Romeo & Juliet and the cult classic, MacBeth (spit, turn!). Our horror spoof Hamlet the Vampire Slayer was also an underground hit. We use the recently discovered ‘Port Folio’ scripts which present a newer take on the old material.  

If you love Shakespeare, and can handle him being turned on his head, then this is the show for you! If you dread attending Shakespeare, then come see a performance that will change your perspective on his work. Our newest show is A Comedy of Errors and will feature twin Six person casts. One all male, and one all female! Characters from Comedy of Errors, Twelfth Night, and A Midsummer Night’s Dream all pop up in our version which brings the twin total count to 6. 

About us

My name is Bill Barry and I helped start Six on Shakespeare back in 1992, and have been self producing our plays since then. The company was originally created after a visit from the Royal Shakespeare Company who brought a very scholarly and dry approach to the work- so our idea was ‘what if that if there were no footnotes, or title page, would someone reading the play discover comedy or satire within what has been labeled as Tragedy?’ We thought it would be fun to try and mine that from the text. We use the actual text with some careful editing and a few modern references to create an all new version of the play. Our plays attempt to give the Bard back to the Groundlings-you know, bawdy and brash! As an independent theatre ‘company’ it is difficult to find funding to bring our works to the stage so we are asking for your help! It is extremely expensive for a company like ours to find the finances required to bring our plays to the stage, but we feel that what we offer is fun and fresh. By contributing to our production Portland audiences can enjoy a laugh filled evening of quality theater, in a show never seen before.

What We Need

We are looking and hoping to raise $4000 to produce the show. This amount would cover the rental of the theater space, provide a nominal stipend for the actors (12 total in two casts), buy costumes and props, and help pay the technical team (sound, lights, costumes, props). Our ultimate goal is to simply bring this play to the stage and in the long run break even. You donation will go a long way to bring this production to light. All money will go toward the show, there is no ‘profit’ to be made. Just fun theater. Although $4000 is the goal, every penny counts, so we're going with flexible funding. 

So what can you ‘get ‘ as a thank you for donating? Reserved Seats to the show! Autographed programs! Props from the actual production! Your name mentioned during the show! A super-secret special gift from the director - even a ‘guest’ appearance if the donation is right! 

The Impact

There are so many artists who struggle to get their works presented here in Portland, we being one of them. Whether it is lack of performance space or the price tag to rent it, or lack of funding to present the show in the best possible light or any number of other roadblocks, self-producing is not an easy task. Six on Shakespeare has been lucky enough to have produced several well received and funny shows (The Comedic Tragedy of Hamlet (featuring a ‘speak the speech’ audition session), The Comedic Tragedy of Romeo & Juliet (featuring a 6’ 4” male Juliet), the cult classic Comedic Tragedy of MacBeth (featuring a Scotch Tape design set that fell apart as the kingdom crumbled) and Hamlet the Vampire Slayer (a horror homage with Werewolves, Vampires and Sadomasochistic lesbian Rosencrantz and Guildenstern) over the past decades but haven’t been able to find space since 2002. Now we have! Now we need your help! If you ‘know’ Shakespeare the scripts are filled with winks and nods to other works for deeper chuckles. If you don’t know Shakespeare, the gags are fast and furious with enough slapstick moments to carry you through the show.  Help us fund this production and come have a fun filled evening!

Risks & Challenges

It is very difficult to write and qualify for a grant in our city. It is hard to find sponsors for one off productions like ours without a full ‘season’ to advertise. We rely on the kindness of others to produce shows we think (and have proven to present) are highly entertaining and enjoyable. This isn't Mickey Rooney doing a show in the barn, this is a fresh take on Shakespeare’s work that provides affordable entertainment without all the pretense. The opportunity arose to get this play onstage and we jumped at the chance. Your contribution is gratefully appreciated and desperately needed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way to support our project if you are unable to contribute is to come see the show.  Spread the word about the play! I am very excited and eager to get this show on its feet and make people laugh.

It is hard to find sponsors for one off productions like ours without a full ‘season’ to advertise. We rely on the kindness of others to produce shows we think (and have proven to present) are highly entertaining and enjoyable. This isn't Mickey Rooney doing a show in the barn, this is a fresh take on Shakespeare’s work that provides affordable entertainment without all the pretense. The opportunity arose to get this play onstage and we jumped at the chance. Your contribution is gratefully appreciated and desperately needed. Other Ways You Can HelpThe best way to support our project if you are unable to contribute is to come see the show.  Spread the word about the play! I am very excited and eager to get this show on its feet and make people laugh.

story:
Articulate Theatre Company is an award winning ensemble-based company that was created in early 2013 and is committed to challenging and connecting audiences & artists with clearly structured work that is intelligent, thought-provoking and visually striking. 

Theatre is an art but it’s also a business - and it can be a very tough business in New York City.  Tough or not we are determined to bring you, our audience, performances you will be talking about long after the show is done.  And with your assistance we can make this happen!

ATC is helmed by Cat Parker (Artistic Director), Brittney Venable (Managing Director), and Maeve Yore (Producing Director) but its heart and soul is our Company: the professional actors, designers, playwrights, producers, as well as people with experience in radio, television, and film, that round out this talented group. 

Articulate Theatre Company's First Season was far more successful than we could ever have hoped - thanks to you! 

Here is a look back at our season:

Our award winning first production Dragon


Paying Homage to a Puitzer Prize winning Wordsmith, Seamus Heaney



Our first Articulating the Arts, a benefit that finds inspiration from other art forms for new plays


 And we even found time to partner with The New York Shakespeare Exchange to create a Sonnet Video.

All of these came together extremely well. Now we're ready to move into year two and challenge ourselves even more! 

We are determined to not slow down but we need your help to keep us going in the right direction! This is us practicing our "Please, won't you donate today?!?!" faces. Now - Once more with feeling!

For our second season, we are reprising the very successful Articulating the Arts, creating a night of celebration in honor of Circle Rep Theatre and - if we are successful in our fundraising - producing Thornton Wilder's "Skin of Our Teeth" (yes, we love a challenge!). 


Now that we have regaled you with the adventures of the past year and the good we hope to accomplish in 2014/2015, this is where you come in! You are probably wondering how your marvelous and much appreciated donation would be utilized.  Please read below for how funds are used.

Funds raised will go towards:

  • Venues for our Future Productions - Locations for next year need to be decided upon now!
  • Rehearsal Space - NYC, home of the ever-rising rental market. Space costs!
  • Publicity and Marketing - Getting the Word Out!
  • Play Workshops - New plays and new concepts benefit from some growing room before they are placed in front of you to see.
  • Design Elements - Props, Lights, Sets, Sound & Costumes are integral parts of storytelling.
  • Grant Applications - Yes, It even costs money to ask for money!
  • Legal and Accounting Fees - Is there anything lawyers and accountants don't impact? Certainly not theatre!
  • The list seems endless but it's all dedicated to producing amazing theatre for you, and with your help, we can get to the end of the list and tell you a story!

As a donor, not only do you get a warm fuzzy feeling for helping put amazing theatre back on the stage, but you’re also eligible for a myriad of perks we’ve assembled for all of our donors. Plus our members will give you a standing ovation! We already have them practicing, getting the rhythm just right (a couple are still out of sync, we're working on it).

In this economic climate, we know budgets are tight (believe me, we know!) so if financial support is a challenge, we'd be delighted to receive your assistance in other ways: Share this campaign with your network of family and friends and spread the word by email, Facebook, Twitter and all the other social media playgrounds. Come usher at a show. Host a fundraising event. It all starts, and ends, with you!

So please help keep us in a theatre and out of your living room! Unless you make a $1000 donation then we have something special in mind (please see perks).

Articulate Theatre Company strives to honor its name by creating theatre that is articulate, and also articulates productions involving timeless issues. 

We thrive on being storytellers and look forward to using the donations received here to bring those stories to you!

story:
In the summer of 2014, the play Dollar Store Shampoo was co-produced by Tricklock Company and Egg Murders Productions, and performed in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The play was written by Aaron Hendren, directed by Drew Morrison, and was performed by Harrison Sim and Diana Delgado. Dollar Store Shampoo charmed audiences in its home town, but from its inception/conception the play was designed to be able to travel.

We have a short amount of time to submit Dollar Store Shampoo to the Canadian Fringe Festival. We are planning to submit to Toronto and Ottawa. Simply submitting to these cities costs nearly $1500. International submissions (that's us) are lottery based and not juried. That means our chances of getting accepted are just as good as any other international artists. If we are accepted, we will have several months to prepare for the tour and performances.

If we are not accepted, the funds will be returned to us. We will use your contributions to perform Dollar Store Shampoo in other cities in the US.

 The Canadian Fringe Festival attracts artists and audiences from all over the world. The masters, the amateurs, the avant-garde, and the experimental perform for an international audience. A success in this arena can make careers. Drew, Diana, and Harrison are young, hungry, and perhaps the up-and-comers, but they are ready to represent Albuquerque, the US, and they are itching to succeed. They are ready. 

We truly appreciate your support. Help us submit to the Fringe, and please help us spread the word to others.
story_txt:
In the summer of 2014, the play Dollar Store Shampoo was co-produced by Tricklock Company and Egg Murders Productions, and performed in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The play was written by Aaron Hendren, directed by Drew Morrison, and was performed by Harrison Sim and Diana Delgado. Dollar Store Shampoo charmed audiences in its home town, but from its inception/conception the play was designed to be able to travel.
We have a short amount of time to submit Dollar Store Shampoo to the Canadian Fringe Festival. We are planning to submit to Toronto and Ottawa. Simply submitting to these cities costs nearly $1500. International submissions (that's us) are lottery based and not juried. That means our chances of getting accepted are just as good as any other international artists. If we are accepted, we will have several months to prepare for the tour and performances.If we are not accepted, the funds will be returned to us. We will use your contributions to perform Dollar Store Shampoo in other cities in the US.  The Canadian Fringe Festival attracts artists and audiences from all over the world. The masters, the amateurs, the avant-garde, and the experimental perform for an international audience. A success in this arena can make careers. Drew, Diana, and Harrison are young, hungry, and perhaps the up-and-comers, but they are ready to represent Albuquerque, the US, and they are itching to succeed. They are ready. 
We truly appreciate your support. Help us submit to the Fringe, and please help us spread the word to others.

story:
Short Summary

The Spectrum Theatre Company creates professional productions that promote artistic excellence through thought provoking stories of the human condition as seen through the spectrum of the African American experience.

Our Illumination Celebration was an undeniable success as you can see from the video highlights supplied by RAW Entertainment Films.


The event was graced with not only some of Austin's finest performers by trade (including Julius Tennon, Eugene Lee, Pamela Hart, The Tim Curry Trio, Blue Gardenia, and Dynasty), but also by some of Austin's most respected members of the political and legal community, like State Representative Dawnna Dukes, Chief of Police Art Acevedo, Asst. City Manager Anthony Snipes, Asst. District Attorney Gary Cobb, and Brigid Shae, throwing their support behind Spectrum Theatre Company by taking the stage themselves.  Take a look at this hilarious scene featuring "The Beautiful Ms. Dee Dee" supplied by RAW Entertainment Films.


It was a lot of fun, and the community support was very warm and very generous.

It was a great beginning, and our work continues!

Spectrum Theatre Company’s  goal is to create professional productions that promote artistic excellence through thought provoking stories of the human condition as seen through the spectrum of the African American experience. To this end, one of the pieces that we're looking to present is "Once on this Island," a Caribbean-flavored musical by the Tony Award-winning songwriting team of Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty based upon the book "My Love, My Love" by Rosa Guy, set in the French Antilles in the Caribbean Sea. The show also includes elements of the Romeo and Juliet story, as well as the fairytale of "The Little Mermaid." The story concerns a peasant girl on a tropical island who uses the power of love to bring together people of different social classes.

Spectrum Theatre Company is committed to developing new works, conducting educational outreach, providing community enrichment, and ensuring that plays contained in the canon of Black Theatre do not go forgotten, but find life on its stage.

Spectrum Theatre Company was founded by veterans of the stage.  We recognize that quality theatre does not occur in a vacuum, as patrons of the arts, you know this, too.  It costs, and its creators deserve to be compensated for their contributions.

Our budgetary breakdown is as follows:

  • $4,670.00 is needed for performance royalties and rental of associated materials.
  • $10,000.00 is needed scenic construction materials and costumes.
  • $12,900.00 is needed to employ directors, designers, technicians, managers and crew.
  • $13,020.00 is needed to employ actors, dancers and musicians.
  • $3,000.00 is needed for media publicity and advertising.

The Impact

Your support of this campaign will do much more than fund a production, you will be involving yourself as a forceful agent in helping to propel Spectrum Theatre Company's more altruistic goals, which are:

  • Increasing public awareness of the significant contributions of African Americans in creating a diversified American theatrical tradition.    
  • Encouraging and facilitating a culturally diverse and all-inclusive America by using theatre to teach, criticize, comment and model.
  • Using theatre to create an American mythology that includes African Americans and other peoples of color in every thread of the fabric of our society.
  • Continuing to maintain and stabilize a black performing arts community.
While this is Spectrum Theatre Company's inaugural season, its members are seasoned award winning performing artists and directors whose credits range from regional, to international.  Check out Janis Marie Stinson, Felicia Dinwiddie and Jacqui Cross:

Critical Praise For STC Members

Awards received by STC members include, but are not limited to, the B. Iden Payne Award, the Austin Critics Table Award and the Ostrander Award.  Here's what some of the critics have said about some of our member's performances.

Reginald C. Brown (Artistic Director of Spectrum Theatre Company) seen here in Austin Shakespeare's "As You Like It":

                                                           

received these reviews for his performances in William Shakespeare's "Richard III and Sean Michael Rice's "'Rounds":

"Brown's is the most complete transformation of actor into character I've seen in Shakespearean theater.  He combines the majesty, the lofty distance, which Shakespeare's language requires of a prince and king such as Richard with immediacy, the sense of real presence as a person...he is villainy personified."  Also, "My favorite production this season, hands down, was Richard III...I will remember Reginald Brown as Richard III for the rest of my living days."

Steven Davison (The Home News)

“Welcome back, Reginald C. Brown.  Brown has been a presence on the New Jersey theater scene, having co-founded Ensemble Theatre of Newark.  Before that he acted at Crossroads Theatre and the George Street Playhouse…Let’s be glad he’s returned, for he’s riveting in “Rounds”, currently at 12 Miles West in Montclair...Brown is the outstanding one, though.  What a pleasure to see so natural an actor, trick-free, quietly confident that he understands the character and can play him for height and depth.  When he reminisces on his childhood, then on the vast amounts of work his hands have done, he does each with brave dignity.  But, he’ll return to the matter at hand and zero in on his quest not to be a victim one more time.  When Freeman tells him, “Violence isn’t the answer,” Brown makes the observation that, “It gets their attention” in a way that sounds level-headed.  “Pride, that’s it,” he states.  Well, Brown can be very proud of his performance.”                                                                       Peter Filichia (The Star Ledger)

The following reviews of Jacqui Cross' (STC Managing Director) award winning turns in "Mahalia" by Tom Stolz, and "Dreamgirls" with music by Henry Krieger and lyrics and book by Tom Eyen, are testaments to her amazing artistic contributions.


“So stirring is Jacqui Cross' readings of Jackson's songbook. There is no way an audience can refrain from clapping along to the infusion of energy and good religion encapsulated in those soulful, four-four time numbers.  The amazing Cross receives just as amazing backing from Janis Stinson and Billy Harden. Some of the best moments are when the three go at it a cappella, for intricate, soulful songs that seem to flow from characters too full of the Lord's music to keep quiet.”
Robi Polgar (The Austin Chronicle)

“Enough cannot be said about Jacqui Cross' forceful performance as the turbulent Effie. Cross' voice finds the bottom of your soul, toys with it awhile, then yanks it right out of your body. Yes, she is that good.”                     Adrienne Martini (The Austin Chronicle)

In awarding Janis M. Stinson (STC Associate Director) the "Best Voice of Authority" award, the Austin Chronicle declares:

“Some stage performers need time to develop that convincing sense of experience that grounds them in a character or a song. Not Janis Stinson. The instant this warm, funny actress/singer opens her mouth, whether it's to belt out "Blues in the Night," deliver the poetic musings of a grieving widow in The America Play, or take us "Way Over Yonder" via the music of Carole King, she convinces you that she Knows Whereof She Speaks, that she's Been There and Done That. For Stinson always draws her rich, ripe, husky voice from deep within, straight from her soul, and it gives her automatic authority. That voice, matched with an electric presence and priceless comic savvy, puts Stinson in the top rank of Austin stage artists.”

And, Judy R. Arnold-Hunter (STC Company Member), garnered the following review for her role in "Crowns" by Regina Taylor, adapted from the book by Michael Cunningham and Craig Marberry:

“Judy Arnold raises the roof (and very nearly old Lazarus himself) when she sings "Mary, Don't You Weep." Jacqui Cross makes "His Eye Is on the Sparrow" into a commanding anthem of both belief and liberation.  Crowns doesn't spend much time discussing civil rights or slavery, but when Cross belts out "I sing because I'm free," it seems to come from the heart of the African-American experience and an emancipation dearly purchased after generations in chains."                                                                                                                              Robert Faires (The Austin Chronicle)

This is just some of the remarkable talent assembled in Spectrum Theatre Company, and a sample of the accolades that they've earned.
Risks & Challenges

In every endeavor there is a certain amount of risks involved, no place is that more evident than it the arts, and while our combined experiences have prepared us for most of them, Spectrum Theatre Company has assembled a board of directors of like-minded artists (including Julius Tennon and Viola Davis) and professionals from the corporate sector, to aide us in our pursuits. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • You can get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
    • You can use the Indiegogo share tools!

    Thank you from Spectrum Theatre Company of Austin, Texas!

story:
The annual EuroStar Award for exceptional performance is given to one European leader and one European follower at ESDC, who have exemplified the spirit of the dance throughout the weekend. As well as a trophy and inauguration into the EuroStar Hall of Fame, the winners will also receive free passes to 63 swing dance events around the world, to encourage them to pursue their love of dancing. Marcos will basically need support for fly tickets, accommodation and food.

For the next year, Marcos Agote will become one of the most closely followed Lindy Hoppers in the world. 


THE REASON? He is the 2013 winner of the Eurostar Award – an annual prize given to two dancers who best embody the spirit of swing dancing. 

The Eurostar award comprises of 63 tickets to the most prestigious Lindy Hop events around the world - an incredible gift and something most Lindy Hop dancers could only ever dream of getting their hands on. 

A typical Lindy Hop event consists of training with international teachers, performance opportunities and plenty of chances to compete. 

             

                       


They often start on a Friday and last until breakfast time on Monday morning (Lindy Hoppers dance ALL night long).

                 

                       

Lindy Hop events are widely documented on YouTube, Facebook, and Flikr. It is not unusual for performances to attract thousands of views once they’re uploaded onto YouTube. 

Over the next year, Marcos will be photographed and filmed performing, training and competing thousands of times. He is fast becoming ‘the one to watch’.

And deservedly so: 

Only a week after winning the Eurostar award in London, Marcos has already competed in and won first place in Showcase Division at Lindyshock (Budapest) - an event renowned for attracting the most talented Lindy Hoppers in the world:


All this after only dancing for 1.5 years. 

      

Finding the money to fund the flights for this once in a life-time Lindy Hop adventure is now the only thing holding Marcos back from taking full advantage of this incredible opportunity - one which will solidify his deserved position amongst the swing dancing elite. 

                 

Without funding, Marcos will have to forgo the vast majority of the events donated by the Eurostar Award - missing out on the opportunity to learn from the best dancers in the world and also perform, compete and develop his own teaching skills. 

Marcos is now working against the clock, looking for funding and sponsorship that will allow him to pursue his passion and take full advantage of this truly amazing prize.

          

Marcos Agote

www.marcosagote.com

story:
Diverzity Fuzion is a dance crew brought together from a wide range of ethnic backgrounds and family life. The name was decided on how Diverse everyone is with their own style and dance technique and fusion was having everyone join forces creating one unique hip hop dance crew. 

The youth dance group consists of thirteen students ranging from the ages of nine to nineteen years old. The two older dancers have part time jobs while attending school full time. Others are struggling with severe asthma, but that doesn't keep them from dancing. Truly dedicated, no matter how busy their schedules are, they still manage to come together and practice making sure each step is refined. They all bring something to the table with their diverse styles and unique flair. This youth dance group has so much love and respect towards one another, they're really more like a family. That's what it's all about, coming together to create such positivity. These kids are so amazingly talented at what they do. We can't wait to see what else this youth dance group can accomplish together.

The kids were invited to a special performance in LA and they'll be performing at a red carpet event in Hollywood California with over 40 celebrities in attendance. The !STOP! TOUR benefit concert & talent showcase event is being held on Saturday September 27, 2014 at Busby's East in Los Angeles, CA. It's being held to raise awareness and help STOP bullying and cyber bullying. 

The group is extremely excited and really looking forward to experiencing the event. However some of these kids are less fortunate than others and won't be able to attend. So we are asking if you could contribute to help the entire group in order for them to attend together. We don't want anyone from the group to miss out on this opportunity. The cost would go towards their performance fees, transportation, hotel room, costume and food. The breakdown consists of these costs listed below:

  • Outfit for dance performance - $30 per dancer (crew t-shirt)
  • Hotel fees - $80 per dancer (two nights)
  • Van Rental & gas - $75 per dancer 
  • Food for the weekend - $50 per dancer

If we are able to raise enough donations, the remaining $445 leftover from the $3500 will be donated towards the charity of  the event to prevent bullying and cyber bullying. 


Please help and assist us in making their dreams become a reality. Thank you

story:
About SA Met Ballet

San Antonio Metropolitan Ballet, founded in 1983 as San Antonio Dance Theatre, is a non-profit youth dance company, member Regional Dance America. The Company trains local dancers and choreographers age 9-24 with a foundation of ballet and modern styles. Artistic Director, Susan B. Connally and Associate Director, Karin Connally Heiden, both earned their Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance from The Boston Conservatory. SA Met Ballet has collaborated with such professional companies as Ballet West and Mejia Ballet International for their productions of “The Nutcracker” and The Royal Ballet Covent Garden for their US Production of “The Sleeping Beauty.”

San Antonio Metropolitan Ballet’s mission is to provide high quality, pre-professional instruction to local dancers and choreographers in a stimulating and nurturing environment through the presentation of cost-conscious, family-oriented productions, aimed at uplifting the San Antonio arts community.

SA Met Ballet seeks funds to produce two public performances and one closed- performance for elementary students for the fall presentation of “Snow White,” a new 3-act ballet.

Our goal is, for the first time in our 30-season history, to present our fall ballet with live music, accompanied by members of the Mid-Texas Symphony.

This production benefits the following areas:
  1) Educational Outreach – the Children’s Series performance is being presented to five area Elementary Schools that have Title I qualifications. This means greater than 50% of the population served by these schools are considered to be economically disadvantaged and culturally underserved. Our Children’s Series program offers much needed arts programming not realized at schools that have experienced recent budgetary cuts. Last season, when bringing her school to our production of “A Mid-Summer Night’s Dream,” a local middle school drama teacher exclaimed,“The experience was amazing for my students.  It surpassed my expectations!  This is the only way I've been able to effectively address the evaluation TEKS for theatre that require students be able to compare different modes of performance.”
  2) Community Service – Through our Children’s Series programming, our company dancers are taught about giving back to their community through service hours performing for the Title I Schools. SA Met Ballet also offers admission-free ticket vouchers to local Social Service Agencies to the public performances. In past seasons, agencies such as Roy Maas Youth Alternative, the local Ronald McDonald House and St. Joseph’s and St. Peter’s Children’s Home have participated in our performance voucher program. In 2009, SA Met Ballet was able to offer over $40,000 worth of program tickets to Title I Schools and Social Service Agencies.
  3) Economic Impact of the Arts on the Local Community – We are able to provide paid work for local professional dancers, seamstresses, stagehands, and musicians. We utilize locally-owned, small businesses to provide printing, costume and set construction services. Local restaurants and hotels are booked for guest travel.
  4) Community Inclusion – Through our Extra Student Dancer Roles, we are able to include a wide cross-section of the community in our fall performances free-of-charge. Community students participate in weekly rehearsals over a period from mid-August through performances in November. We provide costumes and headpieces at no cost to the participants as well.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The total project of “Snow White” will cost approximately $67,000. We do have funding from the City of San Antonio Department for Culture and Creative Development that will help cover approximately 20% of this program.
  • Funding for this project will go to the following basic categories: Theatre Rental, Costumes, Sets/Props, Guest Artists, Choreographer/Composer, the Symphony, Stagehands and most importantly – the Children’s Series Educational Outreach Program.
  • We’ve got some great perks for lovers of ballet and theatre. From playbill “Patron Thank-Yous” to Performance T-Shirts to Performance Tickets to Meet & Greets, we have a wonderful perk for every donor level. For those who would specifically like to help the Children’s Series program – We have a category just for you!
  • We believe in the tried and true phrase, “The Snow must go on – I mean, the SHOW must go on!” Any portion of our funding will be utilized to produce our performance of “Snow White.” Your contribution will help keep our program running for the talented youth of San Antonio.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • SA Met Ballet dancers range in age from 9 to 24. We are training students not only to be good dancers, but also productive, well-rounded citizens.
  • The Washington Post recently published a blog that speaks to the work we do on a daily basis: “Top 10 Skills Children Learn from the Arts” – 1) Creativity, 2) Confidence, 3) Problem Saving, 4) Perseverance, 5) Focus, 6) Non-Verbal Communication, 7) Receiving Constructive Feedback, 8) Collaboration, 9) Dedication and 10) Accountability.
  • San Antonio Metropolitan Ballet has a 100% high school graduation rate. Currently, our two featured company dancers are 1) in the top 5% of her graduating class and 2) pre-accepted into her top-choice college dance department.
  • Two of our performances are for the public and one of our performances is for an audience of Elementary Students and their Teachers/Chaperones. The Student Performance is an Admission-Free performance for economically disadvantaged and culturally underserved students from San Antonio area Title I schools. Many of these students have never before experienced live theatre productions. Included with this program is a lecture-demonstration that is presented in their school to prepare them for the ballet they are coming to see. SA Met Ballet volunteers travel to the schools to introduce the students to the music of the ballet, theatre etiquette, costume examples, ballet movement and theatre-specific projects. We traditionally have a list of schools who contact us directly to ask if their school will be able to attend our student programming. These repeat attendees reaffirm the need we fulfill in their school’s curriculum and the quality of the product we continue to present. Performances such as these also provide hope and inspiration for the attending students and give many options for their life path they may have not realized was out there.
  • Our Student Series program also teaches our company members the responsibility of giving back to your community. The sooner our students learn that their contribution to society is far-reaching through these types of productions, the more likely they will be productive citizens in the future.

Risks & Challenges

  • Since we perform in a city facility theatre venue, we are required to use a national ticketing agency to sell our tickets. This means that we do not see a penny of ticket sales until 2-3 weeks after the performance is over; therefore, we must fundraise ahead of time to produce our shows. This is sometimes a challenge when there are so many worthy causes out there.
  • We have maintained our season programming for 30 years without ever having to cancel a single performance. Even when times have gotten hard financially, we have still pulled through with the generosity of donors like you. We feel it is because they believe in the quality of the work we do and the impact it continues to make on the lives of students and their families.
  • Any time you produce a new performance, there are risks and challenges. In this day and age of technology, we must continue to reinforce the importance of interpersonal interaction and the value of the arts as a much needed factor of one’s collective being.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone may not have the funds to donate, so we ask you to help in the following ways:

·  Please give our campaign your time and energy to help spread the word of our mission.

  • Don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for taking the time to view our crowdfunding campaign! I hope you find a category that intrigues and inspires you. We truly appreciate your support.
story_txt:
About SA Met Ballet
San
Antonio Metropolitan Ballet, founded in 1983 as San Antonio Dance Theatre, is a non-profit youth dance
company, member Regional Dance America. The Company trains local dancers and
choreographers age 9-24 with a foundation of ballet and modern styles. Artistic
Director, Susan B. Connally and Associate Director, Karin Connally Heiden, both
earned their Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance from The Boston Conservatory. SA
Met Ballet has collaborated with such professional companies as Ballet West and
Mejia Ballet International for their productions of “The Nutcracker” and The
Royal Ballet Covent Garden for their US Production of “The Sleeping Beauty.” 
San
Antonio Metropolitan Ballet’s mission is to provide high quality,
pre-professional instruction to local dancers and choreographers in a
stimulating and nurturing environment through the presentation of
cost-conscious, family-oriented productions, aimed at uplifting the San Antonio
arts community.
SA
Met Ballet seeks funds to produce two public performances and one closed-
performance for elementary students for the fall presentation of “Snow White,”
a new 3-act ballet.
Our
goal is, for the first time in our 30-season history, to present our fall
ballet with live music, accompanied by members of the Mid-Texas Symphony.
This
production benefits the following areas:
  1) Educational Outreach – the Children’s
Series performance is being presented to five area Elementary Schools that have
Title I qualifications. This means greater than 50% of the population served by
these schools are considered to be economically disadvantaged and culturally
underserved. Our Children’s Series program offers much needed arts programming
not realized at schools that have experienced recent budgetary cuts. Last
season, when bringing her school to our production of “A Mid-Summer Night’s
Dream,” a local middle school drama teacher exclaimed,“The
experience was amazing for my students.  It surpassed my expectations!
 This is the only way I've been able to effectively address the evaluation
TEKS for theatre that require students be able to compare different modes of
performance.”
  2) Community Service – Through our
Children’s Series programming, our company dancers are taught about giving back
to their community through service hours performing for the Title I Schools. SA
Met Ballet also offers admission-free ticket vouchers to local Social Service
Agencies to the public performances. In past seasons, agencies such as Roy Maas
Youth Alternative, the local Ronald McDonald House and St. Joseph’s and St.
Peter’s Children’s Home have participated in our performance voucher program.
In 2009, SA Met Ballet was able to offer over $40,000 worth of program tickets
to Title I Schools and Social Service Agencies. 
  3) Economic Impact of the Arts on
the Local Community – We are able to provide paid work for local professional
dancers, seamstresses, stagehands, and musicians. We utilize locally-owned,
small businesses to provide printing, costume and set construction services.
Local restaurants and hotels are booked for guest travel. 
  4) Community Inclusion – Through our
Extra Student Dancer Roles, we are able to include a wide cross-section of the
community in our fall performances free-of-charge. Community students
participate in weekly rehearsals over a period from mid-August through
performances in November. We provide costumes and headpieces at no cost to the
participants as well.
What We Need & What You Get

     approximately $67,000. We do have funding from the City of San Antonio
     Department for Culture and Creative Development that will help cover approximately
     20% of this program.
Funding for this project will go to the following basic
     categories: Theatre Rental, Costumes, Sets/Props, Guest Artists,
     Choreographer/Composer, the Symphony, Stagehands and most importantly –
     the Children’s Series Educational Outreach Program.
We’ve got some great perks for lovers of ballet and
     theatre. From playbill “Patron Thank-Yous” to Performance T-Shirts to Performance
     Tickets to Meet & Greets, we have a wonderful perk for every donor
     level. For those who would specifically like to help the Children’s Series
     program – We have a category just for you!
We believe in the tried and true phrase, “The Snow must

     utilized to produce our performance of “Snow White.” Your contribution

more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their

story:
DANCE EDUCATION FOR KIDS IN NEWARK

we bring dance to children who may never have the opportunity or resources to access us

 

50 DAYS TO RAISE $5,000

Sharron Miller’s Academy for the Performing Arts (SMAPA) has been  offered a matching challenge grant to raise $5,000 to continue providing an inclusive year-long dance residency to underserved  K–5 students at the and further, to expand the program to include 6th, 7th and 8th grade students.

 

Help us meet the Victoria Foundation’s matching challenge grant so we may continue to bring quality dance education to all the students of Quitman Street Community School.

 

WHO WE ARE

Sharron Miller’s Academy for the Performing Arts (SMAPA) has provided inclusive, comprehensive, developmental training in dance and related theater arts to children, teens, and adults for 17 years.  SMAPA's teaching philosophy focuses on exploring and nurturing the creative possibilities within every student and is designed to develop the whole person by building skills, stimulating creativity, and fostering self-discipline and self-esteem.

 

SMAPA was founded in 1996 by Sharron Miller - Juilliard-trained, former soloist with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and Broadway veteran. Year-round training at SMAPA serves more than 1,500 students in four divisions: Preschool (2-5), Junior (6-11), Prep (12 -18), and the Adult division, which also includes a seniors exercise program. The most advanced students from the Prep and Junior Divisions are invited to join the Performance Workshop Ensemble (PWE). Ten students on full merit-based scholarship currently comprise the PWE, receiving the opportunity to work with directors and choreographers on presentational material to be performed within the community.  The PWE  and Junior PWE Programs are supported in part by a generous grant from The Stone Foundation.

 

Beyond classes held at the Montclair facility, SMAPA is committed to developing and implementing meaningful in-school arts experiences with hundreds of young people in collaboration with public schools.  The Quitman Street Community School is one of these collaborations.

 

WHY DANCE?

Dance nurtures the body and the mind. The original concept behind the Quitman program was to reinforce math skills through dance.  Of course, dance is geometric shapes, form, counting, time, recognizing the differences in general and personal space.  For the students at Quitman, the everyday four walls transform into a studio space where the concepts of symmetry and  asymmetry become the lexicon and the body the conductor. The kinesthetic intelligences of hundreds of children are nurtured as the study of dance allows students to work creatively to problem solve, develop sharp listening skills and learn to take control of the body as it moves through space.

 Through our collaboration, we’ve learned that dance creates another viable road for children to express while learning transferable academic skills.  The children with whom we work return to their classrooms with a  more positive self-image, a greater ability to focus and the application of conceptual learning skills.  In addition, the teaching of West African and Latin dance promote a deep sense of cultural grounding and pride.

 

WHAT WE’VE DONE SO FAR

For several years, Mr. Glover, the Quitman School principal,  has created the space for every child in K–5 to experience what we offer throughout the entire school year:

 

Creative Movement  Grades K-1

Rhythm & Tap   Grades 2-3

Latin & West African   Grades 4-5

 

HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE USED

The only way this program can continue is with your support.  

Outside of challenge grant donations, the residency is fully funded by foundational support.  The Victoria Foundation has strongly encouraged us to seek more divergent funding sources and we hope you can join us in meeting our November 14th deadline.  The grant compensates our teaching-artists for providing 14 classes a week for 36 weeks, buys tap shoes for all 2nd and 3rd grade students, and covers the program’s administrative expenses.

 

WHAT WE ENVISION

The has now  expanded to serve children through the 8th grade.  Our goal is to expand SMAPA’s residency, to offer a combined 6th, 7th and 8th grade dance elective once a week for the entire school year.

Modern, Jazz, Hip-Hop and  Theatre Dance would be offered during this yearlong residency allowing the older students with interest and/or ability the skills necessary to Audition for Newark’s Arts High School.

 

WHAT YOU GET

In return for your tax-deductible contribution* you may receive:

$10      Acknowledgement on our website

$25      One free SMAPA adult class & acknowledgement on our website

$50      A SMAPA dance bag & acknowledgement on our website

$100    A SMAPA Hoodie & acknowledgement on our website

$300    One semester (16 weeks) in the Preschool, Junior, or Prep Division &

            acknowledgement on our website

$1,000 One session of SMAPA’s Prime Time Summer Arts full day arts program & acknowledgement on our website

$1,500 Lunch with Sharron Miller & acknowledgement on our website

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

We understand that not everyone can make a monetary contribution at this moment., but there are still ways to help:  SPREAD THE WORD:

o Share our campaign effort with friends, organizations, dancers, lovers of dance. 

 http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/dance-education-for-kids-in-newark/x/4873316

o Like us on Facebook

o Follow us on Twitter:

o Come to our June  8, 2014 performance

o  Visit our website for more information   www.smapa.org

 

Please note:  Your donation qualifies for tax deductions according to the Federal tax laws. Generally, contributions are tax-deductible minus the fair market value of any gift items received.  To receive the full value of your contribution, you may choose not to receive the gift.  For questions about tax deductibility contact your tax advisor.  SMAPA will provide the value of any goods/services received in your acknowledgement letter.  SMAPA is a registered 501(c)(3) organization in the state of .

story:
True love is a giddy sensation,
Like madness with less medication.
But if you are crazy,
The line can get hazy;
Is it love or just self-mutilation?

Steph is a recovering depressive. Jamie overachieved himself off the deep end. When they meet in their psychiatrist’s office, the chemistry is undeniable, but is it survivable?


CHEMISTRY

by Jacob Marx Rice
directed by Joshua W. Kelley
Produced by Addison O'Donnell
Starring Noam Ash & Cassie West

September 26 - 28 @ 8pm
September 29 @ 2pm

THE ALCHEMICAL THEATRE LABORATORY
137 West 14th Street, NYC

www.ATLNYC.com for tickets & info


***

Associate Producer - Ali Skye Bennet

Scenic Designer - Justin West

Costume Designer - Matsy Stinson

Lighting Designer - Drew Paramore

Sound Designer - Olivia Gemelli

Makeup Artist - Stefani Vivian

Stage Manager - Kelsey Lake

Graphic Designer - Cathryn Salamone

story:
Since opening their doors in 2011, EMP Collective has been dedicated to paying stipends for all artists in their theatrical productions. Each year, we strive to produce works that are increasingly more imaginative and more risk-taking than the last; incorporating diverse voices from many artistic disciplines. While this is rewarding practice that supports brilliant work, it is an expensive operation. 
This year, we're taking it to the streets and asking for your donation toward these costs as we open our 2014-2015 season of performance, visual art, film, music, and lit with our next play, Potatoes of August.   

Potatoes of August kicks off EMP Collective's performance season which also includes our Pulse performance art series, a site-specific remount of Liz Maestri's Condo Condo Condoland (first workshopped through our Cans n Drafts writing program in 2012-2013), a brand new theatre weekend festival in the spring, several resident artist performances, and our super-secret summer show in 2015. 
We need $2500 for artist stipends on Potatoes of August. Any additional funds raised over our goal will go DIRECTLY toward artist stipends on these upcoming performance projects.


Two middle-aged couples are sent into spiraling existential crises when they discover a growing sack of sentient potatoes. These potatoes have brains, have read their Swedenborg, and DON’T. PLAY. FAIR. Rapidly growing in number and intellect, the potatoes unravel the couples’ carefully curated realities.

Parts kitchen sink drama, musical comedy, intimate biographical portraiture, museum educational presentation, opera, Renaissance fair, science fiction, science fair, and phenomenological debate, Potatoes of August swells and swirls on a vision quest for a different kind of understanding of the world around us.

The play opens October 9th and runs until October 26th, Thursdays - Sundays at 8PM. TICKETS AVAILABLE HERE.

Potatoes of August is our biggest to date and provides a wealth of artistic opportunities and challenges! We need your help in order to fully realize the vision of the artists bringing Potatoes of August to life and still ensure everyone is paid a stipend.



We are raising $2500 for artists stipends on Potatoes of August. Any additional funds after that will go toward artist stipends for our 2014-2015 programming. More money = more funding directly to local artists and new work. For your donation, we are also offering a slew of weird perks and goodies to make sure you never ever forget us. Check them out!



EMP Collective is an all-volunteer, artist-run 501(c)(3) non-profit and arts space. We are dedicated to free and low-cost events that offer uncompromising and adventurous art.  Because of this dedication, we need passionate people like you to help support our community of artists and continued success as a space. Since late 2011, we've produced and supported over 200 events and 400+ artists and have been recognized as the "Best Collective" and "Best Multi-Use Art Space" in Baltimore.

A donation to this campaign is a direct contribution to these local artists and the creation of new, challenging work in Baltimore. 



    • Strong-arm others into donating! Share this campaign with your friends and cohorts! Share it often!
    • Volunteer your time and skills at EMP!
    • Make an individual or business in-kind donation for our events!
