Strong-arm others into donating! Share this campaign with your friends and cohorts! Share it often! Volunteer your time and skills at EMP!
Make an individual or business in-kind donation for our events!

story:
Who We Are

The Young Americans’ Theatre Company (YATC) was founded in 2008 by six high school students. Since our inception, we have produced a summer season each year at a different Seattle venue, continually expanding our company of actors, directors, administrators, and audience. YATC’s work is entirely produced by teenagers ages 14 – 21. Now, in its seventh year, YATC is a vibrant piece of Seattle’s theatre community and youth culture. Each year, a new board of students take over the company’s administration, keeping it fresh and relevant. 


YATC provides young people with opportunities to explore every aspect of the theatre, including tech, acting, directing and learning about business and marketing as board members. YATC is completely youth run, and participants have the rare opportunity to experience program management while still in high school. Working with YATC is a truly empowering and life changing experience. 

           


Why We're Asking for Donations

We want to make our seventh season bigger and better than ever and we need your help to do that. 

What We Need To Pay For

  • Space
    This season we are performing at The Eclectic Theatre on Capitol Hill, in the heart of Seattle. 
  • Rights 
    Since we are performing more plays than ever this season we need extra money to pay for performance rights. 
  • Props 
  • Costumes
  • Marketing 
    We want to extend our impact on the Seattle community through outreach and publicity. 
  • Tech 
    We want to make sure that the technical elements of our performances are as high quality as the acting and directing that we put so much work into. 


Impact

Participating in any of our programs is always free. We offer an intern training program where students learn project management and business skills. There are also opportunities to direct, act, and work on technical theatre technique every season. YATC provides an opportunity for teens to stay involved in the arts during the summer without having to pay for expensive summer camps. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to provide financial support, you can still help us out by spreading the word about our campaign and YATC as an organization. Please share this campaign to your friends if you can.

Most importantly, theatre is nothing without an audience. It would mean the world to us if you could come see one of our shows this summer and participate in our mission to make Seattle youth-run theatre a reality. 

You can find information about our season and showtimes on our website. 
www.youngamericanstheatreco.org

story:
WHAT IS THE MISSION?

Curious Beast Theatre Co. believes that theatre is an essential tool in bringing about a dialogue on important issues that face a community as diverse as Los Angeles. We believe that storytelling is at the forefront of the theatrical experience because it bridges the gap between seemingly diverse populations and shines a light on our common human experiences. For without story we are mindless beasts linking together pieces of information without the framework to understand their context and application. We honor stories that engage us in an emotional and cerebral way to inspire conversation about social equality, including sex, race, religion, as well as civic duty and personal responsibility. With an emphasis on new works, re-imagined classics and multi-disciplinary projects incorporating music and dance we will bring to the community stories that inspire us, haunt us, demand of us, and, in some small way, change us, always helping us find a way to humanize us all. This year we are producing two plays for the renowned Hollywood Fringe Festival in Hollywood, California. This festival bring 35,000 theatre lovers from around the world. 

One of the plays chosen is called REBORNING by up and coming playwright Zayd Dohrn. A dark comedy about life-like baby dolls, latex and phallus. Kelly, an orphan doll maker and Daizy, a hippy art school dropout, who now use their skills to fill the void of those in need. A demanding client may be the key to kelly’s past; as she tries to unravel the mystery she discovers the path to her own reborning. “Reborning” was originally produced in New York at the Summer Play Festival.

WHERE ARE MY FUNDS GOING? 

We are raising funds to help aid in the production of this play but on a much larger scale we are using this opportunity as a spring board for our theatre company to gain traction in Los Angeles.  To become a force for positive and mindful action that inspires a stronger sense of community, along with helping cultivate a sustainable and thriving theatre culture in Los Angeles.

Your money goes directly to creating these opportunities and securing the venues in which to do so. It is not being used in fanciful or over glamorous productions- it is being used to secure the theatre. We are all about finding meaningful stories, wonderful story tellers, and appropriate venues that will allow us to reach people and showcase the work.   If we can raise our goal of $850 it will pay for the rent fees of the theatre for all four nights of the performances. 

WHO AM I HELPING? 

"Investment in the creative industries is an investment in our innovative potential, our health, our humanity, and our education."

"The arts and creative industries aren’t just the things that make our spare time better, they’re also the therapy, the prison rehabilitation schemes, and the people working in schools to improve community cohesion and literacy."

"Children working in schools with the recently cut Creative Partnerships got, on average, 2 and a half grades better at GCSE than schools where the program wasn’t working. Absenteeism was reduced by 1/5 (source). The improvement to the atmosphere of the schools, and the aspirations of their staff and pupils have improved both the schools involved and their local communities."

WHO? WHAT? WHEN? WHERE?

We are presenting two shows at the Hollywood Fringe this year; LOCKOUT and REBORNING. The two one-acts will be performed back to back on Saturdays, June 14, 21 and 28 at 8:15 and 9:15pm. Preview on Sunday June 8 at 3:15 and 4:15pm.

At McCadden Place Theatre                                                                                               1157 N McCadden Pl                                                                                                              Los Angeles, CA 90038


Hollywood Fringe 2014 link for LOCKOUT:

 http://hollywoodfringe.org/projects/1838

 Hollywood Fringe 2014 link for REBORNING"

http://hollywoodfringe.org/projects/1839

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our show and forward our campaign to anyone you think might be interested. And if it's not in your budget to donate right now, please let us know if you would like to help out during the performances.  We need volunteers for Front of House, Box office, Load In/Load Out. You can see the show for free if you volunteer!

Curious Beast Theatre Co. is also presenting LOCKOUT 1 hr prior to REBORNING at McCadden Place Theatre at 8:15.

Thanks to everyone for your support from all of us at Curious Beast; 

From Left; Christopher Wallinger, Managing Director, Jaimie Boabley, Co-Artistic Director, Spark O' Connell, Marketing Director and Bridgette Campbell, Co-Artistic Director

We can't wait to see you at Reborning and Lockout Fringe 2014!

story:
Short Summary

Olivia Briggs is an award-winning dramatic writer fresh on the New York theatre scene. Her first New York production, 'Bottles on the Water, a Night of Short Plays from Abroad', that she co-wrote and produced, was performed in September of 2013 at the Arthur Seleen Theatre in New York City and recently published by Next Stage Press. 

Now Briggs is embarking on her second New York City production, "Ronnie's Cabinet", a full-length play about a neurotic, young, New Yorker who discovers the familial roots of his dysfunction through the death of his older sister. It is a family dramedy comprised of seven characters all performed by two incredible actors. (Jonathan Greene and Shelley Little)

The play has just received placement Cabrini Repertory's Thespis Theatre Festival for six performances scheduled in June of 2014. To pull this production off, however, we need your help! All contributions to this campaign go directly to the actors, the design and artistic team, as well as a non-refundable deposit on the space for the festival.


What We Need & What You Get

We are attempting to raise $4,000 to start this thing off. The funds raised in this campaign will go directly to:

1. Paying the actors and assistant director for a one week intensive workshopping process to refine the script.

2. Paying the $500 non-refundable deposit on the theater at Cabrini Rep.

3. Renting Cabrini rep for $80 one night for a reading of the play on January 29th, 2014.

4. All additional funds will go towards the purchase of materials to begin construction on set and costumes.

Every contribution gets us one step closer to bringing more original theatre to Washington Heights, and helping this brand spankin' new play get it's world premiere on the NYC stage!

In addition, depending on the amount of your contribution, you could get your name in the program as a special thanks, an associate producer, a producer, or an executive producer credit! Producers and executive producers will also have their names immortalized in the published script when it hits shelves shortly after the production in June of 2014.



The Impact

"Ronnie's Cabinet" will be the first fully staged, full-length production written and directed by Olivia Briggs. By donating, you are not only helping to bring her work into the public arena, you are also helping to promote the talents of two extraordinary actors, an incredible assistant director, Cherish Henson, as well as the artistic team that will be assembled for the June production.

But wait! There's more!

Your contribution also helps to support the Thespis Theatre Festival and the Cabrini Repertory Theatre, one of the very few organizations bringing live theatre to the up and coming neighborhood of Washington Heights. Live theatre helps communities thrive. Be a part of the next wave!



Other Ways You Can Help

We COMPLETELY understand if this is a bad time for you and you can't contribute money to the campaign. That doesn't mean, however, that you can't help us reach our goal. You can paste the link to our campaign on Facebook and tell your friends why they should contribute, tweet it, e-mail your theatre-loving uncle Larry and tell him that some crazy kids are putting up a new show. Spreading the word helps us too, so any extra publicity is very much appreciated!

story:
Speak! Set in Miami, Florida just as the Funk of the 80’s was ending and the hip hop/grunge period of the 90’s was beginning. In Speak! Not only do you witness the plight of me trying to find my voice, but you also meet my Puerto Rican/Cuban/African American/Jewish posse who helped and inspired me with their own amazing voices and who in their own way had something that prevented them from saying what they really meant to say.  Speak! explores the thing that unites us all, which is our need to be heard and understood. 

Speak! started as a solo piece in the basement of University California, San Diego. Locking myself in rehearsal spaces in the school's basement I listened to music from my pre-teen years, to seek inspiration. While listening to any one of my musical giants from Chaka Khan to Erykah Badu to the Cranberries I began to improvise and record scenes and dialogue. During this process I also utilized family videos. Inspired by the support of the faculty at UCSD I continued developing my piece. After moving to New York City I started to write and rehearse my solo piece as part of a weekly acting class with JoAnna Beckson. Upon joining the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater Writers Lab, I continued the process of writing, rehearsing and performing Speak! There I met director Andreas Robertz, who like the teachers at UCSD, saw something in this piece that was worth developing.

With a great director at the helm, I am beyond excited, for the opportunity to perform this show at Under St. Marks Theater, but I can't get there without your financial support! Your generous contribution will go entirely to the production of Speak! 

(Production Breakdown)

Director's Fee

Theater Rental

Rehearsal Space Rental

Insurance

Fire Guard

Technical Support

Publicity

PR

Photographer

Editor

Costumes

Props

Thank You for Visiting!


￼ ￼￼

story:
Hello and welcome to the 2015 FUNDRAISING CAMPAIGN for SCI-FEST LA: The 2nd Annual Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival!

2014 was a very cool year.  After a decade of acting on TV shows like BOSTON LEGAL, MAD MEN, TRUE BLOOD & JUSTIFIED, I got to fulfill a lifelong dream by teaming up with my friends (and veteran LA theater producers) Lee Costello and Michael Blaha to create an utterly unique Sci-Fi Festival here in Hollywood.  
Last May, SCI-FEST LA debuted, bringing 2 rotating evenings of scary, hilarious and mind-bending short plays to Los Angeles starring an incredible cast of actors famous for their work on such iconic TV franchises as STAR TREK, THE X-FILES, LOST, STARGATE: UNIVERSE, HEROES, TRUE BLOOD and FRINGE.  The Fest was such a success (with packed houses & great press) that it's brought a whole new set of even more challenging and amazing scripts our way including knock-out adaptations of Neil Gaiman's "The Case of Four and Twenty Blackbirds" and Clive Barker's acclaimed short story, "The Departed," (sent to us by Mr. Barker himself).  We're tremendously excited about bringing all these new stories of time travel, ghostly obsessions and intergalactic journeys to life, but to do them justice, we will need to substantially increase our production budget.  

Last year, we raised an impressive $81,000.00 on Kickstarter and produced a groundbreaking month-long Festival.   Luckily, our major donors believe (as we do) that this opportunity to take Sci-Fest LA to the next level is too amazing to pass up. These incredible people have made us a very generous offer.  If we can raise $100,000.00 via this IndieGoGo campaign, our major donors will contribute an additional 30% MATCHING GRANT!  This would be a real game changer for us. 

Sci-Fest LA is on an utterly unique path.  Unlike the "cons" or fan gatherings, Sci-Fest LA is passionately dedicated to the creation of NEW Sci-Fi content.  This year, in addition to our stage shows, we have initiated two new Sci-Fi short fiction contests: THE ROSWELL AWARD (for adult Sci-Fi writers from around the globe) and THE TOMORROW PRIZE (for LA County High School Students).   All funds raised at the presentation ceremony for the Tomorrow Prize will be awarded to the winner's high school science department. Info: www.Sci-FestLA.com 

What We Need & What We Can Offer

Last year, we floated astronauts in space and figured out how to make an live actor's face grow out of an elastic wall.  Almost all the shows we're doing in 2015 will need some kind of specially designed props, lighting, sound effects or prosthetic make up.  All these cool effects require a lot of our designers' time and effort.  This also means paying for more rehearsal time in the theater to perfect those effects before our first audience arrives.  Like last year, the majority of Sci-Fest's budget will be spent on theater rental and the cost of physically producing the plays with only a small portion devoted to modest salaries for key design and production people.   

We're Changing!   Sci-Fest LA is now a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Sci-Fest LA can now be easily made via Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

We want to make it fun to support Sci-Fest LA!  That's why we're continuing to offer cool, clever (and in some cases) amazing perks to our donors.  Everything from funny bumper stickers to free tickets to signed memorabilia and unique works of poster art designed especially for the Festival by some of LA's hottest comic book and Sci-Fi artists.  Your support matters to us.  

Why Sci-Fest LA Matters to You

Our mission is simple:  To create new work that inspires artists and audiences alike to consider our collective future.  Our hope is to continue to grow the Festival, eventually moving into a larger venue and becoming a "destination event" attracting Sci-Fi fans from around the globe to Los Angeles.  Above all, Sci-Fest LA is fun!  Last year, we produced a dynamite Festival that the world-famous Hollywood Reporter called "An inspired notion," concluding that "After seeing the First Annual Sci-Fest, rest assured you’ll be hoping for a Second Annual Sci-Fest, and more after that.” Our audiences were moved and amazed by last year's Festival and we want to deliver them even more surprises in 2015.  We believe in the possibility of Sci-Fest LA to inspire innovative and purposeful thought in every person who participates, volunteers or attends.  Please help us insure the future of this awesome annual event by allowing us to hit (or even exceed) our goal of $100,000.00 in 50 days! 

Challenges

Producing Science Fiction live on stage requires (a) great material and (b) creative thinking.   We are blessed to have an incredibly skilled team of Los Angeles-based producers, directors and designers -- All of whom are currently professionally employed in the TV, Film and Theater industries.  Between all of us, there aren't many problems we can't solve.  This team is backed up 100% by an tireless crew of volunteers and fans who consistently make sure the Festival gets the loving support it needs to succeed.   Challenges are inevitable, but the equation for success is always the same:  passion + team work.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to give financially, there are other ways you can help. One way is to be our "voice" in your community by talking about the Festival and re-posting anything you see about us on Facebook or Twitter.  Taking the time to personally endorse us to your friends can mean a lot!  Sci-Fest LA also needs volunteers to staff events, hand out flyers and do promotional work.  The Festival can always make use of donated prizes to offer to our many contributors as rewards for their generosity.   Contact us at Info@Sci-Fest.com.  And don't forget that IndieGoGo also has some great "Share" tools.   Please use them.  

Lastly, we would like to say THANK YOU FOR BELIEVING IN SCI-FEST LA!  This is a pivotal time for us and we are extremely grateful for the incredible outpouring of support we are receiving from all over the globe.  Welcome to our growing family of donors! We have a lot of exciting announcements coming up so please sign up for our e-mail list at www.Sci-FestLA.com.  We hope to see you at the Festival in May. Please make sure to say hello!  

Live Long and Prosper,

David Dean Bottrell

Producer, Sci-Fest LA (with Lee Costello & Michael Blaha)  

www.Sci-FestLA.com or contact us at Info@Sci-Fest.com 



Shooting our 2015 pre-show video with the hilarious and legendary STAN LEE!

January 17th, 2015:  Our All-Star, One-Night Only performance of Orson Welles' WAR OF THE WORLDS featuring  Wil Wheaton and Series Regulars from ALL 5 "Star Trek" TV franchises plus special guests from "The X-Files" and "The Event"

Hello and welcome to the 2015 FUNDRAISING CAMPAIGN for SCI-FEST LA: The 2nd Annual Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival!
2014 was a very cool year.  After a decade of acting on TV shows like BOSTON LEGAL, MAD MEN, TRUE BLOOD & JUSTIFIED, I got to fulfill a lifelong dream by teaming up with my friends (and veteran LA theater producers) Lee Costello and Michael Blaha to create an utterly unique Sci-Fi Festival here in Hollywood.  

Last May, SCI-FEST LA debuted, bringing 2 rotating evenings of scary, hilarious and mind-bending short plays to Los Angeles starring an incredible cast of actors famous for their work on such iconic TV franchises as STAR TREK, THE X-FILES, LOST, STARGATE: UNIVERSE, HEROES, TRUE BLOOD and FRINGE.  The Fest was such a success (with packed houses & great press) that it's brought a whole new set of even more challenging and amazing scripts our way including knock-out adaptations of Neil Gaiman's "The Case of Four and Twenty Blackbirds" and Clive Barker's acclaimed short story, "The Departed," (sent to us by Mr. Barker himself).  We're tremendously excited about bringing all these new stories of time travel, ghostly obsessions and intergalactic journeys to life, but to do them justice, we will need to substantially increase our production budget.  


Last year, we raised an impressive $81,000.00 on Kickstarter and produced a groundbreaking month-long Festival.   Luckily, our major donors believe (as we do) that this opportunity to take Sci-Fest LA to the next level is too amazing to pass up. These incredible people have made us a very generous offer.  If we can raise $100,000.00 via this IndieGoGo campaign, our major donors will contribute an additional 30% MATCHING GRANT!  This would be a real game changer for us. 


Sci-Fest LA is on an utterly unique path.  Unlike the "cons" or fan gatherings, Sci-Fest LA is passionately dedicated to the creation of NEW Sci-Fi content.  This year, in addition to our stage shows, we have initiated two new Sci-Fi short fiction contests: THE ROSWELL AWARD (for adult Sci-Fi writers from around the globe) and THE TOMORROW PRIZE (for LA County High School Students).   All funds raised at the presentation ceremony for the Tomorrow Prize will be awarded to the winner's high school science department. Info: www.Sci-FestLA.com  

What We Need & What We Can Offer

Last year, we floated astronauts in space and figured out how to make an live actor's face grow out of an elastic wall.  Almost all the shows we're doing in 2015 will need some kind of specially designed props, lighting, sound effects or prosthetic make up.  All these cool effects require a lot of our designers' time and effort.  This also means paying for more rehearsal time in the theater to perfect those effects before our first audience arrives.  Like last year, the majority of Sci-Fest's budget will be spent on theater rental and the cost of physically producing the plays with only a small portion devoted to modest salaries for key design and production people.   


We're Changing!   Sci-Fest LA is now
a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization.
Contributions for the charitable purposes of Sci-Fest LA can now be easily made via Fractured Atlas and are
tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

We want to make it fun to support Sci-Fest LA!  That's why we're continuing to offer cool, clever (and in some cases) amazing perks to our donors.  Everything from funny bumper stickers to free tickets to signed memorabilia and unique works of poster art designed especially for the Festival by some of LA's hottest comic book and Sci-Fi artists.  Your support matters to us.  





Why Sci-Fest LA Matters to You


Our mission is simple:  To create new work that inspires artists and audiences alike to consider our collective future.  Our hope is to continue to grow the Festival, eventually moving into a larger venue and becoming a "destination event" attracting Sci-Fi fans from around the globe to Los Angeles.  Above all, Sci-Fest LA is fun!  Last year, we produced a dynamite Festival that the world-famous Hollywood Reporter called "An inspired notion," concluding that "After seeing the
First Annual Sci-Fest, rest assured you’ll be hoping for a Second Annual
Sci-Fest, and more after that.” Our audiences were moved and amazed by last year's Festival and we want to deliver them even more surprises in 2015.  We believe in the possibility of Sci-Fest LA to inspire innovative and purposeful thought in every person who participates, volunteers or attends.  Please help us insure the future of this awesome annual event by allowing us to hit (or even exceed) our goal of $100,000.00 in 50 days! 
Challenges
Producing Science Fiction live on stage requires (a) great material and (b) creative thinking.   We are blessed to have an incredibly skilled team of Los Angeles-based producers, directors and designers -- All of whom are currently professionally employed in the TV, Film and Theater industries.  Between all of us, there aren't many problems we can't solve.  This team is backed up 100% by an tireless crew of volunteers and fans who consistently make sure the Festival gets the loving support it needs to succeed.   Challenges are inevitable, but the equation for success is always the same:  passion + team work.  



Other Ways You Can Help
If you're unable to give financially, there are other ways you can help. One way is to be our "voice" in your community by talking about the Festival and re-posting anything you see about us on Facebook or Twitter.  Taking the time to personally endorse us to your friends can mean a lot!  Sci-Fest LA also needs volunteers to staff events, hand out flyers and do promotional work.  The Festival can always make use of donated prizes to offer to our many contributors as rewards for their generosity.   Contact us at Info@Sci-Fest.com.  And don't forget that IndieGoGo also has some great "Share" tools.   Please use them.  

Lastly, we would like to say THANK YOU FOR BELIEVING IN SCI-FEST LA!  This is a pivotal time for us and we are extremely grateful for the incredible outpouring of support we are receiving from all over the globe.  Welcome to our growing family of donors! We have a lot of exciting announcements coming up so please sign up for our e-mail list at www.Sci-FestLA.com.  We hope to see you at the Festival in May. Please make sure to say hello!  
Live Long and Prosper,
David Dean Bottrell
Producer, Sci-Fest LA (with Lee Costello & Michael Blaha)  
www.Sci-FestLA.com or contact us at Info@Sci-Fest.com 



Shooting our 2015 pre-show video with the hilarious and legendary STAN LEE!

January 17th, 2015:  Our All-Star, One-Night Only performance of Orson Welles' WAR OF THE WORLDS featuring  Wil Wheaton and Series Regulars from ALL 5 "Star Trek" TV franchises plus special guests from "The X-Files" and "The Event"

story:
Short Summary


Sans-Culottes Theatre Company Presents Peter Weiss' Marat/Sade!

￼￼With a cast comprised of professional actors, along with war veterans and those who have experienced homelessness, the play's central themes of the devastation of war and of economic injustice, themes highly relevant to our present time, are poignantly conveyed by those who have known firsthand the true cost of war and economic inequality.  

Marat/Sade will be our Company's premier production!

Thus far the production has been enthusiastically endorsed by the following organizations:

 - Veterans for Peace (NYC Chapter) 

 - Veterans Peace Council

 - Warrior Writers

 - Institute for Community Living  

 - Brooklyn for Peace  

Why do we need $50,000?  This may seem like an exorbitant amount to spend on a production, but as anyone who has produced in New York City a play as large in cast and crew as Marat/Sade would know, $50,000 is a very lean budget.

Here's a breakdown of the approximate budget for the production - 

- Theatre Rental: $20,400

- Actors'/Crew's Per Diem (Total amount set aside for per diem payments made to cast and crew; includes per diem paid for rehearsals and performances):  $21,600

- Rental of Rehearsal Spaces (four weeks of rehearsals, six rehearsal-days each week):   $3,000

So far, that brings our expenses to $45,000.  The remaining $5,000 will be used for marketing, and for purchasing insurance, sets, costumes, make-up, and for any transportation costs.  

The casting has begun, and we have several war veterans in key roles and as members of the ensemble!  With your financial help, we will bring this production to the public!

story:
Raising Oleanna

We are thrilled to be asking for funding for our innaugural production:  Oleanna by David Mamet.

Why this show?  Read the blog post:  http://jaybirdproductions.blogspot.ca/2012/07/why-this-piece-why-now.html

Jacqui Burke, Artistic Director

Jacqui has over forty years experience in and around theatre.  She was a professional stage manager in her twenties, transitioned into directing in her thirties and, since returning from living abroad in Australia, Jacqui is directing exclusively, helming three or four productions a year.

She has filled just about every position in theatre - including performing - and is no stranger to producing.  Directing resume:  http://www.wordsnimages.com/archives/resume2010.pdf

More about Jacqui with reviews and pictures from old shows:  http://www.wordsnimages.com

Jaybird Productions

Jaybird is just a year old after having been established for the purpose of presenting edgy and difficult shows at a Community Theatre level.   Goo, goo. Struggling to get out of the nest....

Jaybird's homepage:  http://www.jaybirdproductions.ca

Jaybird's facebook page:  https://www.facebook.com/pages/Jaybird-Productions/133676920019087

Oleanna by David Mamet

In this critically acclaimed two character play (one of my personal favourites), a college student accuses her professor of sexual exploitation, an act which loses him tenure.  The power struggle between them is riveting.  But who is in the right and who is in the wrong?  You be the judge.

Facebook event:  https://www.facebook.com/events/479287328750669/

Our Funding Goal

We are looking to raise funds for 1) the rights, 2) theatre, and 3) rehearsal space by the middle of October -- these costs total about $2,500; so this is our funding goal.  We have a great many perks to offer our supporters and, as always, our thanks for anyone who is willing to contribute to the production in any way.
 
If we are able to exceed this goal we will add shows, hire local musicians to create live music for the show, and sock money away for Jaybird's second production.

The Impact

Currently, a large pool of very talented performers are working at the Community Theatre level in Toronto.  These performers are interested and willing to take up the challenge of edgier work.  We are trying to present shows that are rarely, if ever, performed at this level - Oleanna is one of those shows.  Some community theatres may be making very safe choices at this time but these difficult, relevant stories still deserve to be told.

Other Ways You Can Help

Folks!  Want to help out the production?  Get props? Costumes?  Hang lights?  Or help us out by spreading the word both about the show and/or this fundraising event.

story:
Short Summary

Celebrating Jamaica 50 and the Jamaican Woman. Katherine tries to keep her daughter employed, her mother out of her business and her secrets buried! Come see what happens in the play on Nov. 29!

Hi I'm Karl the program director for Braata Theatre Workshop, and the playwright for Not About Eve. I act, I teach, I write, and I direct - all with the desire to promote my region as an artistic birthing mecca, and to add to the rich cultural heritage it has helped to give the world. My play deals with the changing face of the Jamaican society through the very peronal lens of 3 generations of women. It's part entertainment, and part educational. I would love to see and hear the response to the play from a more diverse audience, so please come out and see it, and if you can help make it live on the New York Stage, check out the info below and get involved.

What We Need & What You Get

We need:

Ply wood to make lattice work partitions for the set

Paint - whites, browns, blues and greens

Lots of Green Tropical Plants and Orchids

Funds for Design & Program Printing

Funds for Promotional Material

You get:

Honorable mention in the Not About Eve Show Program 

Honorable mention on Braata Production's Website

Honorable mention on all Online Promotions for Not About Eve

An invite to Braata's All-Inclusive Annual "Thank You" Party in December! The food is all Jamaican, the music is Caribbean & the Vibe is Great!!!!

The Impact

The Braata Theatre Workshop (BTW) is part of the Braata Productions family and it's responsible for promoting Caribbean theatre in the NY Tri-state area. Projects like Not About Eve help advocate for emerging Caribbean talents. BTW's mission is to help give talent within the Caribean Diaspora a platform to showcase and develop their work. The United States is home to over 6 million Caribbean Immigrants, and BTW is dedicated to playing its part to secure and maintain current theatrical representation in our communities and beyond!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about Braata Productions and the play Not About Eve

Email me at getmadkow@gmail.com, or Braata's founder Andrew Clarke at braataproductions@gmail.com if you are interested in volunteering your time to 1. Sell tickets, 2. Work backstage or front of house, 3. Help with promoting the play or 4. Help with sourcing props for the production.

story:
WHAT DO YOU WANT TO DO THIS SUMMER?


In July 2013, the Road Less Traveled Productions’ Summer Institute (SI) began to ask young aspiring theatre artists that question. My name's Jon and I'm the Education Director for the SI. We educated young theatre artists to create & perform original plays... not major musicals, not necessarily classic chestnuts of the American theater... but instead offbeat, fun, and unique plays that our students initiate, devise, and produce. Now in our third year, the SI continues to bring our students’ dreams to life. You can help! 

The first two-week session of RLTP's 2015 Summer Institute is fully enrolled. However, space remains in our second two-week session. We seek to provide our unique summer theatre program to seven students in Western New York, free of charge. Please help us underwrite tuition costs for seven talented and enthusiastic students who otherwise might be unable to participate in this exciting opportunity! 

A little information about the Summer Institute:

 

Some kids like to spend their summers hiking and camping. Some like to play sports. Me? I liked to write, produce, and perform plays with my friends. It turns out that there are a lot of kids like me out there. Some of them want to dedicate their summers to perfecting the choreography to a large chorus number from a major musical. Others, though, want to focus on acting... they aspire to performing in Shakespearean dramas, or guest-starring on "Saturday Night Live"... or they want to write or direct or star in their own plays (or all of the above). The RLTP Summer Institute is designed for those students! 

The SI’s two-week day camp, Summer Fundamentals, allows each student to craft their own experience to suit their personal interests & ambitions. In Week One, students enjoy an introduction to basics of theatre performance while simultaneously developing universal life skills like confidence, public speaking ability, and teamwork - skills which will benefit them no matter their educational or career paths. SI students also receive training in Linklater, Stanislavski, and Suzuki techniques (skills usually reserved for a college curriculum) so they receive a major advantage that will benefit them should they continue their theatre training! And, we help them improve their writing, character-building, and storytelling skills... which (again) are universally useful tools but which furthermore will come in handy in Week Two...

In Week Two, the SI faculty implements an innovative technique where our students curate & generate a collection of short scenes and plays, develop & rehearse them with peer & faculty support, and unveil them for an audience of family & friends at Final Presentations Night. Basically, on Monday morning we ask our students: What do you want to do this week? They present us with a monologue, or a short play, or a scene from a longer play. Sometimes these are extant works, but often these are original plays written by our students. Other times, students collaborate under faculty supervision to devise original plays through improvisational scene-building. The students stage, rehearse, and polish the work that's important to them, with faculty support. On Friday night, they reveal their efforts to an eager audience of fans & well-wishers.


I should mention that all of this happens onstage in RLTP's brand new Road Less Traveled Theater @ 500 Pearl - a professional producing theater! Not only do students learn & perform onstage, they will in fact be the first performers to present work at this premier theater space! 


Some theatre camps accommodate dozens of students in each session, herding them towards a single finish line. The SI recognizes, however, that each of our students is an individual with unique strengths & passions, so we strive to invest significant time & attention to each of those students. The SI not only instructs future generations of theatre practitioners but also inspires & empowers them to create the kind of theatre that they want to see. Although we have grown in the past two years, we realize that our specialized “boutique” program must be nurtured with the same patience & care that we offer our students. Although we may serve two dozen students a year, we are providing them with an experience they won't receive anywhere else! So today I invite you to support the vital development of our best & brightest young artists as well as the unique program that serves them. 

Please help us underwrite tuition so that seven students can attend RLTP’s 2015 Summer Institute! Our first two-week session is fully enrolled. However, spaces remain in our second two-week session. RLTP has provided fully sponsored tuitions to underprivileged students in 2013 and 2014. We can provide our program to seven additional students this summer, too - but we need your help! 


RLTP is a 501c3 not-for-profit organization, so your donation is tax deductible. All donations, no matter the size, will be recognized in the programs for our Final Presentation Nights. 

RLTP will also provide a variety of Perks to thank you for your support, according to the level of your donation. There are some fun Perks available, but the most valuable Perk will be the experience that you help supply to these students! 

Every little bit helps, and every five hundred dollars we raise will allow us to provide our service to another young theatre artist in WNY. 

If you're not able to donate, please help us spread the word. Use those Indiegogo share tools! Tweet, retweet, Share, phone a friend, or text them, or heck, even mention it in conversation to other human beings, in person. I'll appreciate it, but the students that this campaign supports will appreciate it even more. 

What do you want to do this summer? We at RLTP want to help kids to write and stage world premiere plays, never before seen outside of their imaginations; we want to enable them to assume roles onstage that they’ve only ever fantasized about playing; we want to make their dreams come true. Will you help us?

Thank you for your consideration & for all that you do!

story:
My name is Idan Cohen and I am an Israeli choreographer.  

This April and May I am taking my company on a cross country US tour to conclude my intensive work on 'I Capuleti e I Montecchi', a dance opera which I have been working on over the past three years.

Our art is about love and hate - about increasing peace and understanding. We are committed to building bridges between people and cultures. 

I need your support on this tour in order to meet our goal through opera and dance.

I was raised and educated in a high conflict zone in northern Israel. This has had a tremendous effect on my artistic life and work. I have dedicated my artistic life to increasing communication for peace and understanding. I believe in equality, in reaching out to unprivileged communities, and in raising social and political issues through dance.  I believe in finding ways to cross artistic boundaries to reflect of our society. During the last three years, I've been creating 'I Capuleti e I Montecchi', a dance opera, as a response to the need for societies and individuals to co-exist. My exploration and expression unites the art forms of opera and dance, which I continue to present through a variety of public talks, master classes, and of course, performances! This US tour, which will include both Israeli and American artists, will play an extremely important role in the creation of a global community through art. 

I ask for your support to achieve these shared goals, to promote love and equality through the international language of art.



Where and when

April 21 & 23, 2016 - "I Capuleti e I Montecchi”: The Idan Cohen Dance Company, in collaboration with Amherst College,  premiere at 'Kirby Memorial Theater', Amherst College, MA.

May 13 & 14, 2016 - “Gender Bender”: Two performances of Cohen’s celebrated creation at 'Diavolo Dance Theater', Los Angeles, CA.

May 20, 2016 - “Gender Bender": Performance at the 'Mandeville theater', University of California San Diego, Master Classes, open rehearsals and Post performance talk. 

May 22, 2016 - “Gender Bender”: One performance at the Jewish Federation JCC,  as a part of Irvine’s Israeli Expo.  'Myers Theatre', Irvine, Orange County .CA.

Come and join us!!

Please support us…

We need to raise an additional $7,500.

Your support will go toward: Transportation and accommodation, 

artist Per Diems, equipment rentals and musicians.

Any surplus of funds will help us to:

Fund transportation within the USA (Amherst- Irvine- LA-Irvine- SD).

Shipping the “Gender Bender” set design to Los Angeles.

Tour & stage manager fee.


Ways you can support us 

1. Donate toward one of our funding proposals.

2. Mail this campaign to 5 people who may be interested in supporting us.

3. Share our campaign on your FB page and Twitter or any other type of

  social media.

4. Talk about us.

5. Come and join us at a performance.


Forming the bridges that connect us

A little more about me: I'm a former dancer at the world-renowned Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company.  Since 2007, I have been performing, creating and teaching as an international award-winning choreographer through the Idan Cohen Dance Company. I recently graduated from the “Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance” with a MA in Choreography.

From the press:

("Swan Lake"- Deborah Friedes, Jerusalem Post- December 2009)

("Mad Siren"- Sarah Halzack, Washington Post- February 25, 2013)

Collaborators on the project

Israel’s leading opera singers: Karin Shifrin, Anastasia Klevan, Eitan Abraham Drori, Guy Peleg Pelc, and the American Bass-Baritone Enrico Lagasca.


Idan Cohen Dance Company Dancers: Naama Tamir, Tomer Golan, Tomer Giat, Coral Friedman, Gal Calic, Dana Zeharia, and Noa Shiloh.

The Israel Lottery Council for the Arts.

Asylum Arts, a global network for Jewish Culture.

Amherst College Theater and Dance Department, MA, USA.

Amherst College Faculty Research Award Program, MA, USA.

The Jewish Federation & Family Services, Orange County, CA, USA.

Chad Michael Hall, MULTIPLEX DANCE and UC Irvine, CA, USA.

UCI Claire Trevor School of the Arts, Lisa Naugle, UC Irvine, CA, USA.

ArtPower at  the University of California, San Diego, CA, USA.

The Harold Grinspoon Foundation (HGF), MA, USA.

The production is supported by the Israeli Consulate, NYC, USA and The Israel Ministry of Culture and Sport. 

Other collaborators: The Israeli Choreographers Association, ‘Dance at the Prairie' Residency, ‘Intima-dance’ Festival, ‘Tmuna’ Theater, ’Between Heaven and Earth’ Dance Festival, and The Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance.

__________________________________________________________________________


*) Credits:

I capuleti e i Montecchi:

Members of Amherst Symphony Orchestra conducted by Mark Lane Swanson.

Costumes and Set design by Suzanne Palmer Dougan.

Lighting design by Kathy Couch.

Rehearsal Directors by Melannie Berson, Noa Shiloh.

Gender Bender: Lighting Designer : Netta Koren. Music Advisor: Eyal Bromberg. Vocal work: Offir Dagan. Stage Design: Shimon Castiel, Zohar Shoef. Graphic Designer & Artwork: Galit Marciano, Adi Shafran. Costume Design& Soundtrack Editor: Idan Cohen. Producer: Hadas Antman.

 Video: Idan Hellmann, Arkady Ostrovsky. video editing: Katianna Nardone- Amherst College '19. Photos: Luis Curiel, Tamar Lamm, Hamutal wachtel. 

*) Special Thanks: Wendy Woodson, Roger C. Holden 1919 Professor of Theater and Dance at Amherst College (and the Five College Dance Department) for her huge support. Professor Netta Pulvermacher, Dr. Vered Aviv, head of the graduate program, The Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance. Dr. Sari Elron, Dr. Ido Ariel head of the Vocal Department.

Tal Yachas/ Yair Vardi; Nava Frenkel& Ronen Itzhaki, Israel. 

Netta Blumenthal and the Pais Center, Qiryat Sharet-Holon, Eyal Benin, Dalit Haramati and ‘Ironi Alef School of the Arts, Tel Aviv. Oshri Segev for his support and advice along the way, Ophir Lotan for her styling advice. Special thanks to Maestro Omer Meir Wellber.

story:
The What

A production of a Shakespeare masterpiece in protest of HB2.  We would be the only company doing this in North Carolina.  The theatre community needs to speak out, as we are also affected by this ill-conceived law.  This production will open June 16th, 2016 at the former Sputnik Club.

The Play

The play centers on the hypocrisy of strict religious belief, and “the dichotomy between corruption and purity”.  This is a play about the morality of the few governing the lives of many.

This Version

We have adapted the script and changed the location to North Carolina in an unspecified future-sadly could only be a few years away.  In the original Angelo (an overly zealous judge) re-establishes an ancient sex crime law, anyone in violation will be put to death.  Our version will keep much of the original, but have the law target the LGBT community.  Claudio who in the original is arrested for sex with “Juliet”, will now be arrested for sex with a man “Julian”.  Isabella appeals to Angelo to spare her brother, only to fall victim to Angelo’s lust and eventual attempted sexual assault.  When she threatens to out him, he tells her no one will believe her because he is a man of high moral authority. The parallels in light of lawmakers recently being arrested for sexual misconduct are too chilling.  The rest of the play concerns the owner and patrons of a brothel which is being threatened with closure.  In our version it will be an LGBT club run by a drag MC called in the play “Mistress Over-done”.

story:
What is this epic theater piece with the weird title?

WHO WE ARE: Sara Farrington & Reid Farrington are a wife and husband team collaborating together for the first time. Sara  is a playwright, Reid is a director and new media artist. Working together on CasablancaBox, Sara and Reid have created a perfect fusion of "old media" and "new media."

WHAT IT IS: CasablancaBox is a contemporary theater piece, an elegant dance of light, shadow, story and cinema. The movie serves as the spine from which a myriad of stories branch off. Employing simple wooden canvas flats and a large cast, CasablancaBox is a full film set onstage. Inspired by a roving camera style, the piece captures everyone's story, from the most famous players to the hundreds of real-life European refugees who peopled the “atmosphere” of Rick’s Café Americain.  

HOW WE DO IT: With new media technology, gorgeous manipulation of the film itself, 17 actors and a killer script. CasablancaBox dives into things like the psychology of Peter Lorre's inescapable morphine addiction, of Bogart's violent 3rd wife Mayo Methot, the real life German actors who escaped death at the hands of the Nazis only to be typecast as a Nazi in Hollywood, of stagehands with disturbing pasts, of Bergman's love affair with Roberto Rossellini, of Paul Henreid's outrageous contractual demands and his own escape from Austria, of the team of screenwriters' struggles to write that ending. Simmering just beneath the surface of CasablancaBox is the question on everyone's mind: How will this war (and movie) end? The narratives are endless, funny and moving, always returning to the Casablanca. Whether you love the Casablanca, haven't seen it in years or haven't seen it ever, CasablancaBox is for you. You'll get it.

WHY SHOULD I DONATE?: This is a huge moment for Sara and Reid and this project deserves to be fully realized. They are thrilled to be bringing this project to life, one they have worked on for many years, and with such an incredible team of performers and collaborators. It is particularly at this moment in history, when the arts can help us to move forward, rather than backward.

Your tax-deductible donation helps our artistic team tell this story.

The impact your donation makes...

Reid, Sara and HERE Arts Center firmly believe that actors deserve a living wage. The impact this has on an ensemble is infinite: talent improves, morale is lifted, the theater community as a whole begins to demand higher standards and, most importantly, the team feels valued.

We are producing CasablancaBox on an Equity Transition Code. This means that not only are the actors getting a weekly paycheck, a percentage will go toward their health insurance. This is why we are raising this $10,000. If we raise this amount, these amazing performers can work fewer hours at their “survival jobs.” When an artist is no longer painfully split between art and survival, the art is the thing and CasablancaBox will become transcendent.

So this is where YOU come in.

What you are saying when you donate $20, $50, $100, $1000 is “I value the artist.” And in extraordinary, chaotic and uncertain times like these, the world needs that message more than ever.

In return, we will relay your message of support out into the internet with a social media shout out, a personal thank you, a rehearsal visit where you will get a sneak peek into our exciting process and, best of all, you will get a chance to "sponsor" a movie star. Check out our perks section for details and donation levels!

For images, video, press and publications for Reid: www.reidfarrington.com and for Sara www.ladyfarrington.com

story:
Summary

We are Thin Space Productions, and we need YOUR help to produce our first, fully-produced, feature length play!

From over 1000 SUBMISSIONS, our full-length play, "Die For Me," was accepted into the NYC Fringe Festival. This is the largest festival for new works in NYC, and one of the largest in the world.

The play is a two-act drama. Somewhat experimental in nature, it weaves together the story of a high-school romance with themes from Shakespeare's "As You Like It," and T.S. Eliot's "The Waste Land."

What is "Thin Space?"

Thin Space Productions is a new and developing theater company, based in Manhattan, NYC. We focus on the creation of new work that is both powerful and imaginative.
Thin Space Productions has already had a string of successes throughout the Manhattan area.
You may have caught our short play, "The List"--which was featured at the Midtown Short Play Festival.
Or you may have seen our one act, "The Tea Party"---which received not only a full performance at the Manhattan Repertory Theater, but ALSO a public reading at Dixon Place in East Village.

Our Ultimate goal is the creation of a nonequity theater group in Manhattan that creates theater that is exciting, memorable, and a place for budding actors to develop their craft.

Cost Breakdown

Funding a play is expensive!
Fringe NYC is one of the easier ways to present a full play in Manhattan, but it still runs a high cost. That's where you come in.
Here's our break down:

$700--Fringe Fees. This amount covers the ENTIRE cost of performance space for 5 performances, as well as a full-length tech rehearsal, AND it pays for the advertising done by Fringe Festival NYC.

$100-Event Manager Fees. This pays for the Event Manager, who is required by Fringe to properly run the event for all 5 nights of performances.

$200-Actors! We at Thin Space Productions believe very firmly in paying actors for their work, and would like to see more theater companies do the same. We are a nonunion company, but we are still planning to allocate funds towards the payment of actors.

$200-Technical requirements. A show can run high costs for technical requirements, and ours is no exception! These funds will go towards paying a board operator, as well as other technical issues that we may face as we construct our show.

$100-Rehearsal Spaces. Since this will be a small cast show, we will be able to cut back on rehearsal space costs, but that doesn't mean there won't be fees. These funds will go towards securing rehearsal spaces as needed.

$200-PR. Publicity is one of the largest aspects of the Fringe. We want to be able to get the word out, and we want to do it as well as we possibly can. That means spending money on good publicity, and getting the word out!

The Final Product?

With all of these costs in mind, we hope to fully produce a quality, full-length work for Fringe Festival NYC.

And we don't plan on stopping there--
Thin Space Productions is constantly hoping to develop new and exciting theatrical work. We have several other projects in various stages of development, and the more support we get, the more projects we are able to bring to fruition.

How Else Can You Help?

Even if you can't contribute money, you can still help us! Follow us at our Facebook page--"Thin Space Productions," for updates and info on our development!

And please, be sure to spread the word!

Word of mouth is one of the most valuable gifts you can give us, and we are deeply grateful for any amount of support that you feel inclined to give.

Thank you, and I hope to see you at the Fringe!
-Ethan Ness
Thin Space Productions

story:
Indiegogo campaign for NY-based Dance Cat-alyst Company was accepted into the Detroit Dance City Festival August 25-27 2016.

Artistic Director, Cat Manturuk, native of Detroit Michigan is grateful for the success  last 2 years 2014-15 tours.   Dance Cat-alyst was able network with many other artists coming together to help keep Detroit alive after its devastating bankruptcy from 2013.  We are happy to announce we have been accepted in for 2016 making a 3rd year in a row.  We could not have done it without your help!!! Thank you, Thank you, Thank you.  

Please help keep the momentum swinging forward as Detroit  is improving day by day  but still has a way to go! ANY HELP IS GREATLY APPRECIATED!!! 

To get an idea as to what we've done thus far.... Please take a moment to see footage of last years scenes in Detroit Dance Cat-alyst doing summer stage outreach about dance and fitness as well as teaching master class to students!

 Dance Cat-alyst needs help raising funds for dancer travel, dancer pay, per diem,  and rehearsal space.   Once again, we appreciate any help to get Dance Cat-alyst from NYC to Detroit, Michigan celebrating and educating audiences about the importance to keep moving forward for this wondrous city.

What We Need & What You Get:

3 DAY FESTIVAL (July 29th-Aug. 1st 2016)

TRAVEL:  dancers airplane flight approxiamately $400= $1600

PER DIEM: 4 days for 4 dancers at $35 per day = $560

PERFORMANCE PAY: $300 for 4 dancers = $1200

REHEARSAL SPACE:  $18.00 per hour space minimum of 21 hours rehearsal $378

2 queen suite for $131 per night for 2 nights=$262

TOTAL COST FOR TOUR:  $4,000.00

HELP THE STRUGGLING CITY OF DETROIT, MICHIGAN GET BACK ON ITS FEET!  BROOKLYN BASED DANCE CAT-ALYST YEARNS TO UNITE AGAIN WITH OTHER EMERGING ARTISTS AT THE DETROIT DANCE CITY FESTIVAL 2015. THE FESTIVAL HELPS BRING PEOPLE TOGETHER AND LIFE/CULTURE INTO THE CITY. BY CONTRIBUTING TO DANCE CAT-ALYST YOU ARE HELPING SUPPORT THE ART OF JAZZ, MODERN AND HIP HOP DANCE AND REBUILDING A GREAT AMERICAN CITY. 

ANY HELP GREATLY APPRECIATED!  PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!  GET UP and GET MOVIN! 

Best, Cat Manturuk

Please take a moment to see footage of last years scenes in Detroit Dance Cat-alyst doing summer stage outreach about dance and fitness as well as teaching master class to students! Dance Cat-alyst needs help raising funds for dancer travel, dancer pay, per diem,  and rehearsal space.   Once again, we appreciate any help to get Dance Cat-alyst from NYC to Detroit, Michigan celebrating and educating audiences about the importance to keep moving forward for this wondrous city.What We Need & What You Get:3 DAY FESTIVAL (July 29th-Aug. 1st 2016)TRAVEL:  dancers airplane flight approxiamately $400= $1600PER DIEM: 4 days for 4 dancers at $35 per day = $560PERFORMANCE PAY: $300 for 4 dancers = $1200REHEARSAL SPACE:  $18.00 per hour space minimum of 21 hours rehearsal $3782 queen suite for $131 per night for 2 nights=$262TOTAL COST FOR TOUR:  $4,000.00HELP THE STRUGGLING CITY OF DETROIT, MICHIGAN GET BACK ON ITS FEET!  BROOKLYN BASED DANCE CAT-ALYST YEARNS TO UNITE AGAIN WITH OTHER EMERGING ARTISTS AT THE DETROIT DANCE CITY FESTIVAL 2015. THE FESTIVAL HELPS BRING PEOPLE TOGETHER AND LIFE/CULTURE INTO THE CITY. BY CONTRIBUTING TO DANCE CAT-ALYST YOU ARE HELPING SUPPORT THE ART OF JAZZ, MODERN AND HIP HOP DANCE AND REBUILDING A GREAT AMERICAN CITY. ANY HELP GREATLY APPRECIATED!  PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!  GET UP and GET MOVIN! Best, Cat Manturuk

story:
The Three Yells

Veronica Lee-Baik founded The Three Yells Performance Company to explore and translate modern dance through activism, performances, and education. Originally from Singapore, Lee-Baik is a visual artist whose medium of choice is the body. She collaborates with cross disciplinary artists to install landscapes to engage audiences in visceral experiences that invite new perspectives on important social/civic issues. Lee-Baik’s diverse training has allowed her to have a unique voice integrating Asian aesthetics with western styles.


The Project

The Project Her Name Is Isaac is a multidisciplinary dance work that draws attention to the treatment of women through a distinctly Asian lens. A current recipient of the Artist Trust GAP and Seattle Office of Arts & Culture smART Ventures grant, Artistic Director/choreographer of The Three Yells Veronica Lee-Baik began this project in April 2015 and developed it further during Cornish Playhouse's Arts Incubator Residency with the collaborative genius of media artist Robert Campbell, lighting designer Meg Fox, and Fritz Rodriquez and Brendan Hogan for original music composition. 

As a visual artist whose medium of choice is the body, Lee-Baik collaborates with artists from different disciplines to engage audiences viscerally. Dance, music and media co-exist in a live-activated stage space where dancers will have the autonomy to control sound and light cues through their movement. Lee-Baik’s distinct style reflects ballet and modern dance styles through the prism of Asian aesthetics and traditions. Her unique movement vocabulary exhibits strong imagery and hyper-controlled motion contrasted with abandoned athleticism.Her Name Is Isaac boldly presents a modern-day warrior dance that will resonate beyond the theatre to spur conversation around gender and equity.

Her Name Is Isaac premieres February 11 & 12, 2016 at 8pm       Cornish Playhouse At Seattle Center - 201 Mercer St, Seattle, Washington 98109

Project Creator/Choreography: Veronica Lee-Baik                                                       Media Artist: Robert Campbell                                                                                          Lighting Designer: Meg Fox                                                                                                    Sound Composers: Brendan Hogan + Fritz Rodriguez                                        Performers: Amy Ross, Corina Dalzell, Dakota Crist, Emily Durand, Hayley Shannon, Rebecca Smith & Sruti Desai


What We Need 

Welcome to our Indiegogo fundraising campaign where we are trying to raise $6,500 to fund our latest project, Her Name Is Isaac.
The Three Yells is mostly funded by the artists themselves and by contributions from supporters like you. Your donation enables me to give the tremendously deserving artists who contribute to my work, compensation for their hard work and dedication. Your generous contribution will also help pay for: costumes, set materials, media equipment rental and rehearsal space rental.
It is never a fun or easy task asking people for money BUT in order to be making art, let alone good art, we need your help. The truth about art is that it takes friends, family and community to bring it to fruition.
Any amount will help us tremendously. Your generosity is greatly appreciated! I know we can do this together!
Your support will GIVE The Three Yells CONTINUITY.

Risks & Challenges

With every project comes risks and challenges but The Three Yells will always be looking forward to its future, continually celebrating its growth, and planning for new opportunities. I will continue to explore the infinite possibilities of dance in relation to other mediums, and to familiarize the observer with the unfamiliar.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot back this campaign financially, you can still make a huge impact!!!
  • talk about The Three Yells with your friends and family 
  • share the news on your Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and help us get the word out all over the world
  • Like and follow The Three Yells on Facebook and Instagram
  • Join us for The Three Yells performances and events
  • Donate your time and/or services

The more this campaign gets shared, the better chance we have of crushing this goal and pressing forward full steam with our current and future projects!
We have 32 days from Tuesday, January 12th to raise at least $6,500 USD.

Let's do this!!!

For more info about The Three Yells, please visit: http://www.thethreeyells.com

story:
(Version en français plus bas) 

WHO ARE WE?

LA TRESSE is a Montreal-based dance collective established by Geneviève Boulet, Erin O’Loughlin, and Laura Toma. We believe in a collective spirit where all elements of the creation process are a shared endeavour. Driven by our fantasies and inspired by pop culture, we create worlds of contrast where the audience is transported to places both familiar and unknown. We are intuitive, lighthearted, and devoted to the pursuit of pleasure. 

After our serendipitous meeting in Tel Aviv in 2012, Geneviève (Montreal), Erin (Calgary) and Laura (Ottawa), reunited in Montreal and formed the collective LA TRESSE in 2014. Since then, we have created two works, performed extensively, received public funding, and been supported by several creative residency programs. Our first work, “Beauté Brute” was shown at Montreal festivals: Zone Homa, Vue Sur La Relève, and OFFTA, in Toronto for the Dance Matters Series, and in Québec City at La Rotonde. Our second piece, “Volume II” was presented at Festival Quartiers Danses in 2016 and won the Audience Choice Award (“Prix Coup de Coeur du Public”). 

WHAT IS THE PROJECT?

The piece, “A Walkabout”, will be presented by the 2017 Festival Quartiers Danses. Part of the festival’s mandate is to make contemporary dance more accessible to the people of Montreal by offering performances at public spaces throughout the city, free of charge.  Performing in outdoor public spaces will give greater visibility to our work and help us create a dialogue with new audiences. 

To date, we have created work uniquely on ourselves. This project will be the first time we invite additional artists to perform with us as a larger ensemble. Dancers from Tel Aviv, New York, and Los Angeles are flying to Montreal to join us in the creation and performances of “A Walkabout”. We first worked with Shahar Sarit Sharashove, Lindsey Mattheis, and A.J. Parr during the Springboard Danse Montreal program this June where we were invited choreographers. As a result of this process we established a strong artistic connection with these dancers and a desire to continue the collaboration.

This project includes: one week of creation for Geneviève, Erin, and Laura; one additional week of intensive rehearsals for all 6 cast members; 3 outdoor public performances.

Thursday, September 7th, 12:30pm – Place des Festivals 

Tuesday, September 12th, 5pm – Place Émilie Gamelin

Wednesday, September 13th, 5pm – Place Émilie Gamelin

In this new piece focused on orchestrating and encompassing a vast outdoor space, LA TRESSE Collective will continue to explore a feminine force through uninhibited physicality. Employing music and references from both pop culture and antiquity, the collective endeavours to transport the audience to places both familiar and unknown. “A Walkabout” will bring a continuation and evolution of the characters developed in LA TRESSE’s prior works “Beauté Brute” and “Volume II”.

WHY ARE WE FUNDRAISING? 

Fundraising Goal: $4000

We are raising money to cover the artist fees associated with this project. It is important to us to adequately compensate our collaborators for their artistic contributions. 

In the event that we exceed our $4000 goal, the Collective will be able to pay themselves for the preparation and rehearsals leading up to this process. It will also contribute to the cost of costumes and research materials. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP?

Every dollar helps and will contribute to the success of this project. 

We recognize that there are so many wonderful artists struggling to fund their own projects, so a simple share of this campaign would be more than appreciated. 

Thank you for your support!

//

QUI SOMMES NOUS?

LA TRESSE est un collectif de Montréal, composé de Geneviève Boulet, Erin O’Loughlin, et Laura Toma. Nous croyons dans un esprit de collaboration où tout les éléments du processus créatif sont une expérience partagée. Entraînées par nos fantasmes et inspirées par la culture pop, nous créons des univers contrastants où le spectateur voyage entre ses références et l'inconnu. Nous sommes intuitives et dévouées à la poursuite du plaisir sans jamais se prendre trop au sérieux. 

Suite à leur rencontre à Tel-Aviv en 2012, Geneviève Boulet (Montréal), Erin O’Loughlin (Calgary) et Laura Toma (Ottawa) se sont réunies à Montréal pour former le collectif LA TRESSE. En trois années seulement, le Collectif connait un franc succès. Elles ont créé deux oeuvres qui ont été présentées plusieurs fois pour lesquelles elles ont reçu des bourses ainsi qu'une multitudes de résidences de création. Leur première pièce Beauté Brute a été présentée à Zone Homa, Vue Sur La Relève, OFFTA (Montréal), Dance Matters (Toronto) et à La Rotonde (Quebec ). Leur deuxième trio Volume II,a remporté le prix “Prix Coup de Coeur du Public”  lors de sa première au 2016 Festival Quartiers Danses.

DESCRIPTION DU PROJET

Notre nouvelle pièce,  “A Walkabout”, sera présentée dans le cadre du Festival Quartiers Danses en septembre 2017. Le mandat du festival est en grande partie de rendre la danse contemporaine plus accessible aux citoyens en offrant des performances in-situ gratuites dans différents lieux de la ville. Ce sera une belle occasion pour nous de présenter notre travail à un public beaucoup plus large. 

À ce jour, nous avons chorégraphié uniquement sur nous-même. Dans ce projet, nous souhaitons intégrer des nouveaux danseurs de sorte à passé d'un trio à une plus grande forme. Des artistes de Tel Aviv, New York et Los Angeles seront à Montreal pour participer au nouveau processus. Nous avons d'abord rencontré Shahar Sarit Sharashove, Lindsey Mattheis, and A.J. Parr durant le stage de Springboard Danse Montréal où nous avons été chorégraphes invités. Ce fut une rencontre riche et inspirante et nous avons très hâte de continuer notre collaboration avec elles.

Pour la réalisation de ce projet, nous allons répéter une semaine toutes les trois, suivi d’une semaine intensive à 6 et de 3 représentations.

jeudi le 7 septembre, 12h30, Place des Festivals 

mardi le 12 septembre, 17h, Place Émilie Gamelin

mercredi le 13 septembre, 17h, Place Émilie Gamelin

Dans cette nouvelle chorégraphie in-situ,  nous continuerons à explorer la force de la féminité à travers des corps libérés et fougueux. Ce sera la suite de notre univers unique où la musique et la culture pop cohabitent avec des références aux archétypes de l'antiquité. Nous souhaitons faire osciller le spectateur entre terrains connus et perte de repères. “A Walkabout” sera la continuité et l’évolution des personnages développés dans nos deux premières pièces “Beauté Brute” et “Volume II”. 

OBJECTIF 

Montant Visé: $4000

Nous amassons des fonds pour pouvoir assurer le cachet des artistes. Il est primordiale pour nous de pouvoir rémunérer adéquatement tout nos collaborateurs.

Si nous dépassons notre but de 4000$, nous serons en mesure de nous rémunérer pour les heures de répétitions fait en amont ainsi que de payer pour des nouveaux costumes et des matériaux servants à la recherche.

COMMENT AIDER? 

Chaque dons est d'une grande valeur et contribue directement au succès de notre projet

Nous sommes conscientes que plusieurs artistes talentueux vivent les mêmes réalités que nous alors un simple partage de notre campagne est grandement apprécié. 

Merci pour votre support!

story:
Short Summary

"What was dark so long had felt like winter, finally there's sun, and so I sing that I feel so much spring." - From A New Brain 
Sixteen years ago while painting a deck, MTM founder and executive director listened to a cassette tape of A NEW BRAIN and fell in love, both with the show and the idea of all musical theatre could be. 
Now, as MTM celebrates its tenth anniversary of presenting weird, unknown musicals, we're asking for your help.  
For ten years, we've believed that musical theatre is only beginning and have taken risks to bring "the weird stuff" to Madison.  Without us, you may not have gotten a chance to see it.  
For ten years, we've also compensated every artist, including actors, for our mainstage shows. 
Help us culminate a decade of weird and wonderful with a gift to help A NEW BRAIN spring to life. 

Your benefits

As with past MTM fundraisers, we've gotten creative.  A NEW BRAIN features a variety of wacky props, stories, and characters.  In exchange for your donation, we'll publicly dedicate one of them to you on Facebook with a quote from the show.  
Example: The plate of ziti in A NEW BRAIN is dedicated to [YOU].  "Plus there's ziti, with a sauce that's meaty.  It's fun!"
