story:
one hour of mind-bending head-scratching
meta-meta-quasi-romanti-tragi-dramedy

Question the characters.
Question the actors.
Question yourself.

Penny is Penny.
But Richard is William.
And you are just a member of the audience.

Or are you?
Just how impenetrable is the fourth wall?

 
Personal Space Theatrics and rogerandtom

THE COMPANY
Personal Space Theatrics is a non-profit, New York-based company that's been producing theater since 2001. PST believes that the invisible divide between performers and audience members is detrimental. Theatre isn’t a passive experience, like watching a movie. Theatre is an all-inclusive event, where the audience is just as important as the folks putting on the play. Actors aren’t reciting lines into a void; rather, they are touching the minds and hearts of a living entity that experiences the story through them.

THE SHOW
Julien Schwab’s rogerandtom was first produced by Personal Space Theatrics in 2003, as the company’s inaugural production. Since then, the show has been produced in Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Boston, and most recently, Edinburgh, Scotland. Director Nicholas Cotz has worked with Schwab on many versions of the show, helping him polish the script and preparing it for its return to NYC.

Now, PST is bringing rogerandtom back to New York, to the Dorothy B. Williams Theatre at HERE, as part of HERE's Curated Rental Program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support. The opportunity is amazing, as HERE is one of the top performance spaces in all of NYC.

This is the chance rogerandtom needs and deserves. The chance to be seen and recognized by the New York theater community as an important new addition to the cultural conversation.  And it is the opportunity Schwab deserves as one of America's brightest young playwrights.

What We Need & What You Get
We are looking to use this campaign to raise the money we need to pay our (subsidized!) rent at HERE.  HERE is offering us their spectacular space at a truly discounted rate, but that doesn't mean it's free!

$10,000 is what it will take for rogerandtom to open in SoHo this March.
 
Plus, for your generous donation, not only will you be able to see a great show, you'll also be able to write off the expense come tax time.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you just can't help at this time, we completely understand. We're working artists as well! But that doesn't mean you can't help us spread the word. Like our Facebook Page, follow us on Twitter, and tell your friends to support our show.

If you’d like to get involved and volunteer your time, please get in touch with PST at info@personalspacetheatrics.org.

Thank you so much.

The R&Team
 
P.S. All Perks will be available for Pick Up at the door to the theater. Just tell the House Manager that you're a VIP Donor and there'll be a package waiting for you!!

Question the characters.Question the actors.Question yourself.
Penny is Penny.But Richard is William.And you are just a member of the audience.
Or are you?Just how impenetrable is the fourth wall?

 

Personal Space Theatrics and rogerandtomTHE COMPANYPersonal Space Theatrics is a non-profit, New York-based company that's been producing theater since 2001. PST believes that the invisible divide between performers and audience members is detrimental. Theatre isn’t a passive experience, like watching a movie. Theatre is an all-inclusive event, where the audience is just as important as the folks putting on the play. Actors aren’t reciting lines into a void; rather, they are touching the minds and hearts of a living entity that experiences the story through them.THE SHOWJulien Schwab’s rogerandtom was first produced by Personal Space Theatrics in 2003, as the company’s inaugural production. Since then, the show has been produced in Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Boston, and most recently, Edinburgh, Scotland. Director Nicholas Cotz has worked with Schwab on many versions of the show, helping him polish the script and preparing it for its return to NYC.Now, PST is bringing rogerandtom back to New York, to the Dorothy B. Williams Theatre at HERE, as part of HERE's Curated Rental Program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support. The opportunity is amazing, as HERE is one of the top performance spaces in all of NYC.This is the chance rogerandtom needs and deserves. The chance to be seen and recognized by the New York theater community as an important new addition to the cultural conversation.  And it is the opportunity Schwab deserves as one of America's brightest young playwrights.What We Need & What You GetWe are looking to use this campaign to raise the money we need to pay our (subsidized!) rent at HERE.  HERE is offering us their spectacular space at a truly discounted rate, but that doesn't mean it's free! $10,000 is what it will take for rogerandtom to open in SoHo this March.
 
Plus, for your generous donation, not only will you be able to see a great show, you'll also be able to write off the expense come tax time.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you just can't help at this time, we completely understand. We're working artists as well! But that doesn't mean you can't help us spread the word. Like our Facebook Page, follow us on Twitter, and tell your friends to support our show.If you’d like to get involved and volunteer your time, please get in touch with PST at info@personalspacetheatrics.org.Thank you so much.The R&Team
 
P.S. All Perks will be available for Pick Up at the door to the theater. Just tell the House Manager that you're a VIP Donor and there'll be a package waiting for you!!

story:
**please note all donations go through our season sponsor's paypal account AAA Atlas Roofing. All the funds come directly to the Anandam Dancetheatre....just incase you are wondering as you go through the donation process.****

Short Story

Anandam needs your help to make our performing space better!

Anandam Dancetheatre is a contemporary performance company based in Toronto, Canada. We create and collaborate on diverse works with large ensembles that explore ideas of site specific ness and alternative audience/ performer relationships. 

Our rehearsal home is in a shared facility called Collective Space.  This incredible venue allows the company to have both a regular rehearsal space and a place to present performances.  

Our campaign is to raise funds to purchase chairs and lights for our space.  We have a number of upcoming performances both by the company and from other members of the Toronto dance community and we want to acquire chairs, so our audiences have a place to sit and lighting equipment to illuminate our performers.

We are building a cultural space dedicated to community collaboration, shared resources and alternative economic models of sustainability. By supporting this campaign you are not only supporting the company but strengthening the resources of the entire dance community. 

For more information on the company see www.anandam.ca

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to purchase 70 folding chairs and a small inventory of adaptable lighting equipment for our space. It will cost 3000 cdn dollars.

Supporters of our campaign can receive unique perks that range from our eternal gratitude, donor recognition on our website, your name on a single chair or rows of chairs, auditorium naming privilages,  tickets to performances and events of the company, charitable tax receipts,  and a private performance for one lucky donor!

If we do not meet our goal we will use whatever funds we raise towards these purchases! We really hope we can achieve it with your help. If we raise more than needed we will enhance our lighting equipment accordingly!

The Impact

Your support is helping Anandam evolve by adding resources that allows us to animate the space with consistent performance activities. This lets us  engage with our audiences regularly in an intimate and alternative setting.

This campaign represents ideas of micro investing. A small amount of funds will create a large network of opportunity, cultural development and employment through future company activities in our space. We just need chairs and lights to get us started.

Other Ways You Can Help

From our past fundraising activity we know every little bit helps, even the smallest amount!

If you cannot donate financially to our campaign please help spread the word through sharing on indigogo, facebook, twitter, word of mouth….help us get the information out there!

story:
_____________________________________________________________________

Text in English

Texte en Français

Texto en Castellano

_____________________________________________________________________

English

“Entre deux eaux”

Three good friends, experienced circus artist, for not saying old, share some of their touring experiences, their funny stories, their doubts, their dreams, their regrets. Briefly, three friends tell their life. What is it about to be a circus artist? What’s it to have reached the 30’s, that your body wants to calm down, but your spirit and creativity are more active than ever? The world of “entre deux eaux” is exactly that moment where the acrobat can succeed or fail; where the body asks him, for how long can you do this? When he asks himself if he wants to stay nomad or become sedentary.

In 2013, the Canadian council for the arts believed in this theme and awarded us a grant to do a research and creation process. Investigate how to mix our stories with circus disciplines. How to bring theater inside a circus act. Now we need the help of all of you to bring this nice research into a real show. Our goal, to present a first run of our creation “Entre deux eaux” the 21th of May at the renowned Montreal theater “Monument National”.


The Company

Cie. De la Barbotte is a Canadian circus collective with international flavors. Is the encounter of Philippe Dreyfuss from Switzerland, Andy Giroux from Québec and Gonzalo Coloma from Peru. The three of them, experienced circus artists, have been travelling the world with some of the most famous circus companies around and with their own separated shows.


Why funding it?

With the money the government of Canada gave us, we could do 4 months of research and creation. We got to develop new acts that come in closely to the theme of the show. Worked with Véronique Côté, a theater director, who helped us a lot with the texts and the structure of the acts. And worked with Fredéric Barrette as co-director and acrobatic coach.

Now we have reached the important part of presenting it to an audience. With this, a lot of new expenses arrive. Re-hiring our co-director, creating costumes, the scenography, and some others production costs that include microphones and a projector. Plus paying the technicians that will help us during the show.

_____________________________________________________________________

Français

“Entre deux eaux”

Trois bon amis, artistes de cirque d’expérience, pour ne pas dire “vieux”, partage leurs expériences de tournée, leurs histoires drôles, leurs questionnements, leurs rêves, leurs regrets. Trois amis racontent leurs vies avec le cirque. Qu’est ce que c’est d’être un artiste de cirque? Qu’est ce que ça fait d’avoir atteint la trentaine? Quand le corps veut plus de calme, mais que l’esprit et la créativité sont plus présentes que jamais? Le monde d’”Entre deux eaux” est exactement ce moment précis quand l’acrobate peut soit réussir, soit rater; quand le corps demande: pendant combien de temps vas-tu encore faire ça? Quand l’acrobate se demande si il veut encore vivre comme un nomade ou devenir sédentaire?

En 2013, le Conseil des arts du Canada a cru en notre projet et nous a récompensé d’une  bourse  pour  faire  de  la  recherche  et  création.   Pour   chercher  comment mélanger nos histoires avec les disciplines de cirque.

Maintenant,  nous  avons  besoin  de  vous  tous  pour  amener  cette  intéressante recherche vers un spectacle réel. Notre objectif  est de présenter  pour  la première fois notre création “Entre deux eaux” le 21 mai au Monument National, à Montréal.


La Compagnie

Cie. De la Barbotte est un collectif de cirque Canadien à saveur international. C’est l’initiative de Philippe Dreyfuss de Suisse, Andy Giroux du Canada et Gonzalo Coloma du Pérou. Ce sont trois artistes d’expérience qui ont parcouru le monde avec quelques unes des plus fameuses compagnies de cirque du moment, ainsi qu’avec leurs propres projets individuels.


Pourquoi nous financer?

Avec  l’argent de la bourse  du gouvernement du Canada, nous avons pu faire quatre mois de recherche et création. Nous avons pu travailler sur de nouveaux numéros en rapport avec notre thématique.  Nous  avons collaboré avec Véronique Côté, metteur en scène de théâtre,  qui  nous a  aidé  avec les textes  et  la  structure, ainsi qu’avec Frédéric Barrette, co-metteur en scène et coach acrobatique.

Nous avons maintenant atteint le moment important de présenter notre travail au public, ce qui nous amène à de nouvelles dépenses. Payer notre co-metteur en scène, concevoir des costumes, la scénographie, ainsi que d’autre coûts de production qui incluent l’achat de matériel, comme des micros et un projecteur. Nous avons aussi besoin de fonds pour pouvoir rémunérer notre équipe technique.

_____________________________________________________________________

Castellano

“Entre deux eaux”

Tres buenos amigos, artistas de circo experimentados, por no decir viejos, comparten algunas de sus experiencias de gira, sus historias divertidas, sus dudas, sueños, lamentos. Tres amigos cuentan su vida. ¿Qué es ser artista de circo? ¿Qué significa llegar a los 30, que tu cuerpo quiera calmarse pero que tu espíritu y creatividad estén más activos que nunca? El mundo de “entre deux eaux” es ese momento exacto donde el acróbata puede tener éxito o fallar; Cuando su cuerpo le pregunta, ¿hasta cuando podrás hacer esto aún? Cuando él se pregunta a si mismo si quiere seguir siendo nómade o convertirse en sedentario.

En el 2013 el consejo para las artes de Canadá creyó en este tema y nos hizo ganadores de una subvención para empezar un proceso de investigación y creación. Investigar cómo mezclar nuestras historias con las artes del circo, cómo hacer teatro al interior de un número de circo. Ahora necesitamos la ayuda de todos ustedes para convertir esta hermosa creación en un espectáculo de verdad. Nuestra meta, presentar una primera versión de “entre deux eaux” el 21 de mayo en el reconocido teatro “Monument National” en Montreal.


La Compañía

Cie. De la Barbotte es un colectivo de circo canadiense con sabor internacional. Es el encuentro de Philippe Dreyfuss de Suiza, Andy Giroux de Quebec y Gonzalo Coloma de Perú. Los tres, experimentados artistas de circo, han estado viajando por el mundo con las compañías mas famosas del mundo y con sus propios espectáculos antes de juntarse para crear “entre deux eaux”


¿Por qué financiar el proyecto?

Con el dinero que el gobierno canadiense nos dio, pudimos hacer cuatro meses de investigación y creación. Logramos desarrollar nuevos actos que están ligados al trama narrativo del espectáculo. Trabajamos con Véronique Côté, directora de teatro, quien nos ayudó con la escritura de los textos y la estructura de los actos. También trabajamos con Fredéric Barrette como co-director y entrenador acrobático.

Ahora hemos llegado al importante momento de presentar al frente de un público. Con este momento llegan muchos gastos. Contratar de nuevo a nuestro co-director, crear los vestuarios, la escenografía, pagar algunos otros costos de producción como comprar micrófonos y un proyector. Aparte, tenemos que contratar a los técnicos que nos ayudarán durante el espactáculo.

This are pictures of two of the paintings someone can get when funding for $1000. We have 5! Who are the lucky ones?

20x14

14x13

story:
HEROIC

In a world overrun by greed and evil, one man stands between order and complete chaos. Did I say a man? Scratch that. He's more than a man. He is a beacon of hope in a sea of darkness. A life raft floating in an ocean of sorrow. A glimmer of magic in a Scottish loch. What's up with all of these water metaphors? Who knows...The only thing I know is that he is one bad mamajama! His name? Good thing you asked, I might have forgot. His name...is the Mighty Madman!

Join the Mighty Madman in his quest to battle evildoers, figure out what the hell is going on, and snag that perfect piece of lasagna!

What We Need

Heroic is the culmination of my time as a theatre student at the University Of Texas. I have always been fascinated with the fantastical, and no world resonated with me as deeply as the world of superheroes. I always wanted super powers. I wanted to smash things and be indestructible like the Hulk, to control minds like Professor X, and fly through the air like Iron Man. Hell, I still do. Man, that would be awesome!

During my time at UT, I discovered a passion for play writing, and I immediately set out to write a play about a superhero. But not your typical superhero. I wanted this hero to be crude. I wanted him to be violent. But most of all, I wanted him to fit into the world we live in now, not the comic book world of old. With your help, I intend to make that a reality. I already have almost all of the pieces in place that I need to get this production on its feet. A cozy venue, the support of my family, and a great group of actors who can't wait to tell my story. All I need now is the funds to make that happen.

$900-Space Rental Fee
$200-Set Construction/Props
$100-Advertising
$300-Stipend to help pay my amazing actors

The Impact

My goal, other than to entertain, is to keep theatre alive in Austin, and in the rest of the world for that matter. Some people think that live theatre is a dying art form, and I just want to show people that isn't true in the slightest. As long as there are people out there who are passionate about creating dynamic art that has the ability to adapt to our ever-changing world, theatre will live on. The Ancient Greeks prized theatre above all else. It was mandatory for citizens to go, and the plays of the time touched on numerous social issues. That's not necessarily the case today, what with all of the spectacle for spectacle's sake on Broadway, but there are still people out there trying to affect change. I feel I must warn you that I am not one of those people, but I like to think that if I can keep people going to the theatre, then those people get the opportunity to spread their message of change, and that's good enough for me.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone will be able to contribute. I'm a broke actor/playwright myself, so I understand completely. If you can't help us out, then instead tell everyone about this project. Spread the word! Tell every person you know. Every person you've ever met. Hell, tell people you haven't even met yet! I don't know how you're supposed to do that, but I'm confident that you'll find a way. You've always been good to me in the past. Don't let me down now!

story:
Short Summary

Latin Addiction is a dance studio in Christchurch, New Zealand teaching Salsa, Bachata, Samba, Cha Cha, kids hip hop and Zumba. Over the years, their dance teams have accumulated elite awards and championship titles. Now is another opportunity for the ladies shine team to compete at the New Zealand Salsa Dance Championships 2013 and the Sydney Latin Festival 2014.

Most of us are amateurs and have normal day jobs on top of the training commitments. This means that we are turning to our friends and family to help support our journey to not only perform at these elite competitions, but to kick butt at them.

What we need & what you get

We are looking to raise enough money to cover the flights for all of the dancers. We have 6 dancers competing in Auckland at the NZSDC and 8 dancers competing in Sydney at the SLF.

The first trip to Auckland will entail flights ($250), performer's pass ($120), accommodation ($100), plus the dance lessons, costume, nails, hair, make-up, and other travel costs for each of us.

The Sydney trip will include all of that again, but the flights will be $500+, performer's pass $300+ and accommodation $200+.

$1500 will cover the cost of the flights for the team to Auckland, so that is really the minimum we are looking to raise and anything over that will be absolutely amazing and can go towards the Sydney competition.

No matter what we raise, it will be split evenly amongst the entire team. Anything you contribute will go to all of us, so thank you from all of us!

We know we can do amazingly and come home with another elite achievement, but we need our whole team there in order to do that. As a thank you, you will receive one of the "perks" listed to the right based on your contribution amount. These are just small ways for us to show our gratitude.

The Impact

We are all extremely excited and honoured to be able to take part in these competitions. They are truly bucket list items. All of us have had to look at the realities of the financial commitment attached to see if we can be a part of the team, but none of us have been able to say 'no' without denying ourselves of a dream come true.

Your support means the world and we literally would not be able to do it without fundraising efforts and the support of our friends and family.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand completely if you are unable to contribute. Please do pass on the campaign to your friends and family, though, because you never know who had that dream of becoming a dancer when they were young and would like to join us on our journey.

THANK YOU!!!!!!!!!!!!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Latin Addiction is a dance studio in Christchurch, New Zealand teaching Salsa, Bachata, Samba, Cha Cha, kids hip hop and Zumba. Over the years, their dance teams have accumulated elite awards and championship titles. Now is another opportunity for the ladies shine team to compete at the New Zealand Salsa Dance Championships 2013 and the Sydney Latin Festival 2014.
Most of us are amateurs and have normal day jobs on top of the training commitments. This means that we are turning to our friends and family to help support our journey to not only perform at these elite competitions, but to kick butt at them.
What we need & what you get
We are looking to raise enough money to cover the flights for all of the dancers. We have 6 dancers competing in Auckland at the NZSDC and 8 dancers competing in Sydney at the SLF.
The first trip to Auckland will entail flights ($250), performer's pass ($120), accommodation ($100), plus the dance lessons, costume, nails, hair, make-up, and other travel costs for each of us.
The Sydney trip will include all of that again, but the flights will be $500+, performer's pass $300+ and accommodation $200+.
$1500 will cover the cost of the flights for the team to Auckland, so that is really the minimum we are looking to raise and anything over that will be absolutely amazing and can go towards the Sydney competition.
No matter what we raise, it will be split evenly amongst the entire team. Anything you contribute will go to all of us, so thank you from all of us!We know we can do amazingly and come home with another elite achievement, but we need our whole team there in order to do that. As a thank you, you will receive one of the "perks" listed to the right based on your contribution amount. These are just small ways for us to show our gratitude.



The Impact
We are all extremely excited and honoured to be able to take part in these competitions. They are truly bucket list items. All of us have had to look at the realities of the financial commitment attached to see if we can be a part of the team, but none of us have been able to say 'no' without denying ourselves of a dream come true.
Your support means the world and we literally would not be able to do it without fundraising efforts and the support of our friends and family.


Other Ways You Can Help
We understand completely if you are unable to contribute. Please do pass on the campaign to your friends and family, though, because you never know who had that dream of becoming a dancer when they were young and would like to join us on our journey.THANK YOU!!!!!!!!!!!!

story:
Short Summary

History of Our Past Partnership

  • 2 Years Ago You Sent This Teaching Artist Back to Haiti

After the 2010 earthquake ravaged through Haiti, I joined a team of artists and socially conscious people of color to return to Haiti and help the people of Leogane, Haiti process, grieve, celebrate life, and support the re-opening of the adobe clinic that was built just the year before by the collective.  The collective’s manifesto, or written statement declaring their intentions publicly, suggested they were cultivating “genuine people-to-people solidarity among people of African heritage while reinforcing the strength and autonomy of Haitian residents.


  • 2 Years Later I'm Asking You to Send This Artist to Encuentro: Montreal 

A Performance Festival and Academic Conference; the theme this year is Manifesto, Manifests, Manifestations.  

My piece will explore how the collectives' well-intentioned motives and those of other people in the Diaspora go awry.  My performance will strive to produce evidence that will manifest ideas otherwise invisible, hidden, and unspeakable. 


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Flight to Montreal $450 round trip.
  • Dormitory fee: $64 per night x 4nights = $256
  • Taxes and stuff: $44

The Impact

Allowing me to network and meet with other performers to bring you more stage shows/performances.

story:
Broken Pieces the Stage Play Summary

#Broken PiecesTSP is a play that follows three siblings who were abandoned by their mother and left with their grandmother. Now, as adults we journey through their marriages and relationships and witness the emotional handicaps abandonment has brought into their lives. Dexter, 29, is dealing with trust issues between himself and his wife after two miscarriages and they continue to struggle with infertility. Devin, 26, is stuck with childish ways. He is more consumed with video games, partying and his friends than his wife, Tatiana, and their two daughters, Ashiya, 10, and Kennedy, 4. Erin, 19, is a college sophomore with big dreams of being an attorney. She finds out that she and Adam are pregnant and is faced with a very difficult decision that could alter her life forever. Gramz, their grandmother, is trying to keep their family together and uses her faith and words of wisdom to steer them in the best direction she knows.

What Bleu Royalty Needs & What Y O U Get

Bleu Royalty presents #BrokenPiecesTSP Expenses:

$1500 - Charles H. Flower Auditorium Space (723 seat auditorium, lobby, dressing rooms)

$600- Set and Props (paint supplies, couches, tables, chairs, picture frames, hospital beds, medical tools, end tables, artwork, ect.)

$303.74 for Auditorium Insurance

$200- Hair and make-up

$180- Ticket printing (600 tickets)

$304.00 – 5,000 4x6 flyers (churches, local businesses, promo tour, open mics, college campuses, ect)

$500- Concessions (to cover 550+ patrons)

$300- Lobby ambiance (band, table covers, candles, flowers, banners, posters, ect.)

  With expectation to fill at LEAST five hundred and fifty of the seven hundred twenty-three seats in the facility your sponsorship will create a platform for your business that will reach a demographic eager to support local businesses ranging from ages 11 to 80 years old. Your sponsorship allows opportunity for advertisement of your business via social media, our website, #BrokenPiecesTSP play bill, our lobby as well as word of mouth. People support businesses that support the community. We have various packages that include free tickets, advertisement space and many other perks. With our fundraising goal set at $4,000 we would be most grateful if you could sponsor us to help the progression of #BrokenPiecesTSP. It is very attainable and will be accomplished with your help and support.  A portion of our proceeds will go towards purchasing new chairs for the TV Production lab at Charles H. Flowers High School taught by Ms. Tara Jones.


The Impact of Bleu Royalty

             We are intentional about creating a space that is refreshing, relevant and still family friendly. We do this in attempt to rebuild the idea of family, community and to open lines of communication about very difficult topics. Views and lifestyles have never been so different due to the advance of technology, work demands and the lack of positive family oriented exposure. We are changing the face of pop culture not only in our work, but also in our leadership of future generations. Bleu Royalty exemplifies ambition, initiative, innovation, freedom, growth and leadership. We are a brand that is authentic, honest and unafraid to be transparent with our lives. This approach has been extremely effective as we have expanded from 3 team members to 8, 7 cast members to 15, 1 partnership to 6, and our volunteers for community service events continue to grow daily.

      Other Ways You Can Help Bleu Royalty

We are excited about your interest in helping Bleu Royalty be a success with #BrokenPiecesTSP. There are so many other ways you can contribute. Below is a list of our various departments:

Usher (10) - Your job is very, very special for the evening of the show. You will be the first face our guests will see. They will rely on you to find them seats, help them find the restrooms and concession stands as well as help them enjoy their evening out. This position requires professionalism, courtesy, good team ethic and focus. If you are interested in volunteering please email ealcindor@bleuroyalty.com with the subject line "Usher" if you are interested.

Ticket Handler (2) - Your job is just as valuable, but carries a little more responsibility the evening of the show. Our guests will hand you their hard tickets for entry into the auditorium and it is your responsibility to collect and keep safe every ticket stub because we will need to count all attendees at the end of the evening. This position requires professionalism, great attention to detail and speed. If you are interested in volunteering please email ealcindor@bleuroyalty.com

Concessions Attendant (6) - Your job is very easy, yet requires so much energy! For 20 minutes you will be serving almost every guest that we have in attendance with patience, professionalism and accuracy. Some will be impatient, some will be indecisive, but you should always keep in mind that you are a representative for Bleu Royalty. This position requires professionalism, great attention to detail, a passion for serving others and great team ethic. If you are interested in volunteering please email ealcindor@bleuroyalty.com

Stage Crew (8) - Your job is vital to the success of the actual stage play. You are responsible for moving all sets and props on and off of the stage during black outs. You will be spending time with the cast the week of dress rehearsals and learning the order of the show. You will be responsible for setting up and breaking down the set before and after the show. This position requires professionalism, ability to follow directions, excellent memory and team ethic. If you are interested in volunteering please email ealcindor@bleuroyalty.com

Production Assistant (8) - Your job is so important! You create the feel of the entire event. Your tasks include setting up tables, lighting candles, putting up banners, setting up concessions and following the bleuprint of lobby set up. This position requires professionalism, humility, patience, attention to detail and creativity! If you are interested in volunteering for this position please email ealcindor@bleuroyalty.com 


*******WHILE WE ARE GRATEFUL FOR YOUR VOLUNTARY EFFORTS IT IS IMPERATIVE YOU UNDERSTAND THAT AT ALL BLEU ROYALTY EVENTS, AS A VOLUNTEER, YOU ARE A REPRESENTATION OF THIS ORGANIZATION AND BRAND. ALL INTERACTIONS WITH ALL GUESTS ARE A REFLECTION OF THE TEAM AS A WHOLE SO PLEASE COME PREPARED TO WORK WITH AN ATTITUDE OF PROFESSIONALISM, PATIENCE, KINDNESS AND SERVING. WE WANT EVERYONE TO FEEL WELCOME AND COMFORTABLE. ALL VOLUNTEERS MUST WEAR BLEU ROYALTY APPAREL DURING EVENTS*******

story:
Our Company

Butterfly with a Bomb Productions was formed in 2013, when we collaboratively produced an hour long play;  a project which culminated in two well-attended and well-received performances at Glasgow's The Old Hairdressers. Our first piece was made on a budget of £100, which covered props, costumes and the occasional rehearsal space. Venue hire and tech were made possible through sponsorship and favours from friends. As much as possible, we used our own living spaces to rehearse in order to cut down costs. We are now about to begin rehearsals on our second project, but in order that this can be a step up from our previous work, we are in need of some additional funding.


Our Project

Giving up the Ghost is a darkly comic exploration of life and death, seen through the eyes of a psychic medium, an evangelical exorcist, a rock-star zombie and the teenage girl caught between them.

Carrie Clairvoyant is an acclaimed psychic medium, who has never succeeded in raising a genuine spirit. This changes when Dean appears onstage during one of her public shows, claiming to have been reincarnated. When Carrie flees the stage to escape him, Dean takes up residence in her house, leaving Carrie with no option but to call on her estranged exorcist sister, Mary. With all eyes on the crisis at hand, Mary and Carrie are initially oblivious to the attraction Dean holds for Mary's conflicted daughter, Jess. Will Jess leave her beliefs behind for a man who may well be the devil incarnate? Is there any point in Dean carrying on living when he's not truly alive? And will Mary and Carrie ever face up to the events that drove them apart twenty years earlier?

Cast:

Carrie Clairvoyant – Claudette Baker-Park

Mary – Mary-jo Hastie

Dean – Andy Gerard Hally

Jess – Alice Restrick

Written by Anna Blainey, and directed by Anna Blainey and Mary-jo Hastie


What we need:

The key to our work is collaboration - all members of the company take an equal part in the production process, and our roles tend to overlap and merge. The collaborative nature of crowdfunding therefore fits in perfectly with our ethos, and we love the idea of involving as many people as possible in the process and production of our new work. Contributors and interested parties are invited to follow our process through our rehearsal blog here: http://butterflybombco.wordpress.com/about/

We need money for:

Venue hire: Our aim is to show 2 performances in Glasgow and 2 performances in Edinburgh. For this we will need £400.

Lights hire and tech: We have previously been lucky with favours from friends, but even friends need paid sometimes. We'd like to do this with £300.

Set and Costume: We source as much as possible from charity shops and our own junk collections, but we still have to spend a bit on this - and then we have to transport it. It will cost around £200.

Transport: We cut down on rehearsal costs by using our own living space; however this involves a lot of travelling across the city. This costs us collectively £10 a pop, meaning a weekly cost of £20 during 3 months of rehearsals. This plus four trips to Edinburgh for the five of us will come to a total of £500.

Marketing: We have a relationship with a brilliant designer who makes our posters and programmes out of love; however the people who do the advertising tend to want a bit of money for the privilege. For a marketing campaign to attract audiences who don't know and love us already, we're going to need £600.

What We'll Give You:

We want everyone who loves theatre or stories to come and enjoy our work with us at one of our performances, and we're always up for a chat and a drink with you afterwards. If you can help us bring our work up to the highest standard we're able with any amount of pennies we'll be eternally grateful; and for anyone who's just been paid/ come into some pocket money and can give a bit more, we have all sorts of thank you gifts on offer.

If you give us £5, we'll mention your name in our programme under our list of sponsors, with a big public thank you. 

Donations of £10 will entitle you to the above plus one of our show's posters signed by the cast.

£15 will get you all that plus a ticket to any performance of the play.

For £25 you'll receive all the above, plus a personal psychic reading from Carrie Clairvoyant pre or post show.

If you have £50 to invest in us, you'll get your name in our programme, a signed poster and 2 tickets to the play, plus your photo on the front page of a newspaper which will be used as a prop during the show.

For an investment of £100, we'll give you a mention in our programme, a poster and 2 tickets, plus the chance to sit in on one of our rehearsals, observe our process and potentially have a part in the artistic shaping of our production.

We understand if you don't have any cash you can donate to us, but if you like what you've read and you want to help us anyway, please do share our page with all your friends. And if you've got projects of your own, we'll be more than happy to return the favour.

You'll find out more about us here: https://www.facebook.com/butterflybombco?fref=ts 
https://twitter.com/butterflybombco

story:
About Us

Pegasus51 Theatre was founded in Austin, Texas, way, way back in 1998.  The city was a young, pulsating nerve mesh of artists.  It was launched to give the newest voices a place to be heard; in different languages, from different perspectives, with different points-of-view.  From that foundation, Pegasus51 blossomed into a group who valued training young artists and providing them with a laboratory in which they could bridge their differences as humans.

Now, years later, Pegasus51 is in the New York tri-state area and still committed to that same vision.

What We're Doing

Pegasus51 is embarking on an exciting collaboration with several generations of artists to produce None of the Above by Jenny Lyn Bader.  The play will be directed by Maria Aladren and will feature actors Rachel Caplan and Colin Friend.  We are thrilled to be collaborating with the  students of the School of Performing Arts at MCVTS throughout the process and will be incorporating them behind-the-scenes from our rehearsals through the run of the show.  None of the Above will run from October 23-November 1 in NYC.

Here's Where You Come In 

We need the help of generous donors in order to bring this plan to fruition. Your contributions will enable us to fund all aspects of production, including licensing rights, performance space, costumes, set, and promotional materials. Check out our perks on the side of this page, then please consider making a donation to be a part of this collaboration!

Who's Who

Director

Maria Aladren is a professional director originally from Zaragoza, Spain.  Early on, she developed a love for overlapping different forms of human expression in a variety of cultures and time periods.  In the pursuit of such bridges, Maria started a theatre company in Austin, Texas, directing a number of productions ranging from classical works to foreign material to original pieces that put together science and theatre.  In recent years, Maria has taken a hiatus to bring twin baby girls into the world and to develop the conservatory theatre program at the School of Performing Arts-MCVTS, teaching and directing young actors.  At the School of Performing Arts Main Stage program which creates collaborations between professionals and students she has directed pieces such as The Education Project, The Tempest, Comedy of Errors,Neighborhood 3: Requisition of Doom, Midsummer Night's Dream, Anton in Show Business, A Bright Room Called Day, Top Girls andThe Living. Maria trained as a director at the University of Texas-Austin, where she received her MFA, and as a dramaturg at the Theatre School at Washington University in St.  Louis.  She has also trained with Barta Heiner and Jane Lapotaire of the Royal Shakespeare Company and with Gabriel Chame from Clu de Clown in Madrid.

Stage Manager

Rowen Clarke is a junior in MCVTS Theatre, double-majoring in Stage Management and Acting. She has had a passion for Theatre since she was young, but only recently found her niche in Design and Production. For MCVTS, Rowen has staged managed The Education Project, the 2014 Senior Showcase, the 2014 Freshman Showcase, and was the assistant stage manager for the 2013 Senior Showcase. She was also the assistant stage manager for Cake/ATEH's production of Moliere's Learned Ladies and is the assistant stage manager for Cake's production of This Lingering Life in New York City. She appeared as a Spirit in MCVTS’s production of Shakespeare’s The Tempest, and as Willie in Tennessee Williams' This Property is Condemned. Rowen hopes to continue pursuing Stage Management and Acting through college and eventually into her adult life.

Cast: 

Rachel Caplan is a graduate of the Stella Adler Studio as well as a proud Alum of the School of Performing Arts at MCVTS.  She has been privileged to work with a variety of wonderful theatre companies, but is excited to be working with Pegasus51, which reunites her with her very first director, Maria Aladren, and the students of MCVTS. Past roles include Mo in Cadence: Home at the Straz Center with TE'A, Suma in Knight and Brinegar's Doomsurfing, Phile in Michael Milligan's original work Phaeton, the title role in Lily Dale, Jacqueline in Boeing-Boeing, and Lavatch in All's Well that Ends Well. Rachel is also honored to be an Associate Company Member of Theatre East.

Colin Friend studied at the Stella Adler Studio of Acting in NYC. Stand-out roles include Macduff in The Scottish Play, Gratiano in The Merchant of Venice and The Player in Rosencrantz & Guildenstern are Dead. More recently Colin has collaborated with Ensemble Atria on their NYC premiere show Envoy and again this summer in Frame 313. Both were part of the Midtown International Theatre Festival. Envoy was nominated for Best Ensemble in the Midtown International Theatre Awards.

The Play

None of the Above centers on Jamie, an Upper East Side high school senior who has a packed social calendar and an unopened SAT book on her desk.  Enter Clark, the grad student hired by her parents to boost her scores.  The two combine about as well as oil and water: she's a privileged, acid-tongued brat, and he's a by-the-book, word-obsessed freak.  As the test draws nearer and the pair spend more time together, each surprises the other, and they both learn how to exercise intelligence that has nothing to do with a standardized test.  Jenny Lyn Bader's two-hander takes on topics of social class, addiction, and the pressure to succeed with sharp insight and lots of laughs.

Why it Matters

This production is special for a number of reasons.

For Pegasus51, this marks a reintroduction into the New York theatre community after a hiatus.  The company is glad to be doing to with a project that embodies its values so completely and involves young artists. 

For the actors involved, this is the first foray into self-producing.  It is important and empowering to produce, exercise creative control, and gain a greater understanding of creating independent theatre.  This is a chance for us to show what we can do with a fantastic script and excellent collaborators.

Lastly, and perhaps most importantly, for the students, this is an opportunity to dip their toes for the first time in the world of professional theatre.  They will be sitting in on rehearsals and taking on behind-the-scenes positions, which will give them the opportunity to see the process from page to stage.  They will be observing firsthand the real-life application of the concepts they've been learning in school.  This play is largely about the experience of a high school student, and we want to create our production with high school students in mind.  We could think of no better way than to involve them directly and are so excited to have them incorporated into our creative team.  Though we will undoubtedly benefit tremendously from working with these stellar young artists, we hope this experience will also assist them in applying to top theatre programs around the country. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

We understand that not everyone is in a position to make a financial donation, but there are other ways you can help! 

Please share our Indiegogo campaign with your friends and family via email and your favorite social media outlets.

Like us on Facebook and follow us on Instagram and Twitter (both @p51theatre).  We will be posting updates and photos throughout the entire process and we want to share them with you!

And of course, make sure to come check out the show once it opens. We will post a link for ticket sales soon, so look out for that!

Every bit of help we receive means the world to us, so thank you in advance for your kindness and support.
See you at the theatre!
The P51 Team
story_txt:
About Us Pegasus51 Theatre was founded in Austin, Texas, way, way back in 1998.  The city was a young, pulsating nerve mesh of artists.  It was launched to give the newest voices a place to be heard; in different languages, from different perspectives, with different points-of-view.  From that foundation, Pegasus51 blossomed into a group who valued training young artists and providing them with a laboratory in which they could bridge their differences as humans.
Now, years later, Pegasus51 is in the New York tri-state area and still committed to that same vision.
What We're DoingPegasus51 is embarking on an exciting collaboration with several generations of artists to produce None of the Above by Jenny Lyn Bader.  The play will be directed by Maria Aladren and will feature actors Rachel Caplan and Colin Friend.  We are thrilled to be collaborating with the  students of the School of Performing Arts at MCVTS throughout the process and will be incorporating them behind-the-scenes from our rehearsals through the run of the show.  None of the Above will run from October 23-November 1 in NYC.

Here's Where You Come In We need the help of generous donors in order to bring this plan to fruition. Your contributions will enable us to fund all aspects of production, including licensing rights, performance space, costumes, set, and promotional materials. Check out our perks on the side of this page, then please consider making a donation to be a part of this collaboration!
Who's Who
Director

Maria Aladren is a professional director
originally from Zaragoza, Spain.  Early on, she developed a
love for overlapping different forms of human expression in a variety of
cultures and time periods.  In the
pursuit of such bridges, Maria started a theatre company in Austin, Texas,
directing a number of productions ranging from classical works to foreign
material to original pieces that put together science and theatre.  In recent years, Maria has taken a hiatus to bring twin baby girls into
the world and to develop the conservatory theatre program at the School of
Performing Arts-MCVTS, teaching and directing young actors.  At the School of Performing Arts Main Stage
program which creates collaborations between professionals and students she has directed pieces such as The
Education Project, The Tempest, Comedy of Errors,Neighborhood 3:
Requisition of Doom, Midsummer Night's Dream, Anton in Show
Business, A Bright Room Called Day, Top Girls andThe Living. Maria trained as a director at the
University of Texas-Austin, where she received her MFA, and as a dramaturg at the Theatre School at Washington University
in St.  Louis.  She has also trained
with Barta Heiner and Jane Lapotaire of the Royal Shakespeare Company and with
Gabriel Chame from Clu de Clown in Madrid.
Stage Manager
Rowen Clarke is a junior in MCVTS Theatre, double-majoring in Stage Management and Acting. Rowen hopes to continue pursuing Stage Management and Acting through college and eventually into her adult life.

story:
The Project

Juan Villa, award-winning writer and performer of EMPANADA FOR A DREAM, shares a magical adventure version of a "highjacked childhood" through action, puppetry and song in the brand new DON CHIPOTLE. Being developed as a part of an In The Works residency with the Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events, the amazing creative team bringing it to life is personally asking YOU to please consider supporting the ongoing development of this exciting project.

Your fully tax-deductible contribution will help fund the current performances this summer in Chicago, support continued development of the play, and offer the collaborating artists compensation for their tremendous work.

Current Performances

terraNOVA Collective Chicago proudly presents

A Workshop Presentation of

DON CHIPOTLE

Written by JUAN FRANCISCO VILLA
Directed by JO CATTELL

Featuring:

Lorena Diaz, Wendy Mateo, Angela Oliver, Karen Rodriguez, Angelica Roque
Puppet Designers  Taylor Bibat & Rachel Singer
Composers Jenny Lynn Christoffersen & Preyas Roy

DON CHIPOTLE is inspired by the classic story of Don Quixote and Juan Villa's experience growing up in the immensely violent environment of the Lower East Side of New York City. The tragedy is not that of an old man who, while going senile exudes the spirit of an uninhibited child, but that of a child who has his childhood hijacked from him, forcing him to grow up too fast. This is a magical adventure story, where, through the eyes and brave action of a child, the audience crosses the vast metropolis of Manhattan to see the world put to right.

June 22 at 2pm, June 23 at 6:30pm
RSVP: don.chipotle.play@gmail.com
Studio Theatre at the Cultural Center
77 East Randolph Street Chicago, IL 60601

Artists' Bios

Juan Francisco Villa, Playwright

Juan Francisco Villa is an award winning writer and performer. His play EMPANADA FOR A DREAM was developed and performed in Chicago, New York, Los Angeles, San Diego and Syracuse. It won the IB Patrick Lee Award for best solo show, was nominated for 2 Jeff Awards and 3 New York Innovative Theatre Awards, and made Best Of lists in Chicago and Los Angeles. EMPANADA FOR A DREAM has also been published by NoPassport Inc. Juan is a writer with Inviolet Theatre Company (NYC), and an Associate Artist/Writer for 16th Street Theatre (Berwyn,IL) for whom he has written a short for Fall 2014. He was invited to write 3 plays for the One Minute Play Festival. Bob Ford, Artistic Director of Theater Squared, in Arkansas welcomed Juan to their New Play Fest specifically to develop DON CHIPOTLE. Acting Credits include: The Goodman, Steppenwolf, Victory Gardens, Rivendell, SALSATION, 16th Street Theater, Teatro Vista, Walkabout, Silk Road, Chicago Dramatists, Celebration, LATC, HERO, The Duke, Monarch, Rattlestick, Mabou Mines, INTAR,terraNOVA, Collective, Lark, Collaboration Town, 59E59, & La Mama.

Jo Cattell, Director

Jo Cattell is a producer/director/writer who has worked in theatre and television in the UK, Germany, France, Canada and the US. She currently works with Collaboraction in Chicago as Managing Director, as well as Resident Director for terraNOVA Collective in Chicago and New York City.

Jo’s main focus as a director has been on developing new writing. She recently worked as Script Consultant on RADIANT BABY, the Keith Haring musical for The Public Theatre, NYC, and is lead creator on a new project, BETWEEN SHADOW AND SOUL, being developed with terraNOVA Collective and Theatre C. She has directed for Origin Theatre Company, 1st Irish Theatre Festival, terraNOVA Collective, Leviathan Lab and was co-founder and Producing Artistic Director of BNTA in Las Vegas; she developed and directed SKYSCRAPING by Tim Stimpson for Net Curtain Theatre Company, which premiered at London’s Soho Theatre Studio and was then transferred to the Southwark Playhouse; assisted Theresa Heskins on Tony nominated playwright, Bryony Lavery’s PRECIOUS BANE for Pentabus Theatre; co-wrote and directed sketch comedy for the BBC; directed the first digital art installation for Canterbury Cathedral, 18:1-7 with C2atelyst Productions, UK; worked with at-risk youth for Grassmarket Project productions at Rutherglen Town Hall, Glasgow and The Roundhouse, London, staring David Harewood, and she was also Acting Coach for Cirque du Soleil on The Beatles LOVE, Las Vegas. 

Taylor Bibat, Puppeteer

Taylor Bibat is a Chicago born, Oberlin College educated, interdisciplinary artist with a focus on puppetry. Puppet credits include work with Noah Ginex Puppet Company, The Joshua Show, Adventure Stage, Blair Thomas and Company, Redmoon, Stephanie Diaz/Mariposa Nocturna, Chelsea Warren/Skokie Valley Symphony Orchestra, and others.  Her work has been seen locally at Nasty, Brutish, and Short Puppet Cabaret, Puppet Playlist (NYC), the O'Neill National Puppetry Conference (2012 and 2013), and the National Puppetry Festival (2013). She is also a co-curator for Nasty, Brutish, and Short and the Artistic Director of Oracle Puppet at Oracle Productions. Check out taylorbibat.com. 

Rachel Singer, Puppeteer

Rachel Singer began practicing puppetry professionally with Redmoon Theater in 2007.  Rachel's first puppetry training began decades earlier as a young child.  While growing up, her mom taught her that anything could come to life and become a puppet at anytime, and any experience could be transformed into a different reality.  This informs much of her work and play today.  She has been exploring the intersections of art and healing to connect and transform mind, body and spirit.  In 2012, Rachel trained in Dance for Parkinson's and Arts in Medicine at the University of Florida.  She has been teaching dance and puppetry in the Chicago Public Schools since 2007.  Most recently, Rachel became a certified yoga instructor and is thrilled to be sharing this practice at Eden Supportive Living and in private lessons.

Jenny Lynn Christoffersen, Composer

Jenny has been calling Chicago her zip code for three years and couldn't feel more at home. A zealous over-achiever, she has sung in Australia, acted in productions from Tennessee to Rhode Island, and had her work performed from New York to Virginia. Favorites of her written work include SUBTEXT (multiple emerging playwright festivals winner) and HOME (with Chicago's own (re)discover theatre company). She's a proud staff member at Collaboraction theatre company in Wicker Park and plays original music around Chicago.

Preyas Roy, Composer

Preyas Roy is a Chicago-based vibraphonist, composer and band leader. As a performer, he has worked with Dee Alexander's Evolution Ensemble, Ernest Dawkins's We Free Trio, Vincent Davis's Percussion Plus, Samuel Williams's SavoireFaire Jazz Quartet, and Saalik Ziyad's 5 After 7 Project. He was a co-founder of the progressive fusion ensemble Mosaik, and the founder and leader of the creative dance music collective Eigenfunk. His compositions have appeared in film and theater around the world.

story:
New Queer Voices, Outspoken

Patterflash! is a literary variety show, combining the best traditions of live literature with all the energy and verve of queer performance. 

We will draw upon the range of queer life--from ballroom culture to protest movements, from house music to cabaret, from drag to stand-up, from pride to the 'gay language' Polari--to vivify our stories of contemporary queer Britain.

Six writers of diverse backgrounds (spanning three religions, three ethnic groups and three genders) will travel to Edinburgh to perform this exciting new show: Tara Ali Din, Jane Bradley, Barnaby Callaby, Jamal Gerald, Adam Lowe and Rebecca Swarray. (For more about our writers, visit our writers' page.)

In Brief

  • Young Enigma is a not-for-profit collective of young and emerging LGBT writers based in the North of England.
  • We have been invited to take our unique brand of literary performance to Edinburgh Free Fringe (Peter Buckley Hill Free Fringe), where we can reach new audiences, share skills with local community groups and raise awareness for LGBT issues.
  • This opportunity puts young queer voices in the limelight--allowing us to speak up and speak out about our lived experiences, to celebrate LGBT culture and to push the boundaries between writing and performance.
  • As part of our commitment to the community, we will also be providing coverage of other LGBT events that form part of the Free Fringe, to raise the profile of LGBT organisers and performers in the UK. This coverage will be published by our media partners, Vada Magazine, allowing us to reach over 50,000 readers each month.

Why Support Us?

A generation of young people currently faces low employment prospects, increasing living costs and unaffordable housing. LGBT young people face additional pressures, including increased risk of self-harm and suicide, homelessness, substance misuse issues, mental health issues, being bullied and social exclusion. Young Enigma hopes to overcome some of these challenges through artistic interventions and a scheme of personal and professional development.

Young Enigma offers a tailored package of support to young people aged 13-35, in order to create a next generation of community leaders and peer mentors who can be the role models of tomorrow. Young Enigma develops young people's employability and confidence, and supports young people in pursuing fulfilling careers in the arts. Members of Young Enigma work directly with youth and community groups to educate, inspire and record LGBT experiences, and to fight homophobia and transphobia in society.

Through our wider activities, Young Enigma supports young people and the LGBT community to engage with high-quality arts activities and their own LGBT cultural heritage. We do this through prizes and competitions, workshops, educational resources for schools, publications, performances and lectures.

Praise for Young Enigma

'fresh and creative' Gabriella Swirling

‘original, refreshing’ The Public Reviews

'a stunning string of performances' Mancunian Matters

'breathtaking . . . exquisite' Vada Magazine

What We Need & What You Get

We have asked for a very modest sum of £3,000. This will support us in:

  • Travelling to Edinburgh.
  • Paying for accommodation for six nights.
  • Performing our literary variety show for five nights.
  • Documenting the show (photography and video).
  • Publishing a showreel of the performance for the public.
  • Providing opportunities to share skills with local LGBT groups.
  • Attending LGBT events to provide additional exposure in Vada Magazine.

If we exceed this sum, we can do even more:

  • £3,500 will support us in developing a wider programme of outreach workshops with local community groups and LGBT youth.
  • £4,000 will enable us to create a package of short workshop films for young people, including tips on writing and performing, that can be accessed online for free.
  • £5,000 will allow us to tour our performance so that we can perform it in other cities around the country.

As part of our not-for-profit constitution, any surplus funds are reinvested in supporting young LGBT artists. For this reason, every penny really does help. You can ensure the future growth of our organisation and the opportunities we can offer to young people who may face additional difficulties because of their sexuality and/or gender identity.

The Impact

Patterflash! is important to us for a number of reasons:

  • It acts as a living document of LGBT stories, drawn from our research over the last 18 months as LGBT History Month Writers in Residence and Manchester Pride Writers in Residence.
  • It maintains and enlivens the 'gay language' Polari, once considered dead by linguists, and brings it into the context of contemporary LGBT experiences.
  • It explores new ways of performing literature for live audiences--from dance to drag--in a way that appeals to a wider cross-section of society.
  • It will engage new audiences who might not see their own stories reflected in mainstream culture and who may not otherwise attend literary or theatre events.
  • It will form the basis for a new show which can be toured around schools and community groups. This is part of our aim to engage people in the arts and to challenge homophobia and transphobia in all areas of society.

We have an excellent track record in this regard.

  • We produced five writers' commissions, including a day of performances, for LGBT History Month 2013 as the LGBT History Month Writers in Residence.
  • We have produced live shows for Greater Manchester Fringe, Manchester Literature Festival and Queer Contact.
  • We have performed with stellar writers and performers such as Jackie Kay, Patience Agbabi and Gerry Potter.
  • Our writers have delivered workshops in schools, prisons, universities and community settings.
  • Between us we have awards, books, magazines, commissions, plays, films and songs under our belts.

(Find our more about past events and performances)

Other Ways You Can Help

So what if you can't help us financially? Well there are other ways you can support us:

  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word.
  • You can interview one or more of our group for your publication or website.
  • You can offer to distribute flyers and promotional literature to local venues.
  • You can come and see our show (it's free!).
  • You can ask a local theatre, library, school or community group to book us.
  • You can lead a guest workshop in your own area of expertise.
  • You can like our Facebook page or follow our Twitter account.

See you in Edinburgh!

The Empress reads her honours list of contributors so far here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XDmfQAexZG4&amp...
story_txt:
New Queer Voices, OutspokenPatterflash! is a literary variety show, combining the best traditions of live literature with all the energy and verve of queer performance. We will draw upon the range of queer life--from ballroom culture to protest movements, from house music to cabaret, from drag to stand-up, from pride to the 'gay language' Polari--to vivify our stories of contemporary queer Britain.Six writers of diverse backgrounds (spanning three religions, three ethnic groups and three genders) will travel to Edinburgh to perform this exciting new show: Tara Ali Din, Jane Bradley, Barnaby Callaby, Jamal Gerald, Adam Lowe and Rebecca Swarray. (For more about our writers, visit our writers' page.)In Brief

Young Enigma is a not-for-profit collective of young and emerging LGBT writers based in the North of England.
We have been invited to take our unique brand of literary performance to Edinburgh Free Fringe (Peter Buckley Hill Free Fringe), where we can reach new audiences, share skills with local community groups and raise awareness for LGBT issues.
This opportunity puts young queer voices in the limelight--allowing us to speak up and speak out about our lived experiences, to celebrate LGBT culture and to push the boundaries between writing and performance.
As part of our commitment to the community, we will also be providing coverage of other LGBT events that form part of the Free Fringe, to raise the profile of LGBT organisers and performers in the UK. This coverage will be published by our media partners, Vada Magazine, allowing us to reach over 50,000 readers each month.
Why Support Us?A generation of young people currently faces low employment prospects, increasing living costs and unaffordable housing. LGBT young people face additional pressures, including increased risk of self-harm and suicide, homelessness, substance misuse issues, mental health issues, being bullied and social exclusion. Young Enigma hopes to overcome some of these challenges through artistic interventions and a scheme of personal and professional development.Young Enigma offers a tailored package of support to young people aged 13-35, in order to create a next generation of community leaders and peer mentors who can be the role models of tomorrow. Young Enigma develops young people's employability and confidence, and supports young people in pursuing fulfilling careers in the arts. Members of Young Enigma work directly with youth and community groups to educate, inspire and record LGBT experiences, and to fight homophobia and transphobia in society.Through our wider activities, Young Enigma supports young people and the LGBT community to engage with high-quality arts activities and their own LGBT cultural heritage. We do this through prizes and competitions, workshops, educational resources for schools, publications, performances and lectures.Praise for Young Enigma'fresh and creative' Gabriella Swirling‘original, refreshing’ The Public Reviews'a stunning string of performances' Mancunian Matters'breathtaking . . . exquisite' Vada MagazineWhat We Need & What You GetWe have asked for a very modest sum of £3,000. This will support us in:
Travelling to Edinburgh.
Paying for accommodation for six nights.
Performing our literary variety show for five nights.
Documenting the show (photography and video).
Publishing a showreel of the performance for the public.
Providing opportunities to share skills with local LGBT groups.
Attending LGBT events to provide additional exposure in Vada Magazine.
If we exceed this sum, we can do even more:
£3,500 will support us in developing a wider programme of outreach workshops with local community groups and LGBT youth.

£4,000 will enable us to create a package of short workshop films for young people, including tips on writing and performing, that can be accessed online for free.
£5,000 will allow us to tour our performance so that we can perform it in other cities around the country.
As part of our not-for-profit constitution, any surplus funds are reinvested in supporting young LGBT artists. For this reason, every penny really does help. You can ensure the future growth of our organisation and the opportunities we can offer to young people who may face additional difficulties because of their sexuality and/or gender identity.The ImpactPatterflash! is important to us for a number of reasons:
It acts as a living document of LGBT stories, drawn from our research over the last 18 months as LGBT History Month Writers in Residence and Manchester Pride Writers in Residence.
It maintains and enlivens the 'gay language' Polari, once considered dead by linguists, and brings it into the context of contemporary LGBT experiences.
It explores new ways of performing literature for live audiences--from dance to drag--in a way that appeals to a wider cross-section of society.
It will engage new audiences who might not see their own stories reflected in mainstream culture and who may not otherwise attend literary or theatre events.
It will form the basis for a new show which can be toured around schools and community groups. This is part of our aim to engage people in the arts and to challenge homophobia and transphobia in all areas of society.
We have an excellent track record in this regard.
We produced five writers' commissions, including a day of performances, for LGBT History Month 2013 as the LGBT History Month Writers in Residence.
We have produced live shows for Greater Manchester Fringe, Manchester Literature Festival and Queer Contact.
We have performed with stellar writers and performers such as Jackie Kay, Patience Agbabi and Gerry Potter.
Our writers have delivered workshops in schools, prisons, universities and community settings.
Between us we have awards, books, magazines, commissions, plays, films and songs under our belts.
(Find our more about past events and performances)Other Ways You Can HelpSo what if you can't help us financially? Well there are other ways you can support us:
You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word.
You can interview one or more of our group for your publication or website.
You can offer to distribute flyers and promotional literature to local venues.
You can come and see our show (it's free!).
You can ask a local theatre, library, school or community group to book us.
You can lead a guest workshop in your own area of expertise.
You can like our Facebook page or follow our Twitter account.
See you in Edinburgh!The Empress reads her honours list of contributors so far here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XDmfQAexZG4&amp...

story:
WHO ARE WE:


Shrunken Shakespeare Company is a New York City based Not-For-Profit theater company (under Fractured Atlas) whose mission is to develop classical theatre pieces, throw them in the air, scramble them up, shorten them and give them context that allows the actors and audience to see and experience them in a way that they never have before.  We create ensemble-driven, irreverent, inventive classical theatre that incorporates various types of performance, including but not limited to: dance, music, acrobatics, circus and clowning. 

 Our goal is to stay true to the text, while making it relatable to a younger, modern audience. We tailor every play to fit the space in which it is performed. Thus, the site becomes the set. We aim to create a relationship between both the actor and the audience, who we hope will walk away with a profound understanding of each play and an exciting new perspective of what classical theatre means today. 




WHAT DO WE NEED:


We'll be honest. We need A LOT more than $5000. But its a start. All in all we are trying to raise $30,000 to put us in a position to produce more shows, make a bigger impact on our COMMUNITY, and grow our company. Some things funding will help us achieve: Paying our amazing team of actors, technicians, directors, choreographers, and designers,  publicity and marketing, insurance and legal fees, education and enrichment programs for our performers and artistic staff, and accessible, low cost theater for the community.



WHAT'S COMING UP FOR US:


We have three HUGE exciting and surprising projects in the works for this season that will challenge us and our audiences in completely new ways they haven't seen from us before:

1) On Monday April 21, 2014, SSC will be holding celebrity benefit gala/workshop reading.

Shrunken Shakespeare Company’s 2014 Fundraiser Gala will be hosting the New York City premiere of “Lear” adapted by and starring Paul Sorvino.  This cut of William Shakespeare’s “King Lear” will be presented as a staged reading, produced by SSC in collaboration with director and producer Joe Paradise. In addition to Sorvino and Paradise, Eric Tucker (Director and Star of Bedlam's Hamlet and Saint Joan), actor/comedian Wayne Powers, Michael Sorvino, and Tyler Hollinger (The Public Theatre and The Mint), will also be taking part in “Lear.” Complete casting is to be announced. The Gala will take place on Monday, April 21at 7:30PM, at The Barrow Group located at 312 W 36th Street, 3rd Floor, New York, NY. 

We are honored to have the support and talent of Mr.Sorvino and Mr. Paradise!!


2) A co-production with Pulp Variety Streamcast, presenting a radio play adaptation of Anthony Del Col and Connor McCreery's popular graphic novel series Kill Shakespeare. This radio play will be recorded in front of a live audience, then broadcast as a 5 part series on the Pulp Variety Streamcast iTunes podcast. May 2014

(Check out the Pulp Variety Streamcast on iTunes here: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/pulp-variety-streamcast-live/id804971780?mt=2) 


3) After the gala, SSC begins work on its first ever non-Shakespeare production of Chekhov’s “Three Sisters.” Our ensemble will develop and write a new adaptation of this famous classic over Summer 2014, followed by a world premiere in the Fall/Winter of 2014. This production will run in repertory with a yet to be selected Shakespeare play in Spring 2015. SSC will be collaborating with Improv Actor/Teacher Mark Grenier, of The Barrow Group Theatre Company, to develop this contemporary rendition of the play. 


 A Little Bit About Our First Year: 


We previously campaigned and fundraised over $3000 for our first production A Midsummer Night's Dream, in 2012. Since then we completely recouped that investment, sold out that first run, and produced a second show, The Two Gentlemen of Verona, with the proceeds. We recently performed and held a discussion panel at The Pearl Theatre Company Off-Broadway and held our second sold out benefit concert. You can check out photos from all of our shows and events on our Facebook Page.

Company Members Pictured Above (L to R) at The Pearl Theatre Company February 2014: Sam Parrott, Amanda Baumler, Sloan Bradford, Blaire O'Leary, Jennifer Martina, Yvonne Cone, Brendan Sokler


WHY DONATE NOW: 


Donating to SSC at this time is especially important as we have obtained a donor who will fully match the $5,000 we are looking to raise with your help, and another donor who will match that donor. With your support, we can raise the full $30,000 and guarantee all of the amazing work we have planned for our next season will become a reality.

To show our appreciation of your generosity, we will be offering some great perks, including: Complimentary tickets to our Celebrity Gala/Staged Reading which includes a Q&A with the cast and producers followed by a cocktail party, tickets to our next full production, advertisements for you/your company, custom made video monologues just for you, and co-producer credit on our next production. These, plus the perks of our undying love are pretty hard to pass up huh? (Nah, we know you love it cause it's all Tax Deductible). 

 All in all we have doubled our revenue since we began in 2012, with the help of donors like YOU. This past year was more successful than we could have wished, and we have three more unbelievable projects for this year. 

 As you can see, we are busy, and happy to be so. Your support for our efforts is more important than ever, as we aim to create not only plays that are relevant to a modern audience, but plays that are being created in a collaborative way that enrich our community.

Every little bit helps, and if you can't give that $5, $100, $1,000 or $5,000 (and even if you can) share this page with your friends, visit us on Facebook, Twitter, or Tumblr. Each "like" and "share" helps us grow as a company and helps us reach out to our community. 


Thank your from our staff and the entire resident company for your time and support:

Co-Producing Artistic Directors: Yvonne Cone and Jennifer Martina

Company Manger: Amanda Baumler

Production Manager: Christian LeMay

Director of Social Media and PR: Aubree Mercure

story:
Short Summary

Everyone from Time Magazine to Kevin Bacon has weighed in on the plight of Millennials, born from 1980- 2000, in articles and blogs ranging from scathing to sympathetic. Our worst critics have called us lazy, entitled, even psychopathic, while others define us as an entrepreneurial generation, eschewing stability for opportunity and redefining traditional notions of success.

On April 25th and 26th at St. Luke’s Church, Mixed Company Theatre’s Emerging Artists are performing their workshop production of Unemployment Unanimous; A 12 step program for Millennials.  

Unemployment Unanimous is our response to the overwhelming media attention on Millennials. Project Boomerang’s nine emerging artists have come from diverse artistic backgrounds to form a collective and create a fresh perspective on the issues surrounding Millennials. Project Boomerang goes beyond the media hype to ask the tough questions around expectation, entitlement and adaptability. “What exactly is the problem? Are we to blame for our lack of employment prospects? Can the problem be fixed or is it time to learn to adapt?”

What Your Money Will Help Support

The money that you donate will go directly to the production and creation of Unemployment Unanimous. These costs include paying for the performance space, buying and making the costumes and props.  

If we exceed our fundraising goal of $1000.00 the money will go towards paying the artists who have created Unemployment Unanimous. 

Info about the Performance

We would love for you to going us for Unemployment Unanimous; A 12 step program for Millennials on April 25th - 26th at 8:00 pm in the Ladies Parlor at St-Luke's Church, 157 Carlton.

Tickets are $10.00 for Arts workers, Students, Un/under-employed, and $15.00 for any one who can afford it. 

Here is a link to purchase your tickets http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/622804

Created and performed by Kristin Bartlett, Emma Bulpin, Nicole De Angelis, Jenna Harris, Emma Letki, Erin McCluskey, Michael Reinhart, Aidan Sheppard and Meara Tubman-Broeren
