story:
Short Summary

Théâtre du Rêve (Theatre of the Dream) is Atlanta's unique theatre company devoted to bringing French culture and language to life on the American stage. In addition to our annual productions, we have a budding educational sector devoted to exposing kids from all walks of life to French culture and theatre.  Enter Été des Rêves: TdR's Summer Theatre-Intensive Camps.  Atlanta is filled with many wonderful theatre camps, but many of them are hard to afford. Our desire at TdR is to reformat our summer camp so that kids can participate regardless of their parents' wallets.  Campers will be exposed to French literature and theatre arts as they mount a fully staged production based on a classic French story in English. This year's campers will bring Perrault's Sleeping Beauty and Dumas's The Three Musketeers to life. When they are not rehearsing or learning about the original story, campers will take part in workshops in subjects ranging from scenework to mime to stage combat. Each camp will empowering kids to find their unique voices through theater and to develop persuasive skills through scene work. Their one week experience will culminate in two performances open to the public.  Camps are June 16-21 (Sleeping Beauty) and June 23-28 (The Three Musketeers) at The Lovett School in Atlanta.   

Learn more about our organization, our history, and our summer camp. Visit www.tdratl.org. Please support our cause. Donate today!   

What We Need & What You Get

Please help us reach our goal of $8,500 to provide a wonderful, affordable camp for kids ages 7-17 (rising 2nd through 12th graders). We have already had the space for camp generously donated! Funding will be used as follows:  

$2,800 for 2 teaching artists for 2 weeks

$2,000 for full scholarships for 20 kids (10 per week)  

$1,800 for camp director for 2 weeks

$1000 for set, costumes, props for 2 weeks

$400 for rights, scripts, and copies for two plays
$500 for donation platform processing fees 

PERKS:

Donations of $5-$49: Shout Out

Donations of $50-$99: Personalized Thank You Card

Donations of $100-$199: Your Name in BIG Letters

Donations of $200-$349: Life is a Cabaret

Donations of $350-$499: Lunch with the Kids

Donations of $500 and more: Your Name in Lights

*Théâtre du Rêve is a non-profit 501(c)3 organization. All donations are 100% tax deductible.

WHERE DO THE FUNDS GO IF WE FALL SHORT?

In the event that we do not reach our funding goal, we will still make summer camp happen. However, we will be forced to make cuts to salaries for our fabulous teaching artists, cuts to supplies for costumes and scenery, and finally cuts to the number of scholarships we can offer each week.

The Impact

CAMP GOALS:

  • To mount a story by a French author as a one-week play, teaching kids teamwork, confidence, and creativity.
  • To empower kids to find their voices through theater and persuasive skills through scene work.
  • To cultivate lasting friendships and an appreciation of the arts.
  • To provide a summer camp that does not turn campers away because of tuition (by providing full and partial scholarships and by fundraising on Indiegogo).
  • To provide a training ground for young adult theatre artists to serve in the capacity of Camp Intern so they may receive training on leading workshops and running a camp for students.
WHY IT MATTERS:

In our experience in Atlanta, government funding cuts have made it difficult for schools to provide valuable, hands-on experiences related to foreign language and the arts. Kids in these same schools cannot afford the luxury of attending an expensive summer camp. Été des Rêves means "Summer of Dreams," and that is what we aim to offer for kids who otherwise could not have this unique experience. Our camp will empower kids across the boundaries of social and economic background. Through this experience, local kids will establish lasting friendships and learn to cultivate an appreciation of the arts and for other cultures.

As an organization, TdR has been providing foreign language/theatre educational experiences for kids in Atlanta for 17 years. In that time, many teachers and parents have thanked us for reaching out and inspiring kids. Ms. Johnson of Price Middle School wrote, "As a result of these visits, students have learned the value of the French language through drama and art, the use of the French language in other parts of the world, their responsibility to the global society and the importance of preparing for college and careers."

Help summer camp be a step in one kids journey! Donate today.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone has the means to make a donation. Please help our cause by spreading the word to your friends, families, neighbors and co-workers. It's easy! Just use the Indiegogo share tools.

You can also support Théâtre du Rêve by following us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.

More info at www.tdratl.org.

of the French language through drama and art, the use of the French

story:
All Gone West is a sponsored project of Interborough Repertory Theater (IRT), a not-for-profit theater company. If you would like your contribution to be tax-deductible, please get in touch with us at allgonewest(at)gmail(dot)com before making your donation and we will make it happen. Thank you so much!


What’s this all about?

Well, glad you asked! All Gone West is a play about real people pursuing their dreams and coping with the outcomes.  It mirrors our lives and we'd bet yours too.  Whether or not our dreams are fulfilled, we must come to terms with the results and continue to live our lives.  Watching your dream explode can be devastating; having your dream fulfilled is exhilarating.  This is what our two main characters experience in All Gone West, and we want you to be a witness to their journeys.  Join us for the dreams, the jazz, the plot, the love, the disappointments, and the victories.


We've been cooking up this play for two years, and we're sure it's going to be our best yet. We will be producing All Gone West this coming season at a theater in Manhattan, and to do so, we need your help to raise $10,000.


We’ve assembled an incredible team of jazz musicians and designers already, with an awesome cast and crew in the works. We are here now asking for your support to bring this to life. We really can't do it without you.


A little lot of help from our friends.


A life in the theatre is never easy, but it’s the life we've chosen, and love. We’ve been at this for years and have the experience, both individually and as a team, but we need your help with the resources. Your donation today will go such a long way toward getting All Gone West in the theater this coming season. Please help us take our dream off the ground and onto the stage!


Where will the money go?

Thanks to our incredible supporters, we’ve already raised $15,500! We need an additional $10,000 to produce All Gone West this coming season at an off-off Broadway theater in Manhattan, and here's where the money will go:

  • Theater rental and insurance, $2,500 a week for four weeks = $10,000

  • Costumes, sets, props, lighting =  $2,500

  • Actors, musicians, designers, crew, publicist/marketing = $10,000

  • All other expenses = $2,500

TOTAL: $25,000



Who are we?

 


We are Jonathan Fluck (l) and John Attanas (r), with the extremely talented group of jazz musicians and designers you see listed below, and soon-to-be brilliant cast. We met through Interborough Repertory Theatre (IRT), which Jonathan co-founded and ran from 1986 to 2006. Through IRT, Jonathan produced, directed, and acted in over fifty shows, from Equity showcases to traveling shows for children, including directing four of John’s plays on Theatre Row. John is a graduate of the LaGuardia High School of Performing Arts and NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts. He’s had over twenty plays produced and has published three children’s books.

Now we have one more play to present. And it’s going to be the best yet.

We really need your help to make this production a reality! If you make a donation, you will be helping two experienced Off-Off Broadway veterans get a show off the ground and into a theatre.



Testimonials

Quotes from Glen Williamson, Actor

"Jonathan Fluck is delightful to work with. He is both professional and fun. He has a ton of experience as a director, as a producer and as a performer. It is always a joy to work with him."
"John Attanas is a skilled and sensitive playwright. I've had the privilege of originating and reviving roles in several of his plays. His plots and characters are rich with pathos and humanity." 


Video testimonial from Lisa Tracy, Actor




Quote from Luane Davis Haggerty, Ph.D., Actor

"Both Jonathan and John are creative artists with a view to what can suceed for a theatrical audience.  They are hard working individuals who can make a project reach fruition and success.

In the various projects I was able to work with them on, their willingness to problem solve and their dedication and responsibility served as a role model for the rest of the production staff. Their patience and cooperation even when in stressful situations were commendable.  They are both hard workers who are willing to do what it takes to get the job done. Both of them have a natural warmth and love of working with people which influences the rest of the staff, often resulting in a soul satisfying experience as well as credible artistic work.  As a colleague, Jonathan in particular was diligent and offered great insight and creative responses to projects and in discussion."

Video testimonial from Cynthia Shaw, Actor/Musical Director





Meet some of the gang

We’re excited to introduce you to some of the awesome talent that is already on board:

 

COLIN TABER, Musical Director, Guitar

 

MAHLON HOARD, Saxophone

 

KIMA BAFFOUR, Costume Designer

 

CHRISTINA WATANABE, Lighting Designer

ANDREW DIAZ, Set & Prop Designer


Read more about these talented folks on our website: www.allgonewest.org/about



THANK YOU!

... for anything you can give. Every single donation goes a long way toward making this production a reality. Our play is about the past... and the present. Dreams fulfilled… and dreams dashed. Everyone has a dream. Ours is to produce this play. Please help us with your gift today. We need YOU!


& last, but not least, help us spread the word. Tell you friends, your family, the jazz musician who lives across the hall... together we can make this happen. Thank you for your support!

story:
Hi, we are the Wednesday Addams collective. We're Melbourne based artists creating  a live art performance at this year's Fringe Festival.
The work is free to attend, but of course the production costs are mounting. So we're doing an ol' fashioned cook up and giving away other exciting Wednesday Addams Goodies to raise the funds for the piece to be realised.
The funds will be used to cover:
$500 Public Liability Insurance + Fringe Registration
$300- Rehearsal Space Hire 
$400- Set/Costume
$100- equipment hire.
                                                               
The work is an exploration into the world of gazers and our need to believe in something. There will be pop-infused chanting. There will be amulets that will maintain salvation. Visually it will be as potent as burnt toast. 
What will happen when the silence starts?
Will you start to believe?

Direction by Cassandra Fumi
Musical Direction by Lonnie Mackertich
Art Direction  by  Lauren Stephens
Production by Ben Meyer
Video Art by Kenzie Larsen
Dramaturgy by Emma Palackic
Musicians Trelawney Edgar & Joel Skurrie 
+ Wednesday Addams

story:
OUR STORY

Hi, I’m Crystal Lewis the Founder and Artistic Director of Conversion Dance Project.

Conversion Dance Project is something I started towards the end of my graduate school career in 2011 as a way to showcase my work professionally, with the aspirations of one day becoming a professional modern dance company. Through Conversion Dance Project I mostly set works on myself, fellow freelance dance artists and dance students, which are then generally performed in various dance festivals and colleges. However, I have always had the desire to produce my own show. Dance festivals can be a wonderful way to get your work out there in a really cost efficient way. But, I wanted to push beyond showing my work at a dance festival. While festivals can offer lots of exposure, especially to up and coming choreographers, it’s not likely that you will have the opportunity to show more than one work, and on some occasions, more than one performance. I wanted the opportunity to be able to showcase a body of my selected works in one concert event. I’m also hoping this will give Conversion Dance Project the exposure it needs to continue pushing forward.

WHAT WE ARE DOING

Conversion Dance Project is still pretty new and so I thought it would be great to share a concert with a company that is more established. With this realization in mind, I have partnered with Amy Llanes, the Founder and Artistic Director of the Houston based Rednerrus Feil Dance Company, for BLEND:Phoenix Meets Houston, which will be showcasing the works of both Conversion Dance Project and RFDC.  RFDC will open the first half of the show. I thought this would be a wonderful partnership and a great opportunity for the local community here in Arizona to be introduced to some really wonderful dancing coming out of Houston. The Houston dance scene is extremely vibrant and I thought it would be really nice to bring a little piece of that right here to Arizona. Audiences will get to enjoy both local dancers and Houston area dancers all in one show.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Putting on a show is not without expense. Keeping the various expenses in mind we have cut as many corners as possible, without compromising the quality of the show. We have reserved the 350 seat Hal Bogle Theatre at the Chandler Center for the Arts in downtown Chandler, Arizona. The city of Chandler is just east of the Phoenix Metropolitan area. We need help in raising the funds necessary to put on this show, which is why we are running an Indiegogo campaign and asking for donations.

Please take a look below at the total cost breakdown of our needs.

BREAKDOWN OF EXPENSES

The total cost of renting the Hal Bogle Theatre for two days is $3,173.50, which includes crew costs.

A $475 deposit has already been paid to reserve the theater leaving a total cost of $2,698.50 (this amount must be paid in full by September 24, 2014).

Between both companies we have about 12 dancers performing in the show, some of whom will be traveling to Phoenix from Houston.

Not only would we need to cover the cost of renting the theater and insurance for renting the theater, but we would love to be able to reimburse travel expenses for our out of town guests. The theater keeps 4% of total gross ticket sales, but we are hopeful that our ticket sales will still generate enough money to pay our performers and choreographers. However, in the event that ticket sales do not adequately pay our dancers, we hope the money raised on our campaign will also help to serve as a cushion and cover the difference.

AMOUNT NEEDED TO RAISE

With these expenses in mind we have set a goal of $5500 to help offset the total costs of producing the show. We would love any donation you are able to provide to our campaign and appreciate any support you are able to give either monetarily or by sharing our campaign with others. You also have the option to enter the exact amount you wish to contribute. You can enter as little as $5 or as much as $100 or any amount in between. The perk amounts are merely suggested amount donations, but you have the option to choose exactly how much you wish to donate. Any amount donated is much appreciated as every little bit helps!

Thank You In Advance For Your Support!

Warmly,

Crystal Lewis

Founder/Artistic Director of Conversion Dance Project


Check out each respective company below on their official website
www.conversiondanceproject.net
http://www.redfeildance.com/

You can also verify our show by checking out the Chandler Center for the Arts
Chandler Center for the Arts Events Calendar Link Below
http://chandlercenter.org/performances.html

story:
The Journey:

GENESIS:SARAJEVO has been working since 2006 to empower young artists and to unify different cultures and religions through dance and arts education in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The goal is to create outlets and more artists in developing areas of the world while promoting peace. 

Since 2006, Genesis:Sarajevo has held a two week dance intensive twice a year in Bosnia and Herzegovina where girls and young women from different ethnicities have the opportunity to interact through dance and to perform in different cities. We have continued bi-annual intensives and outreach to communities in BiH and have since also established a consistent company of 10 local dancers and various choreographers/instructors from around the world. Our program is unique as we go beyond teaching girls dance technique. We encourage their creative process by giving them the opportunity to develop their own choreography about issues that affect them in their country. 


The Program: 

The activities include regular classes where participants receive training in jazz, ballet, contemporary, and hip-hop from GENESIS: SARAJEVO instructors from the U.S., Bosnia, and Europe. In addition to the regular classes, we invite guest instructors from the Balkan region, Europe, and the United States to conduct workshops in different dance styles with participants. The aim of the workshops is to foster intercultural exchange between artists in other parts of the Balkans and Europe where dance is more developed. In addition, GENESIS: SARAJEVO presents performances in which participants perform in Sarajevo as well as other cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina to bring more dance exposure to the region. Participants also perform their own social awareness choreography during these performances.  

The Objectives:

  • To spread dance, especially tap, jazz, ballet, contemporary, and hip-hop beyond Sarajevo to other towns and areas in Bosnia and Herzegovina
  • To provide regular professional dance training for children/youth to prepare them to be a performance based company that performs in Bosnia and eventually other countries
  • To continue their development as dancers and as more productive members of society
  • To foster mediation between different ethnicities through dance and arts education while developing new community bonds
  • To use dance in an awareness campaign to address societal issues in Bosnia and around the world
  • To provide youth from all economic backgrounds with a livelihood and career in dance, dance education, and arts management


'FROM WITHIN' SUMMER 2014 DANCE INTENSIVE:

NYC instructors/choreographers, Amy Danielson and Nikki Baksh will conduct a two-week dance intensive focusing on the tools to develop sound inner guidance, deepen inner strength, and cultivate a keen inner voice which are essential driving forces through life.  Often innate in dancers, these qualities will be explored, encouraged, and challenged in a safe environment through various dance styles, choreography, yoga, meditation, and discussions.  Awareness is brought to how these attributes carry over into our everyday lives and how we can rely on them to bring us into our fullest being.  

'From Within' will take place August 11 - 25, 2014
More information about Amy & Nikki:  

www.amy-danielson.com 
www.nikkibaksh.com


We are past recipients of the US Embassy Public Diplomacy Grant and the International Freedom to Create Grant. Genesis continues to provide a space for young adults to interact, grow creatively, and engage with local communities.

Please visit our website: www.genesissarajevo.org. You can also read our blog and follow us on twitter!

story:
Almost a century ago, the world was poised to enter one of the most devastating conflicts in human history.

Those involved are no longer here to tell the story of their sacrifice. That is why The Empty Room theatre collective will be mounting RC Sherriff’s Journey’s End this November: as a living memorial to those that fought and died on the battlefields of Europe.

The play is a gripping portrayal of life in the trenches of the First World War. It tells the story of a group of allied soldiers in the front-lines of Northern France in 1918, mere days before the last big German offensive. Written in 1928, the play is a wry reflection of Sherriff’s own experiences as a young man, having served in the British Army until he was wounded in the battle of Passchendaele, and a detailed account of the strain of life at war.

While we’ve managed to raise a portion of our budget, we are looking for the last push to make sure this project can realize its full potential.

Your donation will help offset costs for the following:

•Lighting ($300) Fixtures, cables & stands to illuminate the soldiers’ world.

•Sound ($250) Speakers & amplifiers for the soundscape of the front line.

•Costumes ($750) The iconic uniforms of the First World War.

•Set ($600) Lumber, fastenings, burlap & paint to turn a concrete industrial space into an officers’ dugout.

•Props ($300) Pistols, maps, all the objects that will bring our trench to life.

The Performance Rights for a three-week run, Venue rental costs, and many of our initial expenses have already been covered through sponsorships, private donations, and our own personal contributions. As we move into production however, we need your support to truly bring this project to life.

Don’t have cash to spare, but still want to help? Please spread the word about our show and campaign! And, if you have any materials lying around that you think we could use, send us a message and we’ll put them towards a perk.

Finally, we would like to acknowledge the continued support we’ve received from Royal Canadian Legion branch 344, The Queens Own Rifles. Our performance on Sunday November 10th will be a special benefit for their annual Poppy Drive, with all proceeds from ticket sales going directly towards their appeal.

As we are coming up on the 100th anniversary of the start of the Great War we feel that it is the perfect time to be mounting this production, our version of a living remembrance memorial.


To directly buy tickets for Journey's End visit http://journeysend.eventbrite.ca
The Empty Room is a collective of Toronto theatre artists.
www.empty-room.com

Don’t have cash to spare, but still want to help? Please spread the word about our show and campaign! And, if you have
any materials lying around that you think we could use, send us a message and we’ll put them towards a perk.
Finally, we would like to acknowledge the continued support
we’ve received from Royal Canadian Legion branch 344, The Queens Own Rifles. Our
performance on Sunday November 10th will be a special benefit for their annual Poppy Drive, with all proceeds from
ticket sales going directly towards their appeal.
As we are coming up on the
100th anniversary of the start of the Great War we feel that it is
the perfect time to be mounting this production, our version of a living
remembrance memorial.




To directly buy tickets for Journey's End visit http://journeysend.eventbrite.ca


The Empty Room is a collective of Toronto theatre artists.

www.empty-room.com

story:
ABOUT THIS PROJECT

MEGAN BASCOM & DANCERS (MB&D), a modern dance company based in NYC, has been invited to bring their latest project, STAKE, to Miami, Florida as part of the Inkub8 Arts Open Studio Series during the Wynwood Arts Walk. In an effort to cover the costs of this project, including travel, rehearsals, costumes, original sound score, and dancers' stipends, we are asking for your help with a tax-deductible donation! The incredible performing artists whom your donation will support are: Anna Barker, Carly Berrett, Robin Cherof, Megan Sinnwell, Ben Wolk, Megan Bascom and composer Max Hershenow. We aim to raise $3000 for this tour to Miami.

ABOUT STAKE

Structured as a series of vignettes, STAKE looks into the ways in which we re-arrange our circumstances to better suit our lives.  Our new arrangements can be revealing, shedding light on what we truly value. Inspired additionally by the physical architecture of fences and gates as barriers and openings, the six dancers encounter scenarios they must compromise around and weave through. This work exists in a place both ethereal and grounded, involving continuously changing moments of comfort, unease, humor, loss, surprise, monotony and beauty.

WHAT YOUR SUPPORT FUNDS & WHAT WE'VE GOT FOR YOU!

Your donation will support MB&D's travel expenses, rehearsal and performance stipends for the beautiful dancers, an original commissioned score, rehearsal space, and costumes.

The company is thrilled to undertake our first out-of-state tour, and subsidizing the travel expenses for six dancers is of the utmost importance! This project would never have come to fruition without the valuable time and efforts of the collaborating artists. Our secondary, and equally important goal, is to compensate the dancers for their artistic contributions. It is easy to donate online and EVERY level of donation helps.

We are so grateful for your support and to count you as our friends and backers. To show our appreciation, MB&D has some Floridian delights set up for our donors!

We'd love to:

  • List you on our website's donor page 
  • Mail you a postcard from Miami signed by the dancers
  • Send you homemade marmalade made from fresh Florida oranges
  • Send you a copy of the original score for STAKE by Max Hershenow
  • Immortalize-You-In-The-Dance by creating a dance move for STAKE and naming it after YOU!

How your donation makes a difference:

  • $10 goes towards one hour of the artist's time
  • $50 covers rehearsal studio rental for one week
  • $100 covers one artist's food and living expenses for 4 days in Miami
  • $250 covers one artist's flight to Miami

WHO WE ARE

MEGAN BASCOM & DANCERS is a NYC based modern dance company that was founded in 2009. Our process is collaborative and mathematical, focusing on movement habits of people from all walks of life and patterns from natural and man-made surroundings. The individual characteristics, memories, impressions, and nuances of each collaborating artist are imperative and highly utilized during each project, as a choreographic platform to create works that ignite the imagination.

THANK YOU SO MUCH!

We know times are tough and schedules are busy, so we want to thank you for spending the time to check out our project on Indie Go Go and considering a donation. If you can give, on any level, MB&D would deeply appreciate your support. Thank you for making this project possible and helping all the artists involved to thrive! Check out our website www.meganbascom.com for more information.

All of our gratitude,

Megan Bascom, Artistic Director

with Anna Barker, Carly Berrett, Robin Cherof, Megan Sinnwell & Ben Wolk

story:
Our Story

My name is J Lyn and I am a professional dancer that teaches dance to youth all around the NYC area at non-profits, public schools, charter schools, and dance studios. A year and a half ago I visited Togo and Ghana and had the opportunity to teach dance. The students showed so much passion and dedication that I've been moved to start BTAM.


BTAM (Black To Africa Movement) is dedicated to using the performing arts to raise money to send West African youth that may not usually be able to afford tuition to school. I will be traveling to Accra, Ghana in late December to teach dance workshops and help the students create their own dance production for the community. The final production will be held at the University of Ghana at the end of the program. Nearby dance companies will perform and two students demonstrating need and exceptional talent will receive scholarships to help them continue their education.


The Impact

In 2003, only 27% of Togolese youth and 36% of Ghanaian youth enrolled into school. An estimate of 1/3 of Togo's population lives below the poverty line. Students wishing to enroll into school must pay a tuition fee for all grade levels, even in public schools. Too many families cannot afford to send their child to school and this program is designed to address this need. 


In addition, I believe that performing artists are called to do more than dance in music videos or to perform on stage in front of thousands, but to also make a positive difference in our communities with our talents. The arts are powerful and have the ability to inspire people. This is what BTAM is about.


What We Need & What You Get

We need funding for the following:


-Stipend for youth participants to afford travel to and from program

-Reserving rehearsal space at the University of Ghana

-Finances to bring a guest artist to perform for and inspire youth attendees to final show

-Set design and equipment rental for the final show


For all supporters, you will receive links to rehearsal footage, interviews of our 10 Ghanaian high school participants, and video of the final show. 


For donations of $100 and greater, you will receive a hand-crafted piece of artwork created in Togo. You will have the choice of jewelry, clothing, or painting.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! This is will be the first annual program and BTAM could use all the support possible!


BTAM is also accepting donations of school supplies. If you'd like to donate supplies, please send an email to blacktoafricamovement@gmail.com.


Thank you for your support!

story:
Our Story

ArtEffects Theatre Company was founded in 2009 by three theatre artists in New York City - Kristi McCarson, Zach McCoy and Phil Newsom. Our goal is to provide a safe place for all artists to create, learn, and grow. Since that time we have built a strong relationship with many actors, writers and directors through a series of productions, workshops, and play readings. The company mission statement is as follows:

 

ArtEffects Theatre Company strives to provide a positive environment where each artist can express themselves freely without judgement. Our company focuses on creative processes that include equal appreciation and collaboration among all artists.


The Project

We are now embarking on our biggest undertaking yet - presenting the New York premiere of the award-winning play "The Birthday Boys." Playwright Aaron Kozak has written one of the most thrilling, moving, and realistic portrayals of American soldiers in Iraq that we have ever read. If you have not heard of "The Birthday Boys" or Kozak, you soon will.  This play won a major award at last year’s LA Fringe Festival (Outstanding Contribution to LA Theatre Overall Fringe Performance), and the reviews were stellar:


To say that this very well may be the best thing to go up in the Fringe is an understatement. The Birthday Boys is written, directed and performed to perfection.

- Marcus Kaye (LA Theatre Review)

 

This play about three POW’s cuts straight through to the core. The ending left my jaw on the floor.  Excellent writing, excellent acting and an excellent fringe production.

- Ashley Steed (LA Stage Times)


With your help, ArtEffects Theatre Company wants to bring this play to New York audiences for the first time in a limited engagement 2-week run in September.  I think you will agree that in order to give this play the run it deserves, we will have to assemble not only an amazing cast, but a team of professional designers and technicians.  The theatre space is also incredibly important, and we have had the good fortune of securing the beautiful Access Black Box Theatre downtown, which will allow for both the time frame we need and more importantly, total creative freedom.  In order to make all this happen, we need your help!

 

The Impact

We cannot begin to express how important your contribution is to our company and the success of "The Birthday Boys."  Producing a play in New York is always a great expense, and your generosity and support of this project means the world to us.  Please note that there is no contribution too small - $10 could pay for a prop or an hour of rehearsal time in a studio.  Best of all, you will be contributing to a medium that is so important and vital to our culture.  Thank you for believing in this project as much as we do.  We will see you in the theatre!

story:
Who are we?

We are Lorem Ipsum, the award-winning theater group that brought Ubu Roi, Blood Wedding, and The Threepenny Opera to Portland, Maine. We are devoted to creating innovative and accessible productions of rare, classic, and new works. We are committed to collaborative creative techniques. Whatever we do, we will only do it if we want to and if it is fun. We firmly believe that if you see us do something, you will have fun too.

What is Ghosts?

Norwegian playwright Henrik Ibsen wrote Ghosts in 1881; it was controversial, scandalous, and not particularly well-received - "revoltingly suggestive and blasphemous," according to the Daily Chronicle.

Sporting and Dramatic News said: "Ninety-seven percent of the people who go to see Ghosts are nasty-minded people who find the discussion of nasty subjects to their taste in exact proportion to their nastiness."

We hope you'll be part of the 97 percent!

We are taking this piece of classic theater and airing it out, exploring its themes of sexual repression, the inescapable influence of our parents, and how the dead manifest in our present lives. Do not expect to see actors draped in white sheets. The title is an imperfect translation of the Norwegian word gengangere, which means 'those who walk again' or 'those who rise again.'

Lorem Ipsum's production of Ghosts, at SPACE March 22-April 1, will incorporate film by Last House Productions and Budget Fabulous Films as well as a fully mounted, immersive art exhibition in SPACE Gallery during the month of March.

What do we need?

We are asking for your help in raising $1881 for set, design, film, and projection materials, publicity costs, and to help us pay the talented and professional artists associated with this show. Our vision is ambitious and we need funds to realize it.

Who is Ghosts?

Cast - Karen Ball, Michael Dix Thomas, Corey Gagne, James Hoban, Tess Van Horn

Directors and co-producers - Nick Schroeder and Ian Carlsen

Artistic Designer - Jessica Townes George

Film Designers - Derek Kimball and David Meiklejohn

Lighting Design - Corey Anderson

Producer/Props - Deirdre Fulton

Costumes - Christina Klein

Stage Manager - Shawna Houston

story:
Our Story

New music ensemble thingNY and theatre performance co-operative the Panoply Performance Laboratory (PPL) present TIME: A Complete Explanation in Three Parts, a devised, multimedia work that zealously attempts to communicate one of humanity's most important yet elusive concepts. Exploiting the diverse and virtuosic skills of thingNY's and PPL's composers, actors, and multidisciplinary artists, the piece examines the histories, cultural role, and science of time through print, video and the performance of experiments and sequences created collaboratively by the two ensembles working as one. This hybrid of experimental music, theatre and written work forms an intricately mechanized "timepiece" telling of time throughout time, in real time, and sometimes just in time.
TIME: A Complete Explanation in Three Parts will premiere at The Brick Theater in Brooklyn, NY on May 5 with eight performances through May 15, 2011.

The work is influenced by the chance-based and aleatoric modes of the music of John Cage and Gerard Grisey, the durational modes of the performance art of Tehching Hsieh and Bas Jan Ader, the public theatre forms of the Berlinner Ensemble, the post-dramatic work of companies like KASSYS, and the philosophies and science of Nietzsche, Artistotle, Heidegger, Husserl, Einstein, and many others. Some sections and experiments occur before, during, and after the live performance at The Brick, extending in time through the “Performance Book” containing the program, the entire 60-page script, references, keys, diagrams, rules for participatory games, the musical score of the work, as well as instructions for durational experiments, photographs, visual pieces, footnotes and a complete bibliography.

The Impact

We're raising funds to help print and bind the Performance Book, a 300-page, hardcover tome containing the program, complete score and libretto and pages and pages of footnotes, endnotes, musical notes, results from experiments, scientific and philosophical terms, cited works and original writings and images. Audience members will be loaned a copy for each performance, which they may choose to purchase afterwards. With your help, TIME: A Complete Explanation in Three Parts can become truly multimedia, incorporating the written word and printed image and allowing the audience to experience the work even after they leave the theater.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $1300 more to print enough copies of the book for all the performances. If you're planning on attending a performance, pre-purchase a copy of the book and admission for $30 or two books and two tickets for $55. There are also opportunities to take part in the process and author a few pages of the finished book yourself. Check out which level of support fits you best.


The BOTTOM LINE

The Performance Book is a vital part of this project. As a multimedia work and a continuation of the performance, the Book fleshes out the dimensional and experiential aspects of time that can only be indicated in live performance. Last year, thingNY released a recording of its opera ADDDDDDDDD accompanied a comic book libretto, but neither group has previously attempted to create a book that is so fundamentally fused to their performed work. We would be grateful for your help in bringing this ambitious project to fruition.Thanks and please help spread the word about the performances May 5-15, 2011 at the Brick Theatre.


About the Artists

The Panoply Performance Laboratory (PPL) is a performance co-operative formed by director/librettist/designer Esther Neff and co-directed by composer/sound artist/musician Brian McCorkle. Following a mission to whip up mass participation in the distribution of the sensible, understand conceptual genealogies, socio-political structures, and performance itself, PPL creates music-driven, documentary-based performance works with a diverse array of collaborators, from all disciplines, fields, and walks of life. Additionally, PPL is dedicated to sustainable practices such as the use of recycled and found materials in their production of portable, low-budget performance art for a diverse audience. Their operas, plays, video, and music works have been seen at Dixon Place, The Brecht Forum, ABC No Rio, Surreal Estate, The West End Theater, The Manhattan Theatre Source, University Settlement, Gathering of the Tribes Gallery, pop-up galleries in Queens through QMAD, through residencies at IRT, the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council (LMCC), and in collaboration with Dina Keller, in Munich Germany. PPL manages the performance space at Surreal Estate, where they organize the PERFORMANCY FORUM.

thingNY is a 501c3 not-for-profit collective of composer-performers who create and perform theatrically charged experimental music, champion the work of avant-garde and contemporary classical composers, and collaborate across disciplines, media and genres. New Music Box hailed thingNY's first album, the eccentrically excessive opera ADDDDDDDDD, as "rapid-fire... pulseracing... all consuming.... packaged with a fun, quirky, comic book libretto. A lovely item that takes the album a step beyond the usual CD release, it makes the physical object in the digital age an interesting piece of art in and of itself, worthy of shelf space and providing plenty of additional visual stimulation."

story:
The Outlook Story

Wouldn't it be great if there really were such a thing as a magic wand? Susan Kelly, corporate trainer, has a comfortable life: a dayjob that pays the bills & benefits; a smart, focused daughter about to graduate from college; a long-term girlfriend (who just won't commit to actually living together). Then the mysterious Brown of UPS delivers a package that contains a gift: a wand that makes wishes come true, though never exactly as Susan expects. Brown sticks around to watch what happens (and add herself to the mix) as Susan comes to grips with what she's lost, what she's settled for, and whether joy is something you have to cut back on in these hard times (or whether it's essential to going on).

Outlook is a new play by Kathleen Warnock. Developed over the last two years by TOSOS and Emerging Artists Theatre, Outlook is now a full-length play, with a director, stage manager, and brilliant, beautiful cast, that's been invited present its world premiere in the 9th International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, May 14-20.

 

The Players

 

  • Kathleen Warnock (playwright) is a New York City-based playwright and editor. She gets around.
  • Mark Finley (director) made his Off-Broadway directorial debut with Chris Weikel’s “must see” comedy hit Penny Penniworth. Mark’s international credits include Chris Weikel’s Pig Tale, Kathleen Warnock’s Some Are People, and this year, Outlook, The F*cking World According to Molly and Michael Lynch’s Livin’ on the Real. 
  • Meghan Cary (SUSAN) has been honored to work with these wonderful actors on this fabulous play from the very beginning. Also a singer/songwriter, Meghan recently released her fourth CD, “Building This House.”  www.meghancary.com.
  • Donnetta Lavinia Grays (BROWN) is an actor, writer and director living in Brooklyn, NY. with credits on and Off-Broadway (Lisa Kron's "Well"), regionally, and film ("The Wrestler") and television ("Mercy," all the Law & Orders, and "A Gifted Man.") www.donnettagrays.com
  • Irene Longshore (ELLA) Recent New York Theatre: LUSH VALLEY (HERE Arts Center/U.S. Tour Fall 2012). Marathon 2011-In The Middle of The Night (Ensemble Studio Theatre); SOUNDING (HERE Arts); Graveyard Shift (Berkshire Fringe Festival); MONO (Off-Broadway); Twww.IreneLongshore.com
  • Danielle Quisenberry (PATIENCE)  Just completed her second feature film  “A Case of You,” with Justin Long and Evan Rachel Wood. When she is not on stage, in front of the camera or in a voiceover booth, you can find her teaching ballroom dance at The Actors Studio Drama School on the faculty of  Alvin Ailey. www.studioqd.com.
  • Jennifer Marie Russo (Stage Manager): New York: YANK! (Broadway workshop); The F***ing World According to Molly and A Molly, Jolly Holiday (NYC Fringe Festival/Laurie Beechman); The Best of Jim Caruso’s Cast Party 2011 and 2012 (Town Hall); Collision (The Public);  The Play About a Naked Guy, The Secretaries, Street Theater, Pig Tale (TOSOS).

 

The Impact

This campaign's goal is to raise the funds to pay for airfare and lodging for the cast and crew to Dublin this May. Anything we raise over that will go directly into the production (see below!)

What We Need & What You Get

It will cost $635 (roundtrip) to send each person to Ireland (and bring them all back!) We need to send 7 people  (cast, director, production stage manager, playwright). Total cost of airfare: $4475. Once there, the cast & crew will stay in a furnished apartment that will cost about $1700 total.

Successfully completing our goal for this campaign means that we can cover the plane tickets and lodging; anything over that will go to 1) groceries to stock the larder in the apartment; 2) a per diem for the actors; 3) promotional expenses (posters, postcards, photos) with which to plaster Dublin (and not ourselves. We can pay for our own drinks!)

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you know someone in Dublin? Tell them to come see our show! That's putting money in our pocket.

Do you have a mailing list? Would you consider doing an e-blast?

Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and write, post, or blog about it.
